IM Anat

Wednesday, 4 June 2025

10:22 PM

ID

Question

Explanation

1

Which of the following long bones is the first to ossifiy?

A. Femur

B. Radius

C. Clavicle

D. Fibula

Below is a table evaluating each option. All explanations and high-yield notes are drawn from Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy.

Option

Correct?

Explanation

A. Femur

Incorrect

The femur ossifies via endochondral centers in the prenatal period, but it is not the very first long bone to begin ossification. For example, the humerus (another long bone) begins ossifying at the end of the embryonic period (~8 weeks), and the femur follows shortly thereafter. Thus, although the femur is among early-ossifying long bones, it is not the first.

B. Radius

Incorrect

The radius also follows the typical endochondral sequence: a cartilaginous model forms during the fetal period, and ossification of the diaphysis does not begin until late in the embryonic period or early fetal period. However, it clearly begins ossifying later than the clavicle. Its primary ossification center is visible after the clavicle’s.

C. Clavicle

Correct

Although classified as a long bone, the clavicle forms primarily by intramembranous ossification and is the first long bone to ossify (ossification begins around the 5th–6th week of fetal life). All other long bones (femur, tibia, humerus, etc.) begin ossifying slightly later. The clavicle is also the last bone to fuse completely.

D. Fibula

Incorrect

The fibula’s primary ossification center appears in the late embryonic or early fetal period, after the clavicle has begun ossifying. It follows the general endochondral pattern seen in most long bones and does not precede the clavicle.

 

High-Yield Notes

  • Clavicle (first to ossify): Although designated a “long bone,” the clavicle uses intramembranous ossification for most of its length. Its primary center appears as early as the 5th–6th week of fetal development, making it the very first long bone to ossify. It remains the last bone to complete fusion (~20–25 years of age).
  • Endochondral vs. Intramembranous: Long bones such as the femur, humerus, radius, and fibula form from cartilage templates; their primary ossification centers appear near the end of the embryonic period (around 7–8 weeks for most). By contrast, the clavicle’s intramembranous center bypasses a cartilage model, expediting its early ossification.
  • Clinical relevance: Because the clavicle ossifies so early and fuses so late, fractures in children frequently involve the middle third, and clinicians can use its ossification status to estimate fetal age on prenatal imaging. Continuous monitoring of clavicular ossification also helps assess developmental milestones.

 

2

Which of the following bones makes up part of the roof of the orbit?

A. Frontal

B. Temporal

C. Maxillary

D. Ethmoid

Option

Correct?

Explanation

A

Correct

The orbital (horizontal) part of the frontal bone forms the majority of the roof of the orbit, separating it from the anterior cranial fossa. Near the apex, the lesser wing of the sphenoid contributes a small posteromedial portion, but the frontal bone is the principal contributor to the superior wall.

B

Incorrect

The temporal bone does not contribute to the orbital roof. Its squamous part and greater wing of the sphenoid lie more posterolaterally, forming the cranial vault and part of the middle cranial fossa, but not the orbital roof.

C

Incorrect

The maxilla forms the floor (inferior wall) of the orbit, not the roof. Its orbital surface overlies the maxillary , making it susceptible to “blowout” fractures but irrelevant to the superior wall.

D

Incorrect

The ethmoid bone contributes mainly to the medial wall of the orbit (via its orbital plate) and to the nasal septum and anterior cranial fossa. It does not form any part of the roof; its lamina papyracea lies medial to the orbital cavity.

 

High-Yield Notes

  • The roof of the orbit is almost entirely the orbital plate of the frontal bone, which also forms the floor of the anterior cranial fossa.
  • Near the apex of the orbit, a small portion of the roof is formed by the lesser wing of the sphenoid, but none of the other listed bones contributes to the roof.
  • The maxilla forms the thin orbital floor, sharing a wall with the maxillary sinus; hence, “blowout” fractures often involve it.
  • The ethmoid contributes to the medial wall (lamina papyracea), which is very thin and perforated by ethmoidal air cells, but it does not participate in the roof.
  • The temporal bone forms part of the cranial vault and middle cranial fossa but has no contact with the orbital roof.

3

Regarding the brachial plexus, which of the following statements is correct?

A. Ulnar nerve palsy results in weakness of the interossei and numbness over the radial part of the hand

B. Erb's palsy results in a medially rotated arm with elbow flexion

C. Injury proximal to the trunks will not affect the supraspinatus nor infraspinatus muscles

D. Pectoralis major is the only muscle that can test all roots

 

Thought for 10 seconds

Option

Correct?

Explanation

A

Incorrect

Ulnar nerve palsy does cause weakness of the interossei (the deep branch of the ulnar nerve innervates all interossei) but the sensory loss is over the medial one‐and‐a‐half digits (ulnar side), not the radial side of the hand. Thus, numbness localizes to the ulnar aspect of the palm and fingers (little finger and half of the ring finger), not the radial part. Moore - Clinically Orie… Moore - Clinically Orie…

B

Incorrect

Erb–Duchenne palsy (superior trunk injury) presents with the “waiter’s tip” posture: arm is adducted and medially rotated, but the elbow is extended, not flexed. Loss of C5–6–innervated elbow flexors (biceps, brachialis) results in an extended elbow and pronated forearm. Moore - Clinically Orie…

C

Incorrect

An injury proximal to the trunks (i.e., at the roots) affects all downstream branches, including the suprascapular nerve (which comes off the upper trunk). Therefore, muscles like supraspinatus and infraspinatus (innervated by the suprascapular nerve, C5–6) would be paralyzed, not spared. Moore - Clinically Orie…

D

Correct

Pectoralis major receives fibers from C5 through T1 (clavicular head via C5–6; sternocostal head via C7–8–T1). Testing pectoralis major function (adduction/medial rotation) thus evaluates contributions from all brachial plexus roots. No other single muscle spans every root (C5–T1) in its innervation. Moore - Clinically Orie…

 

 

High-Yield Notes

  • Ulnar nerve distribution: The ulnar nerve’s deep branch supplies the interossei and most intrinsic hand muscles; its sensory distribution is the medial one‐and‐a‐half digits and adjacent palm/dorsum—never the radial side. Moore - Clinically Orie…
  • Erb–Duchenne palsy: Results from C5–6 (upper trunk) injury. Loss of shoulder abduction (deltoid), lateral rotation (infraspinatus), and elbow flexion (biceps, brachialis) produces an adducted, medially rotated arm with an extended elbow. Moore - Clinically Orie…
  • Root-level injuries: Lesions at or above the roots impair all branches distally. The suprascapular nerve branches off the upper trunk, so a root lesion would disable supraspinatus/infraspinatus. Moore - Clinically Orie…
  • Pectoralis major innervation: Dual innervation by the lateral pectoral nerve (clavicular head, C5–6) and medial pectoral nerve (sternocostal head, C7–8–T1) means activation of this muscle tests all roots C5–T1. Moore - Clinically Orie…

4

The motor nuclei of the facial nerve are found in which of the following areas?

A. midbrain

B. pons

C. medulla oblongata

D. cerebellum

The correct answer is: B. Pons

 

✅ Explanation:

The motor nucleus of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is located in the lower pons, specifically in the pontine tegmentum. It contains cell bodies of lower motor neurons that supply:

  • Muscles of facial expression
  • Stapedius
  • Posterior belly of digastric
  • Stylohyoid

These fibers loop around the abducens nucleus, forming the facial colliculus on the floor of the fourth ventricle.

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

  • A. Midbrain → Contains nuclei of CN III (oculomotor) and CN IV (trochlear), not facial.
  • C. Medulla oblongata → Contains nuclei of CN IX, X, XI, and XII.
  • D. Cerebellum → Coordinates movement but does not contain cranial nerve motor nuclei.

 

✅ Final Answer: B. Pons

5

Which statement regarding forearm muscles is correct?

A. Palmaris longus (PL) is absent in 30% of cases

B. Pronator teres (PT) is the most powerful muscle for pronation

C. Flexor pollicis longus (FPL) is unipennate

D. Flexor carpi radialis (FCR) runs over whole length of flexor retinaculum

Option

Correct?

Explanation

A

Incorrect

The palmaris longus is absent in approximately 14% of people, not 30%. When present, its long, cord-like tendon passes superficial to the flexor retinaculum and attaches to the palmar aponeurosis.

B

Incorrect

Although pronator teres can pronate the forearm, the prime mover for pronation is the pronator quadratus. Pronator teres acts secondarily, providing speed and power when needed.

C

Incorrect

Flexor pollicis longus is described as a flat muscle (its fibers run longitudinally), not a unipennate muscle. Unipennate architecture is seen in muscles like some interossei, but FPL is a broad, flat muscle that “clothes” the anterior radius.

D

Incorrect

The tendon of flexor carpi radialis does not run over the entire flexor retinaculum. Instead, it passes through a canal in the lateral part of the flexor retinaculum and then through a groove in the trapezium (in its own synovial sheath).

 

High-Yield Notes

  • Palmaris Longus: Its presence is variable; when present, it tenses the palmar aponeurosis and flexes the wrist. Its tendon is a useful landmark for locating the median nerve at the wrist.
  • Pronation Muscles: The pronator quadratus is the main pronator (attaching distal ulna to distal radius), initiating pronation. Pronator teres assists when more speed or power is required.
  • Flexor Pollicis Longus Architecture: FPL is a flat, broad muscle arising from the anterior radius and interosseous membrane. Because it lacks a pennate arrangement, it should not be classified as unipennate.
  • Flexor Carpi Radialis Pathway: The FCR tendon becomes cord-like distally, then travels through (not over) the lateral portion of the flexor retinaculum in its own canal and synovial sheath. It is the guide to the radial artery at the wrist.

6

Which structure crosses the floor of the anatomical snuff box?

A. Ulnar nerve

B. Deep branch of radial nerve

C. Median nerve

D. Superficial radial nerve

Option

Correct?

Explanation

A

Incorrect

The ulnar nerve does not enter the anatomical snuff box; it courses along the medial forearm and into the ulnar (Guyon) canal at the wrist.

B

Incorrect

The deep branch of the radial nerve (posterior interosseous nerve) pierces the supinator and travels in the posterior compartment of the forearm; it does not cross the floor of the snuff box.

C

Incorrect

The median nerve runs deep to the flexor retinaculum into the carpal tunnel and does not reach the anatomical snuff box.

D

Incorrect

The superficial branch of the radial nerve passes just over the roof of the snuff box (becoming cutaneous on the dorsum of the hand), but it does not cross the floor.

 

High-Yield Note

  • The radial artery, not a nerve, is the structure that crosses the floor of the anatomical snuff box as it winds dorsally around the scaphoid and trapezium .

7

Which of the following statements is correct regarding the cerebral circulation?

A. The anterior cerebral artery is most likely to embolise

B. The largest branch is the anterior cerebral artery

C. The posterior communication artery joins the internal carotid artery and posterior cerebral artery

D. The basilar artery is branch of the internal carotid

The correct answer is: C. The posterior communicating artery joins the internal carotid artery and posterior cerebral artery

 

✅ Explanation of the Correct Answer:

  • The posterior communicating artery (PCoA) is part of the Circle of Willis.
  • It connects the internal carotid artery (anterior circulation) to the posterior cerebral artery (PCA, from posterior circulation).
  • This anastomosis allows for collateral flow between anterior and posterior circulations.

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

  • A. The anterior cerebral artery is most likely to embolise
    → Incorrect. The middle cerebral artery (MCA) is most commonly affected by emboli because it is the largest and most direct continuation of the internal carotid artery.
  • B. The largest branch is the anterior cerebral artery
    → Incorrect. The middle cerebral artery is the largest branch of the internal carotid and supplies the bulk of the lateral cerebral cortex.
  • D. The basilar artery is branch of the internal carotid
    → Incorrect. The basilar artery is formed by the union of the two vertebral arteries, not from the internal carotid.

 

✅ Final Answer: C. The posterior communicating artery joins the internal carotid artery and posterior cerebral artery

8

Which of the following branches of the external carotid artery do not arise in the carotid triangle?

A. Ascending pharyngeal artery

B. Posterior auricular artery

C. Lingual artery

D. Occipital artery

 

9

Which muscle is supplied by the posterior interosseous nerve in the posterior compartment of the forearm?

A. Extensor carpi radialis longus (ECRL)

B. Supinator

C. Anconeus

D. Brachioradilais

Option

Correct?

Explanation

A

Incorrect

ECRL is innervated by the radial nerve (C6, C7) before it branches into the deep branch. It is not supplied by the posterior interosseous nerve.

B

Correct

Supinator is innervated by the deep branch of the radial nerve, which, after passing through the supinator, becomes the posterior interosseous nerve. Although its proximal portion receives the deep branch before the name changes, it is functionally supplied by that same branch as it enters and exits the muscle.

C

Incorrect

Anconeus is innervated by a small branch directly from the radial nerve, not by the posterior interosseous nerve.

D

Incorrect

Brachioradialis is innervated by the radial nerve in the proximal forearm; it does not receive fibers from the posterior interosseous nerve.

 

High-Yield Notes

  • The deep branch of the radial nerve pierces the supinator; distal to this point it is referred to as the posterior interosseous nerve (“PIN”). Thus, muscles that lie entirely distal to where the deep branch exits supinator are truly supplied by the PIN.
  • Supinator receives innervation as the deep branch of the radial nerve travels between its fibers; once the branch exits the supinator, it becomes the PIN. In practice, supinator is functionally supplied by that same deep-branch/PIN continuum.
  • Other posterior compartment muscles like ECRL, Brachioradialis, and Anconeus receive direct branches from the radial nerve before it divides into deep and superficial branches; none of these is a PIN-innervated muscle.

10

Regarding the femoral artery, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It enters the adductor canal by piercing sartorius

B. It is separated from the hip joint capsule by fat only

C. It is found at the mid-inguinal point.

D. It gives off the medial femoral cutaneous as its major branch

Option

Correct?

Explanation

A

Incorrect

The femoral artery does not pierce sartorius to enter the adductor canal. Instead, it passes deep to the sartorius muscle and its overlying aponeurotic roof at the apex of the femoral triangle before entering the canal.

B

Incorrect

The femoral artery lies on the iliopsoas and pectineus muscles, not directly on fat. The hip joint capsule is separated from the artery by these muscular layers, so it is not “separated by fat only.”

C

Correct

The femoral artery is palpable at the mid-inguinal point (the midpoint between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis), where it lies just inferior to the inguinal ligament at the base of the femoral triangle.

D

Incorrect

The femoral artery’s major branches include the profunda femoris (deep femoral) artery, not a “medial femoral cutaneous.” “Medial femoral cutaneous” refers to a nerve branch of the femoral nerve, not an arterial branch.

 

High-Yield Notes

  • The mid-inguinal point (midpoint between ASIS and pubic symphysis) is the landmark for palpating and compressing the femoral artery. At this location, the artery lies superficial under the fascia lata within the femoral triangle.
  • Before entering the adductor canal, the artery courses through the femoral triangle, running on the iliopsoas and pectineus (floor of the triangle) and then travels deep to sartorius under its aponeurotic roof.
  • The profunda femoris artery is the largest branch of the femoral artery, arising about 3.75 cm below the inguinal ligament, and provides major blood supply to the thigh.
  • The femoral sheath encloses the artery, vein, and canal but not the nerve. It allows vessel glide under the inguinal ligament during hip movements.

11

Which is FALSE regarding supination and pronation movements of the upper limb?

A. About 140 degrees of rotation occurs at the radioulnar joints during pronation and supination

B. The ulnar is entirely stationary during pronation and supination

C. The movements of supination and pronation occur at the superior and inferior radioulnar joints

D. During supination and pronation the axis of movement of the radius relative to the ulnar passes through the radial head and ulnar styloid

    Option

    Explanation

    A.

    False. Moore describes the radius rotating around the ulna during pronation and supination but does not support a total of ~140°; in fact, the functional range is closer to 150°–160°, making “about 140°” inaccurate.

    B.

    True. During pronation and supination, the ulna remains fixed while the radius pivots around it at both proximal and distal radioulnar joints.

    C.

    True. Supination and pronation occur at the superior (proximal) and inferior (distal) radioulnar joints.

    D.

    True. The axis of rotation runs proximally through the center of the radial head and distally through the ulnar styloid, defining the pivot for supination/pronation.

    •  

12

A patient with acute necrotizing pancreatitis develops intra-abdominal bleeding. Which artery is the likely source?

A. Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery

B. Superior pancreaticoduodenal artery

C. Short gastric artery

D. Splenic artery

The correct answer is: D. Splenic artery

Explanation:

In acute necrotizing pancreatitis, the pancreas becomes inflamed and starts to autodigest surrounding tissues, including nearby blood vessels. Among the vessels that lie close to the pancreas, the splenic artery is particularly vulnerable due to its anatomical proximity—it runs along the superior border of the pancreas.

  • Necrosis or enzymatic digestion can lead to pseudoaneurysm formation or direct erosion into the artery, resulting in life-threatening intra-abdominal hemorrhage.
  • While the pancreaticoduodenal arteries (superior and inferior) and short gastric artery can be involved in bleeding, they are less commonly affected compared to the splenic artery in the context of necrotizing pancreatitis.

Summary:

  • Most common artery involved in bleeding from necrotizing pancreatitis: Splenic artery. ✅

Let me know if you'd like a diagram or further anatomical context.\

 

13

In relation to the plantar aponeurosis, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It forms the central compartment of the sole

B. Is not attached to the skin of the sole

C. Covers the abductors of the big and little toe

D. Arises from the talus

 

Explanation

A.

True. The plantar aponeurosis forms the strong, central portion of the deep fascia of the sole and serves as the superficial “roof” of the central compartment; vertical septa extend from its margins to create and define this compartment.

B.

False. The skin of the sole is anchored directly to the underlying plantar aponeurosis via fibrous septa, securing the skin to the deep fascia.

C.

False. The abductors of the great toe (abductor hallucis) and little toe (abductor digiti minimi) lie in the medial and lateral compartments, respectively, and are covered by thinner medial and lateral plantar fascia, not by the central plantar aponeurosis.

D.

False. The plantar aponeurosis arises posteriorly from the calcaneus (not the talus).

14

Which of the following cranial foramina and contents is INCORRECT?

A. Foramen ovale = Mandibular nerve (CN V3)

B. Foramen spinosum = Middle meningeal artery

C. Jugular foramen = CN X

D. Foramen rotundum = Ophthalmic nerve (CN V1)

Option

Foramen

Contents

Correct?

A

Foramen ovale

Mandibular nerve (CN V₃)

✅ Correct

B

Foramen spinosum

Middle meningeal artery

✅ Correct

C

Jugular foramen

CN IX, X, XI (includes CN X)

✅ Correct

D

Foramen rotundum

Maxillary nerve (CN V₂) — NOT V₁

❌ Incorrect

15

Regarding the interossei of the hand, which of the following statements is incorrect?

A. They insert into proximal phalanges

B. They insert into dorsal expansion

C. When they act together, the MCP joints flex and the interphalangeal joints extend

D. The palmer interossei abduct and the dorsal interossei adduct.

 

Explanation

A.

True. Each interosseous muscle sends part of its tendon to insert on the base of the proximal phalanx of its respective digit, providing flexion force at the MCP joint.

B.

True. In addition to inserting on the proximal phalanx, part of each interosseous tendon fans out into the extensor (dorsal) expansion, contributing to extension of the IP joints.

C.

True. When interossei contract together (with the lumbricals), they flex the metacarpophalangeal joints while extending the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints (the “Z‐movement”).

D.

False. Palmar interossei adduct the fingers toward the axial line, whereas dorsal interossei abduct them away from the axial line—so the roles are reversed from what is stated.

16

Regarding the menisci of the knee, which of the following statements is correct?

A. The medial meniscus is vascular

B. The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) extends anteromedially and is attached to the anterolateral aspect of the medial femoral condyle

C. fold of synovium lies posterior to anterior cruciate

D. The anterior horn of medial meniscus is attached to medial tibial condyle

 

Explanation

A.

False. The menisci are fibrocartilage with only their peripheral (outer) one‐third having a blood supply; the medial meniscus as a whole is not vascular.

B.

True. The PCL arises from the posterior intercondylar area of the tibia, then passes superiorly and anteriorly on the medial side of the ACL to attach to the anterior part of the lateral surface of the medial femoral condyle (i.e., its anterolateral aspect).

C.

False. Although synovial membrane reflects around the cruciate ligaments, there is no discrete “fold of synovium” lying directly posterior to the ACL; instead, the infrapatellar synovial fold lies anterior to it, enclosing both cruciate ligaments and excluding them from the articular cavity.

D.

False. The anterior horn of the medial meniscus attaches to the anterior intercondylar area of the tibia (the intercondylar eminence), not to the medial tibial condyle.

17

55-year-old woman has an axillary lymph node dissection for breast cancer. Following this, she is unable to medially rotate her arm. Which nerve has most likely been damaged?

A. Thoracodorsal nerve

B. Dorsal scapular nerve

C. Nerve to subclavius

D. Long thoracic nerve

 

Explanation

A.

True. The thoracodorsal nerve (C6–C8) supplies the latissimus dorsi, which is a prime medial rotator of the humerus. Injury to this nerve in the axilla (e.g., during lymph node dissection) paralyzes latissimus dorsi, leading to an inability to medially rotate the arm.

B.

False. The dorsal scapular nerve innervates the rhomboids and levator scapulae, muscles that retract and elevate the scapula, not medial rotation of the humerus.

C.

False. The nerve to subclavius innervates the subclavius muscle, which stabilizes and depresses the clavicle; it does not contribute to humeral medial rotation.

D.

False. The long thoracic nerve supplies serratus anterior, which protracts and rotates the scapula; it does not medially rotate the humerus.

18

Regarding the ligaments of the knee, which of the following statements is correct?

A. The posterior cruciate is longer and stronger than the anterior cruciate ligament

B. The posterior cruciate ligament is attached to the medial condyle of the femur

C. The posterior cruciate stops the tibia slipping forward on the femur

D. Lateral collateral ligament makes a significant contribution to the capsule

 

Explanation

A.

False. While the PCL is the stronger cruciate ligament, it is not longer than the ACL. The ACL and PCL have similar lengths, but the PCL’s fibers are broader and thicker, making it stronger, not longer.

B.

True. The PCL passes upward and forward to attach to the anterior aspect of the medial femoral condyle, securing it to that surface.

C.

False. The PCL prevents the tibia from slipping backward (posterior displacement) on the femur when the knee is flexed; it does not stop the tibia from moving forward—that is the ACL’s function.

D.

False. The lateral (fibular) collateral ligament lies outside the joint capsule (extracapsular) and is not incorporated into the fibrous capsule, so it does not contribute to the capsule itself.

19

A 60-year-old lady presents with a cough and fever. Her CXR reveals consolidation in the posteroinferior portion of her right lower lobe. Percussion adjacent to which vertebral level would reveal an abnormality?

A. T4

B. T2

C. T6

D. T8

The right lower lobe of the lung is primarily located posteriorly. The inferior border of the lung, where the posteroinferior portion of the right lower lobe would be, extends to approximately the 10th thoracic vertebra (T10) posteriorly, with variations depending on respiration.

Consolidation in the lung, such as from pneumonia, causes the lung tissue to become dense and fluid-filled, which will produce dullness to percussion.

Therefore, to percuss over the posteroinferior portion of the right lower lobe, you would need to percuss at a vertebral level corresponding to that area.

Let's evaluate the options:

  • A. T4: This is typically associated with the upper or middle lobes of the lung posteriorly.
  • B. T2: This is even higher, in the apical region of the lung.
  • C. T6: While part of the lower lobe extends to this level, the "posteroinferior" aspect would be lower.
  • D. T8: This vertebral level aligns well with the posterior and inferior aspects of the right lower lobe. Percussing around T8 would be most likely to reveal dullness from consolidation in the posteroinferior right lower lobe.

The final answer is D​

20

Which of the following is caused by Injury to the middle trunk of the brachial plexus?

A. Will manifest in the medial cord

B. C8 sensation will be affected

C. Affects the long thoracic nerve

D. Affects the median nerve

The correct answer is: D. Affects the median nerve

 

✅ Explanation:

The middle trunk of the brachial plexus is formed by the C7 root. It contributes to the formation of the posterior and lateral cords, and therefore plays a role in the development of nerves that arise from these cords.

One of the major nerves that receives fibers from C7 (via the lateral cord) is the median nerve.

So, injury to the middle trunk can lead to deficits in areas supplied by the median nerve, such as:

  • Forearm flexors
  • Thenar muscles
  • Lateral hand sensation (thumb, index, middle fingers)

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

  • A. Will manifest in the medial cord
    → Incorrect: The medial cord is formed from the lower trunk (C8–T1), not the middle trunk.
  • B. C8 sensation will be affected
    → Incorrect: The middle trunk is derived from C7, not C8. C8 is part of the lower trunk.
  • C. Affects the long thoracic nerve
    → Incorrect: The long thoracic nerve arises from C5–C7 roots, before the trunks form. A middle trunk injury would not directly affect it.

 

✅ Final Answer: D. Affects the median nerve

21

Which of the following statements is correct in relation to the radial artery?

A. Lies on brachioradialis in the upper arm

B. In its middle third, the radial nerve lies medial to it

C. Passes between the tendons of extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL)

D. Forms both the anterior and posterior carpal arches with the ulnar artery

 

Explanation

A.

False. The radial artery does not lie on the brachioradialis in the upper arm; it arises in the cubital fossa and then runs under cover of brachioradialis in the forearm.

B.

False. In the forearm, the radial nerve does not lie medial to the radial artery; instead, the nerve descends lateral to the artery as they run together under brachioradialis.

C.

False. Although the radial artery crosses the floor of the anatomical snuff box, it does so beneath the tendons of extensor pollicis longus medially and extensor pollicis brevis/abductor pollicis longus laterally, rather than strictly between only the EPB and APL.

D.

True. The radial and ulnar arteries contribute to both the palmar (anterior) and dorsal (posterior) carpal arches via their palmar carpal and dorsal carpal branches, respectively.

22

Which nerve is responsible for the afferent pathway of the gag reflex?

A. CN IX

B. CN V

C. CN VII

D. CN VIII

✅ Correct Answer: A. CN IX (Glossopharyngeal nerve)

 

🧠 Explanation:

  • The gag reflex involves:
    • Afferent limb (sensory input): Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)
    • Efferent limb (motor response): Vagus nerve (CN X)

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

Option

Nerve

Function

Why Incorrect

B. CN V

Trigeminal nerve

Sensory to face, oral cavity (V₃ to tongue)

❌ Not posterior pharynx

C. CN VII

Facial nerve

Motor to facial muscles, taste (ant. 2/3 tongue)

❌ No role in gag reflex

D. CN VIII

Vestibulocochlear

Hearing and balance

❌ Not involved in reflexes of oropharynx

 

📝 Quick Mnemonic:

"9 in, 10 out"

  • CN IX – Afferent (sensory input)
  • CN X – Efferent (motor response)

Would you like a chart of brainstem reflexes and their corresponding cranial nerves?

23

Which of the following is a fusiform muscle?

A. Deltoid

B. Orbicularis oris

C. Biceps Brachii

D. Pectoralis major

 

Explanation

A.

False. The deltoid is multipennate, not fusiform.

B.

False. The orbicularis oris is a circular (sphincteral) muscle.

C.

True. The biceps brachii is spindle-shaped with a thick belly and tapered ends, classifying it as fusiform.

D.

False. The pectoralis major is a convergent (fan-shaped) muscle, not fusiform.

24

Which of the following muscles controls vocal cord abduction in the larynx?

A. Posterior cricoarytenoid

B. Aryepiglottic

C. Cricothyroid

D. Thyroarytenoid

The correct answer is:

A. Posterior cricoarytenoid

Explanation:

  • The posterior cricoarytenoid is the only muscle that abducts (opens) the vocal cords by rotating the arytenoid cartilages laterally.
  • This action is crucial for breathing, as it opens the rima glottidis (space between the vocal cords).

Other options:

  • B. Aryepiglottic – helps close the laryngeal inlet during swallowing.
  • C. Cricothyroid – tenses and elongates the vocal cords (increases pitch), but does not abduct them.
  • D. Thyroarytenoid – relaxes the vocal cords (lowers pitch), also not involved in abduction.

Let me know if you’d like a visual of laryngeal muscles or innervation details!

25

If a herniation of a cervical disc occurs at the C5-C6 level, in what region would the pain most likely be refered?

A. Thumb

B. Fingers

C. Lateral arm

D. Shoulder

The correct answer is: A. Thumb

 

✅ Explanation:

A herniated cervical disc at the C5–C6 level typically compresses the C6 nerve root (because cervical nerves exit above their corresponding vertebrae until C8).

 

🔍 C6 Nerve Root — Key Innervation Areas:

  • Sensory (dermatome):
    • Lateral forearm
    • Thumb
    • Index finger (partially)
  • Motor:
    • Biceps and wrist extensors
  • Reflex:
    • Biceps reflex may be diminished

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

  • B. Fingers
    → Too vague, but if referring to middle or ring fingers, this would suggest C7 or C8 involvement.
  • C. Lateral arm
    → Suggests C5 root (from C4–C5 disc level).
  • D. Shoulder
    → Also more likely to be C5 or suprascapular nerve involvement.

 

✅ Final Answer: A. Thumb

26

Regarding the sacroiliac joint, which is true?

A. The joint surfaces are smooth

B. Both bones are covered by articular cartilage at the joint surface

C. The SI joint does not allow any movment

D. They are saddle joints

 

Explanation

A.

False. The auricular surfaces of the sacrum and ilium are irregular with interlocking elevations and depressions, not smooth.

B.

True. Both the sacral and iliac auricular surfaces are covered with articular cartilage in the synovial portion of the joint.

C.

False. Although movement is minimal, the sacroiliac joint allows slight gliding and rotation to transmit weight from the spine to the pelvis.

D.

False. The anterior part of the sacroiliac joint is a plane synovial joint (with the posterior part a syndesmosis), not a saddle‐shaped articulation.

27

Regarding ossification centres, which of the following statements is correct?

A. The medial epicondyle fuses at 20 years

B. The capitate ossifies at 10 years

C. The two centres of radius ossify by 15years

D. The pisiform ossifies by the end of the 1st year

 

28

Carpal tunnel syndrome is proved by allexcept?

A. Loss of sensation over the thenar eminence but not the central palm

B. Relief of symptoms after surgical incision of the flexor retinaculum

C. Loss of sensation over the medial three and a half digits

D. Weakness of the thenar muscles

Option

Explanation

A.

False. In carpal tunnel syndrome, sensation over the thenar eminence (supplied by the palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve) is preserved. The central palm is not affected, but the thenar eminence remains sensate because its cutaneous branch leaves before the tunnel.

B.

True. Surgical division of the flexor retinaculum relieves pressure on the median nerve; resolution of symptoms after this procedure confirms the diagnosis.

C.

False. CTS causes sensory loss in the lateral (radial) three and a half digits, not the medial digits. Loss over the medial three and a half digits would implicate an ulnar or combined neuropathy, not a pure median-nerve compression at the carpal tunnel.

D.

True. Weakness or atrophy of the thenar muscles (particularly abductor pollicis brevis and opponens pollicis) is a hallmark of median-nerve compression in the carpal tunnel.

29

Superior pancreaticoduodenal vein drains into which of the following?

A. Splenic vein

B. Portal vein

C. Superior mesenteric vein

D. Inferior vena cava (IVC)

Here's the detailed analysis in table format for your MCQ:

Question: Superior pancreaticoduodenal vein drains into which of the following?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Splenic vein

❌ Incorrect

The inferior pancreaticoduodenal vein may contribute to the splenic vein via the portal system, but the superior pancreaticoduodenal vein specifically does not drain into the splenic vein.

B. Portal vein

✅ Correct

The superior pancreaticoduodenal vein drains into the portal vein, either directly or via the right gastroepiploic vein. It drains blood from the head of the pancreas and duodenum, areas supplied by the celiac trunk.

C. Superior mesenteric vein

❌ Incorrect

The inferior pancreaticoduodenal vein drains into the superior mesenteric vein (SMV), not the superior one.

D. Inferior vena cava (IVC)

❌ Incorrect

The IVC receives blood from systemic veins, not the portal system. The pancreaticoduodenal veins are part of the portal venous system, so they do not drain directly into the IVC.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Portal vein

Let me know if you'd like a rapid review on related anatomy or more MCQs.

30

What, either directly or indirectly, provide sensation to the majority of the peripheral diaphragmatic pleura?

A. Phrenic nerves

B. Intercostal nerves

C. Costophrenic nerves

D. Subcostal nerves

Here's the detailed table analysis for your MCQ:

Question: What, either directly or indirectly, provide sensation to the majority of the peripheral diaphragmatic pleura?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Phrenic nerves

❌ Incorrect

The phrenic nerve supplies central diaphragmatic pleura and mediastinal pleura, not the peripheral diaphragmatic pleura.

B. Intercostal nerves

✅ Correct

The intercostal nerves (T7–T11) supply the peripheral diaphragmatic pleura via their lateral branches, and also contribute to the costal pleura.

C. Costophrenic nerves

❌ Incorrect

There is no distinct anatomical structure called the "costophrenic nerves." This appears to be a distractor or misnomer.

D. Subcostal nerves

❌ Incorrect

The subcostal nerve (T12) may contribute minimally to the sensory supply of the lower thoracic wall and diaphragm, but it does not primarily supply the peripheral diaphragmatic pleura.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Intercostal nerves

Let me know if you'd like a quick summary diagram or more pleural nerve supply questions!

31

In relation to bone, which of the following is correct?

A. Haversian canals are the smallest canals in bone

B. Periostium covers the articulating surface of bones

C. Cancellous bone is capable of rearrangement in response to strain

D. Bone substance does not recieve its nutrition from the periostium

 

32

Regarding the testicle, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It has no parasympathetic supply

B. Vas deferens lies in the lower, posterior part of the cord

C. Appendix testis is attached to inferior pole of the testis

D. It drains to the pre-aortic and inguinal nodes

Here's the detailed analysis for your MCQ:

Question: Regarding the testicle, which of the following statements is correct?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. It has no parasympathetic supply

❌ Incorrect

The testis does have parasympathetic innervation via the testicular plexus, which contains sympathetic and parasympathetic fibers from the renal and aortic plexuses.

B. Vas deferens lies in the lower, posterior part of the cord

✅ Correct

In the spermatic cord, the vas deferens lies in the posterior and slightly inferior part. This is a standard anatomical relationship appreciated during surgeries like hernia repairs.

C. Appendix testis is attached to inferior pole of the testis

❌ Incorrect

The appendix testis is a remnant of the Müllerian duct and is typically located at the superior pole of the testis, near the head of the epididymis.

D. It drains to the pre-aortic and inguinal nodes

❌ Incorrect

The **testis drains to the pre-aortic (lumbar) nodes, not to the inguinal nodes. Inguinal nodes are involved in drainage of the scrotal skin, not the testis itself.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Vas deferens lies in the lower, posterior part of the cord

Let me know if you'd like similar questions on male reproductive anatomy or lymphatic drainage.

33

Which of the following statements is correct in relation to the diaphragm and its openings?

A. Is supplied by C4, 5, 6

B. Has the oesophageal opening opposite the T8 vertebrae

C. Has a vena caval opening at T10

D. Has an aortic opening opposite T12

Here's the detailed table analysis for your MCQ:

Question: Which of the following statements is correct in relation to the diaphragm and its openings?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Is supplied by C4, 5, 6

❌ Incorrect

The diaphragm is primarily supplied by the phrenic nerve, which originates from C3, C4, and C5. The classic mnemonic is: "C3, 4, 5 keeps the diaphragm alive." C6 is not involved.

B. Has the oesophageal opening opposite the T8 vertebrae

❌ Incorrect

The oesophageal opening lies at the level of T10, not T8. It transmits the oesophagus, vagus nerves, and esophageal branches of left gastric vessels.

C. Has a vena caval opening at T10

❌ Incorrect

The vena caval opening (for the IVC) is at T8, not T10. It lies in the central tendon and transmits the IVC and right phrenic nerve branches.

D. Has an aortic opening opposite T12

✅ Correct

The aortic opening is at the level of T12 and transmits the aorta, thoracic duct, and azygos vein. It lies posterior to the diaphragm, between the crura.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Has an aortic opening opposite T12

Would you like a mnemonic or quick visual summary to help remember these levels (T8–T10–T12)?

34

Form which nerves does localised back pain initially originate?

A. Mixed nerve roots

B. Mixed spinal nerves

C. Posterior rami

D. Meningeal branches of spinal nerves

Here's the detailed analysis for your MCQ:

Question: From which nerves does localized back pain initially originate?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Mixed nerve roots

❌ Incorrect

The nerve roots are primarily involved in radicular pain (shooting pain radiating along a dermatome), not localized back pain.

B. Mixed spinal nerves

❌ Incorrect

Mixed spinal nerves give rise to both anterior and posterior rami but do not directly localize the pain. They contribute to multiple branches, making them too broad as the initial source of localized back pain.

C. Posterior rami

✅ Correct

The posterior (dorsal) rami innervate the zygapophyseal (facet) joints, deep back muscles, and overlying skin. These are the primary structures involved in localized back pain. Hence, posterior rami are the correct and specific source.

D. Meningeal branches of spinal nerves

❌ Incorrect

These nerves (also called recurrent meningeal or sinuvertebral nerves) innervate the dura, posterior longitudinal ligament, and outer annulus fibrosus, and are more involved in referred or radicular pain, not localized musculoskeletal pain.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Posterior rami

Let me know if you’d like to go deeper into pain pathways or referred pain mechanisms.

35

A rugby player requires repair of a laceration to his pinna in the emergency department. Blockade of which nerve will provide appropriate sensory anaesthesia?

A. Vagus

B. Maxillary

C. Facial

D. Mandibular

The correct answer is: D. Mandibular

 

✅ Explanation:

The pinna (auricle) receives sensory innervation from several nerves, but the major anterior and superior part of the pinna is innervated by the auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular division (V3) of the trigeminal nerve.

So, to anesthetize the pinna (especially anterior and superior parts) for a laceration repair, a block of the mandibular nerve (via the auriculotemporal branch) is appropriate.

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

  • A. Vagus
    → The auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Arnold's nerve) supplies only the posterior and external auditory canal, not the pinna’s anterior surface.
  • B. Maxillary (V2)
    → Supplies the midface, not the external ear.
  • C. Facial
    → Mainly motor to facial muscles. It has a small sensory component, but not sufficient for auricular anaesthesia.

 

🧠 Bonus: Other nerves contributing to pinna sensation:

  • Auriculotemporal nerve (V3) – anterior/superior pinna
  • Greater auricular nerve (C2–C3) – lower pinna and earlobe
  • Lesser occipital nerve (C2) – upper posterior pinna
  • Auricular branch of the vagus – external auditory canal

 

✅ Final Answer: D. Mandibular

36

Following infiltration around the knee with local anaesthetic, a patient reports weakness to eversion. Which nerve has most likely been affected?

A. Superficial fibular nerve

B. Posterior tibial nerve

C. Saphenous nerve

D. Sural nerve

 

Explanation

A.

True. The superficial fibular (peroneal) nerve innervates the fibularis longus and brevis, which are responsible for foot eversion. Infiltration around the knee can block this nerve as it courses superficially in the lateral compartment.

B.

False. The posterior tibial nerve supplies plantarflexors and intrinsic foot muscles; it does not control eversion.

C.

False. The saphenous nerve is purely sensory, supplying the medial leg and foot, and has no motor function.

D.

False. The sural nerve is also purely sensory, supplying the lateral foot and ankle, with no role in motor control of eversion.

37

Which is the incorrect dermatome description of the upper arm?

A. C5= lateral aspect of the arm

B. C3, C4= region at base of neck, extending laterally over the shoulder

C. C8= little finger, medial side of hand and forearm

D. T1= medial aspect of forearm and superior arm

 

Explanation

A.

True. C5 dermatome covers the lateral aspect of the arm.

B.

True. C3 and C4 cover the region at the base of the neck extending laterally over the shoulder.

C.

True. C8 covers the little finger and the medial side of the hand and forearm.

D.

False. T1 covers the medial aspect of the forearm and the inferior (not superior) part of the arm.

38

The myotome of the great toe extension is

A. S2

B. L4

C. L5

D. S1

 

Explanation

A.

False. S2 innervates muscles for plantarflexion and hamstring function, not great toe extension.

B.

False. L4 is primarily responsible for ankle dorsiflexion (tibialis anterior) and knee extension, not great toe extension.

C.

True. Great toe extension (extensor hallucis longus) is innervated by the deep fibular nerve, corresponding to the L5 myotome.

D.

False. S1 controls plantarflexion (gastrocnemius, soleus) and eversion, not great toe extension.

39

Regarding the phrenic nerve, which of the following statements is correct?

A. Each phrenic nerve supplies only one side of the diaphragm

B. Structures relating to both phrenic nerves are identical

C. They arise principally from C5 nerve root

D. They give of a recurrent laryngeal nerve branch

The correct answer is: A. Each phrenic nerve supplies only one side of the diaphragm

 

Explanation:

Let’s examine each option:

 

A. Each phrenic nerve supplies only one side of the diaphragm ✅

✔ Correct. The right phrenic nerve supplies the right hemidiaphragm, and the left phrenic nerve supplies the left hemidiaphragm. Each nerve acts independently, though both work in coordination for diaphragmatic movement.

 

B. Structures relating to both phrenic nerves are identical ❌

✘ Incorrect. The course and relations of the right and left phrenic nerves differ:

  • Right phrenic nerve: runs alongside the right side of the heart and enters the diaphragm near the IVC opening.
  • Left phrenic nerve: crosses the arch of the aorta and pericardium overlying the left ventricle.

 

C. They arise principally from C5 nerve root ❌

✘ Incorrect. The phrenic nerve arises from C3, C4, and C5, with C4 contributing the most. The classic mnemonic is:

“C3, 4, 5 keep the diaphragm alive.”

 

D. They give off a recurrent laryngeal nerve branch ❌

✘ Incorrect. The recurrent laryngeal nerve is a branch of the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X), not the phrenic nerve.

 

Summary:

  • Correct statement: A. Each phrenic nerve supplies only one side of the diaphragm

Let me know if you’d like a comparison table or schematic for phrenic nerve anatomy.

40

In relation to the circle of Willis, which of the following statements is correct?

A. The anterior cerebral artery (ACA), the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) and middle cerebral artery (MCA) are all branches of the internal carotid artery (ICA)

B. Congenital aneurysms are more commonly found on the posterior cerebral artery (PCA)

C. Most emboli lodge in the basilar part of the circle of Willis

D. The middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies the lateral surface of the brain and the temporal lobe

The correct answer is: D. The middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies the lateral surface of the brain and the temporal lobe

 

✅ Explanation of the Correct Answer:

  • The middle cerebral artery (MCA) is the largest branch of the internal carotid artery.
  • It supplies:
    • Most of the lateral surface of the cerebral hemispheres
    • Lateral frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes
    • Important functional areas: Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas, primary motor and sensory cortex for face and upper limbs

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

  • A. The ACA, PCA, and MCA are all branches of the ICA
    → Incorrect:
    • The ACA and MCA are branches of the internal carotid artery.
    • The PCA arises from the basilar artery, which is formed by the vertebral arteries (posterior circulation).
  • B. Congenital aneurysms are more commonly found on the PCA
    → Incorrect:
    • Berry (saccular) aneurysms are most common at the anterior part of the circle of Willis, especially at the junction of the ACA and anterior communicating artery.
    • PCA aneurysms are much less common.
  • C. Most emboli lodge in the basilar part of the circle of Willis
    → Incorrect:
    • Most emboli from the heart or large arteries tend to lodge in the MCA, not the basilar artery.
    • The MCA has a direct path from the internal carotid and a large diameter, making it the most common site for embolic strokes.

 

✅ Final Answer: D. The middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies the lateral surface of the brain and the temporal lobe

41

Which statement regarding the interossei of the hand is correct?

A. Palmar interossei cause abduction

B. Arise from the flexor retinaculum

C. Innervated by a deep branch of ulnar nerve

D. Combined palmar and dorsal interossei cause abduction

 

Explanation

A.

False. The palmar interossei adduct the fingers toward the axial line; they do not abduct.

B.

False. The interossei arise from the metacarpal shafts, not from the flexor retinaculum.

C.

True. Both the palmar and dorsal interossei are innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve.

D.

False. Only the dorsal interossei abduct and the palmar interossei adduct; together they do not both cause abduction.

42

A patient is unable to look down when his right eye is abducted. Which muscle is affected?

A. Inferior oblique

B. Superior oblique

C. Superior rectus

D. Inferior rectus

➤ When the eye is abducted (turned outward/laterally):

  • The superior oblique is the primary depressor of the eye in this position.
  • This is because the axis of the eye aligns with the pull of the superior oblique when the eye is abducted.

Clinical Interpretation:

  • If the patient cannot look down when the eye is abducted, it indicates weakness of the superior oblique muscle, which is innervated by cranial nerve IV (trochlear nerve).

 

Summary:

  • Correct answer: B. Superior oblique
  • Likely cranial nerve involvement: Trochlear nerve palsy (CN IV)

43

Which of the following statements is correct regarding the newborn skull?

A. The anterior fontanelle has as its borders the frontal,parietal,temporal,sphenoid bones

B. The posterior fontanelle has as its borders the occipital,parietal,temporal bones

C. The bones of the skull develop by intramembranous ossification and by endochondral ossification

D. The skull has similar vertical proportions to the adult

Here's the detailed table analysis for your MCQ:

Question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the newborn skull?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. The anterior fontanelle has as its borders the frontal, parietal, temporal, sphenoid bones

❌ Incorrect

The anterior fontanelle is bounded by the frontal and parietal bones only. The temporal and sphenoid bones are not directly involved in the margins of the anterior fontanelle.

B. The posterior fontanelle has as its borders the occipital, parietal, temporal bones

❌ Incorrect

The posterior fontanelle is located at the junction of the two parietal bones and the occipital bone. The temporal bone is not part of this junction.

C. The bones of the skull develop by intramembranous ossification and by endochondral ossification

✅ Correct

This is correct. Most flat bones of the skull (like the frontal and parietal bones) form via intramembranous ossification, while bones at the base of the skull (like the occipital base, sphenoid, and temporal bones) form via endochondral ossification.

D. The skull has similar vertical proportions to the adult

❌ Incorrect

The newborn skull has disproportionately larger cranial volume compared to the face. The facial skeleton is much smaller in newborns, so the vertical proportions differ significantly from those of adults.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. The bones of the skull develop by intramembranous ossification and by endochondral ossification

Let me know if you want a breakdown of fontanelle closure timelines or skull development stages.

44

Which of the following is a branch of the anterior division of the mandibular nerve?

A. infraorbital

B. zygomaticotemporal

C. infratrochlear

D. Lateral pterygoid

The correct answer is: D. Lateral pterygoid

 

✅ Explanation:

The mandibular nerve (V3) is the third division of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) and has both sensory and motor components.

It divides into two major divisions:

 

🔹 Anterior Division (mostly motor):

  • Supplies muscles of mastication (except one sensory branch)
  • Branches include:
    • Nerve to masseter
    • Nerve to temporalis
    • Nerve to medial and lateral pterygoid
    • Buccal nerve (the only sensory branch of the anterior division)

So, nerve to lateral pterygoid is a motor branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve.

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

  • A. Infraorbital
    → Branch of the maxillary nerve (V2)
  • B. Zygomaticotemporal
    → Also a branch of the maxillary nerve (V2)
  • C. Infratrochlear
    → Branch of the nasociliary nerve, which is from the ophthalmic division (V1)

 

✅ Final Answer: D. Lateral pterygoid

45

Regarding the acromio-clavicular joint, which of the following statements is false?

A. The coraco-clavicular ligament is not a joint stabilising factor

B. It is a complex joint with an incomplete wedge shaped articular disc

C. All movements are passive

D. Is innervated by the lateral pectoral nerve, axillary nerve and lateral supraclavicular nerve

 

Explanation

A.

False statement. The coracoclavicular ligament (conoid and trapezoid) is a primary stabilizer of the AC joint; saying it is “not a joint stabilizing factor” is incorrect.

B.

True statement. The AC joint has an incomplete, wedge-shaped fibrocartilaginous disc interposed between its articular surfaces.

C.

True statement. No muscles act directly on the AC joint; all movement of the acromion on the clavicle is passive, driven by scapulothoracic motion.

D.

True statement. Innervation is provided by articular branches of the lateral pectoral and axillary nerves, plus cutaneous fibers from the lateral supraclavicular nerve.

46

Anterior relations of the internal thoracic artery include

A. Sternum

B. Upper six intercostal spaces

C. Posterior root of the lung

D. Axillary artery

✅ Correct Answer: A. Sternum

 

🧠 Explanation: Anterior Relations of the Internal Thoracic Artery

The internal thoracic artery runs vertically down the inner surface of the anterior thoracic wall, just lateral to the sternum, posterior to the costal cartilages.

 

🔹 Key Anterior Relations:

Structure

Relation

Sternum

✅ Anterior (it lies just behind the sternum — correct answer)

Costal cartilages of ribs 1–6

✅ Anterior relation

Transversus thoracis muscle fibers

✅ Lies deep to these, but still anterior to artery

Internal intercostal muscles

✅ Anterior (upper fibers overlie the artery)

 

🔸 Other Options (Why They're Incorrect)

Option

Why Incorrect

B. Upper six intercostal spaces

❌ These are posterior or lateral to the artery, not anterior

C. Posterior root of the lung

❌ Too posterior and lateral; not related to internal thoracic artery

D. Axillary artery

❌ Located more laterally and superiorly in the axilla; not anterior to the internal thoracic artery

 

✅ Final Answer: A. Sternum is anterior to the internal thoracic artery.

47

All of the following are veins which drain the stomach, with the exception of?

A. Right gastric

B. Left gastric

C. Gastroduodenal

D. Gastroepiploic

The correct answer is: C. Gastroduodenal

 

Explanation:

Most veins that drain the stomach mirror the arterial supply and eventually drain into the portal venous system.

Let’s review the options:

 

✅ A. Right gastric vein

  • Drains the lesser curvature of the stomach.
  • Empties into the portal vein.
  • Correctly drains the stomach.

 

✅ B. Left gastric vein

  • Drains the lesser curvature as well.
  • Connects with esophageal veins, and drains into the portal vein.
  • Correctly drains the stomach.

 

❌ C. Gastroduodenal vein

  • Drains the duodenum and pancreas, not the stomach directly.
  • It is a tributary of the portal system, but its primary drainage is not gastric.
  • Therefore, it is the exception here.

 

✅ D. Gastroepiploic veins (right and left)

  • Drain the greater curvature of the stomach.
  • Right drains into superior mesenteric vein, left into splenic vein.
  • Both are involved in gastric drainage.

 

Summary:

  • Veins that drain the stomach: Right gastric, Left gastric, Gastroepiploic.
  • Exception: Gastroduodenal vein – mainly drains the duodenum and pancreas, not the stomach directly.

Let me know if you'd like a visual of the gastric venous drainage.

48

Which autonomic cranial ganglion distribution paring is INCORRECT?

A. Otic ganglion: eye muscles

B. Submandibular: sublingual

C. Pterygopalatine ganglion: lacrimal gland

D. Ciliary ganglion: iris

Here's a detailed table analysis for this autonomic anatomy MCQ:

 

Question: Which autonomic cranial ganglion–distribution pairing is INCORRECT?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Otic ganglion: eye muscles

❌ Incorrect Pairing → This is the Correct Answer

The otic ganglion provides parasympathetic innervation to the parotid gland, not the eye muscles. Eye muscles are supplied via the ciliary ganglion.

B. Submandibular: sublingual

✅ Correct

The submandibular ganglion distributes parasympathetic fibers to both the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands via the facial nerve (chorda tympani).

C. Pterygopalatine ganglion: lacrimal gland

✅ Correct

The pterygopalatine ganglion carries parasympathetic fibers from the facial nerve to the lacrimal gland (via the zygomatic and lacrimal nerves).

D. Ciliary ganglion: iris

✅ Correct

The ciliary ganglion carries parasympathetic fibers (from CN III) to the sphincter pupillae and ciliary muscle of the iris, controlling pupil constriction and lens accommodation.

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Otic ganglion: eye muscles

Let me know if you'd like a visual map or chart summarizing all 4 cranial parasympathetic ganglia and their targets!

49

Regarding the ankle joint, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It has a fixed axis of rotation

B. The capsule attaches to the articular margins of the tibia, fibula and anterior talus

C. The deep part of the deltoid ligament is triangular in shape

D. The lateral ligament attaches to talus and calcaneus

Option

Explanation

A.

False. Although the talocrural (ankle) joint functions as a hinge, its axis of rotation is oblique and shifts slightly during dorsiflexion and plantarflexion because the wider anterior portion of the talar trochlea wedges more tightly between the malleoli in dorsiflexion. Thus, the axis is not truly fixed.

B.

False. The fibrous capsule attaches just proximal to the articular margins of the distal tibia and medial malleolus, and to the distal fibula at the lateral malleolus, but distally it attaches around the neck of the talus (not solely the anterior talus).

C.

True. The deep (tibiotalar) part of the deltoid (medial) ligament is triangular (fan-shaped), attaching from the medial malleolus to the talus and forming a strong, deep layer distinct from the superficial bands.

D.

False. The lateral ligament complex includes three separate ligaments: the anterior talofibular (fibula to talus), calcaneofibular (fibula to calcaneus), and posterior talofibular (fibula to talus). Although individual components attach to talus or calcaneus, describing “the lateral ligament” as a single structure is misleading, and it does not attach as one unit to both bones.

50

The dorsal scapular nerve, which is correct?

A. Pierces scalenus medius

B. Arises from the C6 root

C. Supplies the rhomboids and occasionally subclavius

D. It is a branch from the trunks of the brachial plexus

 

Explanation

A.

True. The dorsal scapular nerve typically pierces the middle (scalenus medius) muscle as it descends from the C5 root to reach the scapular region.

B.

False. It arises from the C5 root of the brachial plexus, not C6.

C.

False. It supplies the rhomboid muscles (and often levator scapulae), but not subclavius.

D.

False. It is a direct branch from the C5 root, not from one of the trunks of the plexus.

51

All of the following make up the medial arch of the foot except?

A. Calcaneous

B. The first three metatarsals

C. Navicular

D. Cuboid

 

Explanation

A.

False. The calcaneus is a component of the medial longitudinal arch.

B.

False. The first three metatarsals contribute to the medial arch’s distal support.

C.

False. The navicular is part of the medial arch, articulating between the talus and cuneiforms.

D.

True. The cuboid belongs to the lateral longitudinal arch, not the medial arch.

52

At what costal level does the pleura reflection reach at the mid axillary line

A. 6th rib

B. 8th rib

C. 12th rib

D. 10th rib

The correct answer is: D. 10th rib

 

✅ Explanation:

The inferior reflection of the parietal pleura (also called the costodiaphragmatic reflection) varies depending on the region of the thorax:

Region

Pleural Reflection Level

Midclavicular line

8th rib

Midaxillary line

10th rib ✅

Paravertebral line

12th rib

These reflections mark the lowest extent of the pleural cavity in various planes and are clinically important for procedures like thoracentesis.

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

  • A. 6th rib → This is approximately where the lung (not pleura) ends in the midclavicular line
  • B. 8th rib → Correct for the pleura in the midclavicular line, not the midaxillary line
  • C. 12th rib → Pleura reaches this level posteriorly, not laterally

 

✅ Final Answer: D. 10th rib

53

Regarding the male urethra, which of the following statements is correct?

A. The urethra takes a right angle curve in the bulbous portion of the corpus spongiosum

B. It is 15cm long

C. The narrowest point of the urethra is in the prostate

D. The spongy urethra lies within the corpus carvernosum

Question: Regarding the male urethra, which of the following statements is correct?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. The urethra takes a right angle curve in the bulbous portion of the corpus spongiosum

❌ Incorrect??

The male urethra does have two curvatures (in the erect and flaccid states), but not at a right angle and not in the bulbous portion. The main angulation occurs at the junction between the membranous and spongy urethra and at the external urethral sphincter region.

B. It is 15 cm long

✅ Correct

The male urethra is approximately 15–20 cm in length, depending on the individual's body size. So, 15 cm is a correct and acceptable estimate.

C. The narrowest point of the urethra is in the prostate

❌ Incorrect

The narrowest point of the male urethra is the external urethral meatus, not the prostatic part. The prostatic urethra is actually the widest part.

D. The spongy urethra lies within the corpus cavernosum

❌ Incorrect

The spongy (penile) urethra lies within the corpus spongiosum, not the corpora cavernosa. The two corpora cavernosa are dorsal and lateral, whereas the corpus spongiosum is ventral and contains the urethra.

 

 

The "right angle curve" at the bulbous portion (where the membranous meets the spongy) is a very distinct feature often highlighted in anatomy and clinical practice because of the difficulty it presents for catheterization.

54

Which of the following statements is correct in relation to the midbrain?

A. It is supplied by the anterior and inferior cerebellar arteries

B. It is largely in the middle cranial fossa

C. It lies between the pons and the upper spinal cord

D. It contains the occulomotor nuclei

The correct answer is: D. It contains the oculomotor nuclei

 

✅ Explanation of the Correct Answer:

  • The midbrain (mesencephalon) contains the oculomotor nuclei, which give rise to cranial nerve III (oculomotor nerve).
  • These nuclei are located in the periaqueductal gray matter at the level of the superior colliculus.
  • They control most of the extraocular muscles, pupil constriction, and lens accommodation.

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

  • A. It is supplied by the anterior and inferior cerebellar arteries
    → Incorrect: The midbrain is primarily supplied by branches of the posterior cerebral artery, superior cerebellar artery, and basilar artery. The anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) supplies parts of the pons and cerebellum, not the midbrain.
  • B. It is largely in the middle cranial fossa
    → Incorrect: The midbrain lies in the posterior cranial fossa, not the middle.
  • C. It lies between the pons and the upper spinal cord
    → Incorrect: The midbrain lies between the pons and the diencephalon (thalamus). The medulla lies between the pons and spinal cord.

 

✅ Final Answer: D. It contains the oculomotor nuclei

55

Which of the following long bone is the last tocompletelyossify?

A. Fibulae

B. Radius

C. Femur

D. Clavicle

 

Explanation

A.

False. The fibula’s epiphyses typically fuse by around 18–20 years of age, earlier than the clavicle.

B.

False. The radius’ distal epiphysis fuses by about 15–17 years, well before the clavicle’s final fusion.

C.

False. The femur’s epiphyses (head and greater trochanter) generally unite with the shaft by about 20 years.

D.

True. The clavicle is the last long bone to complete ossification, with its sternal end fusing between roughly 18–25 years and often not fully united until 25–31 years.

56

Cell bodies for the motor supply of the facial nerve lie in which of the following areas?

A. Midbrain

B. Hypothalamus

C. Pons

D. Floor of third ventricle

Here's the detailed analysis for your MCQ:

Question: Cell bodies for the motor supply of the facial nerve lie in which of the following areas?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Midbrain

❌ Incorrect

The midbrain contains nuclei for cranial nerves III (oculomotor) and IV (trochlear), but not the facial nerve (CN VII).

B. Hypothalamus

❌ Incorrect

The hypothalamus is involved in autonomic and endocrine regulation, but not the origin of motor cranial nerves. However, upper motor neurons influencing facial expression begin in the motor cortex and project via the corticobulbar tract, which passes through the internal capsule near the hypothalamus — but the facial motor nucleus itself is not here.

C. Pons

✅ Correct

The motor nucleus of the facial nerve (CN VII) is located in the lower pons, specifically in the facial colliculus area. This is where the cell bodies for the branchial motor component (facial expression muscles) are located.

D. Floor of third ventricle

❌ Incorrect

The floor of the third ventricle is near the hypothalamus, which again is not the location of the facial motor nucleus.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Pons

Let me know if you'd like a diagram of cranial nerve nuclei or a breakdown of functional components of the facial nerve.

57

The skin over the femoral triangle is supplied by which of the following nerves?

A. Obturator

B. Ilio-inguinal

C. Medial femoral cutaneous

D. Genito-femoral

 

Explanation

A.

False. The obturator nerve supplies the medial thigh (adductors), not skin over the femoral triangle.

B.

False. The ilio-inguinal nerve’s femoral branch innervates skin over the medial femoral triangle, but not the entire triangular region. It supplies only the most medial portion.

C.

False. The medial femoral cutaneous nerves (branches of the femoral nerve) supply skin of the anterior and medial thigh, but primarily below and lateral to the femoral triangle; they do not cover the triangle itself.

D.

True. The genitofemoral nerve’s femoral branch provides cutaneous innervation to the skin over the lateral aspect of the femoral triangle.

58

Which of the folllowing is FALSE regarding femoral hernias?

A. The A femoral hernia is bounded by the femoral vein laterally and the lacunar ligament medially

B. Femoral hernias are small and do not enlarge as they are contained within the wall of the femoral canal

C. femoral hernia appears as a mass in the femoral triangle, inferolateral to the pubic tubercle

D. Femoral hernias are more common in females because of their wider pelvises.

Option

Explanation

A.

True. A femoral hernia sac emerging through the femoral ring is bounded laterally by the femoral vein and medially by the lacunar ligament.

B.

False. Although the hernia is initially small because it is confined within the femoral canal, it can enlarge by extending inferiorly through the saphenous opening into the thigh.

C.

True. Clinically, a femoral hernia appears as a tender mass in the femoral triangle, located inferolateral to the pubic tubercle.

D.

True. Femoral hernias are more common in females, largely because their wider pelvis creates a relatively larger femoral canal.

59

Which is incorrect about the plantar aponeurosis?

A. Arises from the calcaneous

B. Is attached firmly to the skin

C. Is found in the second layer of the foot

D. Is supplied by the tibial nerve

 

Explanation

A.

True. The plantar aponeurosis originates from the medial process of the calcaneal tuberosity.

B.

True. It is firmly anchored to the overlying skin by vertical septa, securing the skin to the sole.

C.

False. The plantar aponeurosis lies in the first (most superficial) layer of the sole, not the second.

D.

True. Sensory fibers to the plantar fascia come via branches of the tibial nerve (medial plantar and lateral plantar nerves).

60

Which structure passes through the diaphragm with the oesophagus?

A. Vagal trunk

B. Azygous vein

C. Thoracic duct

D. Phrenic nerve

Here's the detailed table analysis for your MCQ:

Question: Which structure passes through the diaphragm with the oesophagus?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Vagal trunk

✅ Correct

The vagal trunks (anterior and posterior) pass through the oesophageal hiatus at T10 along with the oesophagus. These are the continuations of the left and right vagus nerves, respectively.

B. Azygous vein

❌ Incorrect

The azygous vein passes through the diaphragm at the aortic hiatus (T12), not with the oesophagus.

C. Thoracic duct

❌ Incorrect

The thoracic duct also passes through the aortic hiatus at T12, alongside the aorta.

D. Phrenic nerve

❌ Incorrect

The phrenic nerves pass through the diaphragm separately. The right phrenic nerve passes with the IVC through the caval opening (T8). The left phrenic nerve pierces the diaphragm independently. They do not accompany the oesophagus.

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Vagal trunk

Let me know if you'd like a quick mnemonic for the diaphragmatic openings (T8–T10–T12)!

61

Which of the following statements is correct in relation to gluteus maximus?

A. It is supplied by L5, S1 and S2

B. It is the deepest of the gluteal muscles

C. It medially rotates and extends the hip

D. It forms the skin crease of the gluteal fold

 

Explanation

A.

True. Gluteus maximus is innervated by the inferior gluteal nerve, which carries fibers from L5, S1, and S2.

B.

False. Gluteus maximus is the most superficial of the gluteal muscles; gluteus minimus is the deepest.

C.

False. Gluteus maximus extends and laterally (not medially) rotates the hip.

D.

True. The inferior border of gluteus maximus forms the skin crease known as the gluteal fold.

62

Theanterior triangleof the neck is divided into 4 smaller triangles. Which of the following smaller triangles isINCORRECT?

A. Muscular triangle

B. Hyoglossus triangle

C. Digastric triangle

D. Carotid triangle

Here's the detailed breakdown of your anatomy MCQ:

Question: The anterior triangle of the neck is divided into 4 smaller triangles. Which of the following smaller triangles is INCORRECT?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Muscular triangle

✅ Correct

This is a valid subdivision of the anterior triangle. It contains the infrahyoid muscles, thyroid gland, and parts of the larynx and trachea.

B. Hyoglossus triangle

❌ Incorrect (i.e., this is the correct answer to the question)

The "hyoglossus triangle" is not a recognized anatomical subdivision of the anterior triangle. It's likely a distractor or misnomer. It does not appear in standard anatomical classifications of neck triangles.

C. Digastric triangle

✅ Correct

Also known as the submandibular triangle, it is bounded by the digastric muscles and mandible, and contains the submandibular gland, facial artery and vein, etc.

D. Carotid triangle

✅ Correct

This triangle contains the carotid sheath (with common carotid artery, internal jugular vein, and vagus nerve) and is a classic subdivision of the anterior triangle.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Hyoglossus triangle

Let me know if you'd like a diagram or mnemonic for remembering all the neck triangles!

63

Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the consequence of a midshaft fracture of the humerus?

A. Sensory loss occurs distal to the wrist

B. Extension of the interphalangeal joints are possible

C. Paralysis may be transient

D. There is loss of elbow extension

 

Explanation

A.

True. A midshaft humeral fracture often injures the radial nerve in the radial groove proximal to its superficial branch, causing sensory loss over the dorsum of the hand (distal to the wrist).

B.

True. Although the extensor digitorum (radial nerve) is paralyzed, interossei and lumbricals (ulnar/median nerves) can still extend the interphalangeal joints via the extensor expansion.

C.

True. The radial nerve injury at the fracture site is often neuropraxic and may recover function spontaneously over weeks to months.

D.

False. Elbow extension is largely preserved because the long and lateral heads of triceps are innervated proximal to the spiral groove; only a mild weakness may occur due to loss of the medial head.

64

Which is the correct layout of structures form anterior to posterior in the superior mediastinum?

A. Lymphoid system, blood vascular, respiratory system, alimentary system, nervous system

B. Lymphoid system, respiratory system, blood vascular, lymph vascular system, alimentary system

C. Lymphoid system, respiratory system, blood vascular, alimentary system, lymph vascular system

D. Lymphoid system, blood vascular, respiratory system, alimentary system, lymph vascular system

The correct answer is: C. Pons

 

✅ Explanation:

The motor nucleus of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is located in the lower pons, specifically in the pontine tegmentum.

  • It contains cell bodies of lower motor neurons that supply:
    • Muscles of facial expression
    • Stapedius
    • Posterior belly of digastric
    • Stylohyoid

These fibers loop over the abducens nucleus, forming the facial colliculus on the floor of the 4th ventricle.

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

  • A. Midbrain → Contains nuclei for CN III (oculomotor) and CN IV (trochlear), not facial.
  • B. Hypothalamus → Involved in autonomic and endocrine functions, not motor cranial nerve nuclei.
  • D. Floor of third ventricle → This is part of the diencephalon, not where the facial motor nucleus is located.

 

✅ Final Answer: C. Pons

65

Regarding the Internal thoracic artery, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It is a branch of 2nd part of subclavian artery

B. It descends straight down 1 cm medially to border of sternum

C. Gives off two anterior intercostal branches to the 5 superior intercostal spaces

D. The internal thoracic artery is crossed near their origins by the ipsilateral phrenic nerve

✅ Correct Answer: D. The internal thoracic artery is crossed near their origins by the ipsilateral phrenic nerve

 

🧠 Explanation of Each Option:

 

A. It is a branch of the 2nd part of subclavian artery

❌ Incorrect

  • The internal thoracic artery (ITA) is a branch of the 1st part of the subclavian artery, not the 2nd.

 

B. It descends straight down 1 cm medially to border of sternum

❌ Incorrect

  • It actually descends ~1–2 cm lateral to the border of the sternum — not medially.

 

C. Gives off two anterior intercostal branches to the 5 superior intercostal spaces

❌ Incorrect

  • The ITA gives two anterior intercostal arteries to each of the first six intercostal spaces, not five.

 

D. The internal thoracic artery is crossed near their origins by the ipsilateral phrenic nerve

✅ Correct

  • Yes — the phrenic nerve crosses anterior to the internal thoracic artery near its origin from the subclavian artery, typically between the anterior scalene muscle and subclavian vein.

 

✅ Final Answer: D. The internal thoracic artery is crossed near their origins by the ipsilateral phrenic nerve

66

Which is true of the biceps femoral muscle?

A. Biceps femoris's two head together with the semitendinosus and semimembranosus muscle form the hamstrings

B. The main blood supply is form the inferior gluteal artery

C. The long head of biceps femoris is innervated by the tibial division of the sciatic nerve

D. The hamstring's proximal attachment is from the body of ischium

 

Explanation

A.

True. The biceps femoris (two heads), semitendinosus, and semimembranosus together constitute the hamstring muscle group.

B.

False. The primary blood supply to biceps femoris comes from perforating branches of the profunda femoris artery, not the inferior gluteal artery.

C.

True. The long head of the biceps femoris is innervated by the tibial division of the sciatic nerve.

D.

False. The proximal attachment of biceps femoris long head is the ischial tuberosity (part of the ischium), not the body of the ischium itself.

67

A young man is stabbed in the face, he sustains a jagged laceration extending from the mouth to the angle of the mandible. He presents to your ED with paralysis of muscles of the lower lip. Which nerve is most likely injured?

A. Zygomatic mandibular branch

B. Marginal mandibular branch

C. Temporal mandibular branch

D. Buccal mandibular branch

✅ Correct Answer: B. Marginal mandibular branch (of the facial nerve, CN VII)

 

🧠 Explanation:

  • The marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve (CN VII):
    • Innervates muscles of the lower lip and chin, such as:
      • Depressor anguli oris
      • Depressor labii inferioris
      • Mentalis
    • It runs just below the lower border of the mandible, and is vulnerable to trauma or surgical injury in this area (e.g., knife wounds, submandibular surgery).

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

Option

Branch

Function

Why Incorrect

A. Zygomatic mandibular (non-standard term)

Possibly misnamed version of "zygomatic branch"

Innervates orbicularis oculi, not lower lip

❌

C. Temporal mandibular (non-standard term)

Possibly confusion of temporal branch
