Supplies frontalis, orbicularis oculi

❌

D. Buccal mandibular (non-standard term)

Likely referring to buccal branch

Innervates buccinator, upper lip muscles

❌

 

📍 Clinical Pearl:

  • Marginal mandibular nerve injury → asymmetry of the lower lip, especially noticeable when the patient smiles or shows teeth.

Would you like a diagram of the facial nerve branches for better visualization?

68

Which nerve passes through the jugular foramen?

A. CN VII

B. CN V

C. CN IX

D. CN XII

✅ Correct Answer: C. CN IX (Glossopharyngeal nerve)

 

🧠 Explanation:

The jugular foramen transmits the following three cranial nerves and one major vein:

Structure

Passes through Jugular Foramen

CN IX – Glossopharyngeal

✅ Yes

CN X – Vagus

✅ Yes

CN XI – Accessory

✅ Yes

Internal jugular vein

✅ Yes

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

Option

Nerve

Foramen

Why Incorrect

A. CN VII

Facial nerve

Internal acoustic meatus → stylomastoid foramen

❌ Not via jugular foramen

B. CN V

Trigeminal

Exits via V1: SOF, V2: rotundum, V3: ovale

❌ No part through jugular

D. CN XII

Hypoglossal

Hypoglossal canal

❌ Not jugular foramen

 

Let me know if you’d like a summary table of all cranial foramina and which nerves/structures pass through each.

69

Injury to the radial nerve at the elbow will affect function of which of the following muscles?

A. Flexor pollicis longus

B. Brachioradialias

C. Extensor carpi radialis longus

D. Supinator

 

Explanation

A.

False. Flexor pollicis longus is innervated by the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve, not the radial nerve.

B.

False. Brachioradialis is supplied by the radial nerve proximal to the elbow; an injury at the elbow (distal to its motor branch) would not affect it.

C.

False. Extensor carpi radialis longus is innervated by the radial nerve above the level of the elbow; its branch departs before the nerve would be injured at the elbow.

D.

True. Supinator is innervated by the deep branch of the radial nerve immediately distal to the elbow; damage at the elbow disrupts its innervation.

70

Which movement of the upper limb does not involve C6?

A. Supination

B. Pronation

C. Shoulder adduction

D. Wrist extension

Below is a transcription of Moore’s Fig. 6.20 (“Segmental innervation of movements of the upper limb”), listing each major movement with its primary myotome(s) as shown in the figure.

1. Glenohumeral (shoulder) Joint Movements

  • Abduction (C5)
  • Adduction (C6 – C7 – C8)
  • Flexion (C5 – C6)
  • Extension (C6 – C7)
  • Medial (Internal) Rotation (C6 – C7 – C8)
  • Lateral (External) Rotation (C5 – C6)

2. Elbow Joint Movements

  • Flexion (C5 – C6)
  • Extension (C7)

3. Radioulnar (Forearm) Joint Movements

  • Supination (C6)
  • Pronation (C6 – C7)

4. Wrist Joint Movements

  • Extension (C6)
  • Flexion (C7)

5. Metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and Interphalangeal (IP) Joint Movements (Digits 2–5)

  • MP/IP Extension (C7 – C8)
  • MP/IP Flexion (C8)

6. MCP Joint Movements (Intrinsic Hand Muscles)

  • Abduction/Adduction of Digits 2–5 (T1)

(Note: In Moore’s figure, intrinsic movements of the thumb (e.g., abduction/adduction, opposition) are likewise under C8–T1, but the isolated “intrinsic digits 2–5” abduction/adduction is labelled T1 for the interossei.)

71

Which muscle would be expected to be innervated by median recurrent nerve?

A. 1-2nd palmar interossei

B. Extensor pollicis longus

C. 1-2nd lumbricals

D. Abductor pollicis brevis

 

Explanation

A.

False. The 1st and 2nd palmar interossei are innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve, not the median recurrent branch.

B.

False. Extensor pollicis longus is innervated by the posterior interosseous branch of the radial nerve.

C.

False. The 1st and 2nd lumbricals receive innervation from the median nerve’s digital branches, but not the recurrent branch; they are supplied by the common digital nerves.

D.

True. Abductor pollicis brevis is one of the thenar muscles innervated by the recurrent branch of the median nerve.

72

Knowledge of the axilla is important in the emergency department for insertion of chest drains. The costal line of pleural reflection crosses the mid-axillary line at which rib?

A. 8th

B. 6th

C. 10th

D. 12th

Option

Rib

Explanation

A

8th

The 8th rib is where the costal line of pleural reflection meets the mid-clavicular line, not the mid-axillary line.

B

6th

The 6th rib corresponds to the level of the lung’s anterior border at the mid-clavicular line; it is not involved in the costal pleural reflection at the mid-axillary line.

C

10th

Correct. In the mid-axillary line, the costal line of pleural reflection crosses at the 10th rib.

D

12th

The 12th rib is where the costal line becomes continuous with the vertebral reflection in the paravertebral plane, not at the mid-axillary line.

According to Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, the costal lines of pleural reflection pass obliquely across the 8th rib at the mid-clavicular line and across the 10th rib at the mid-axillary line before continuing posteriorly to join the vertebral lines at the necks of the 12th ribs .

73

In relation to serratus anterior, which of the following statements is correct?

A. Protracts the scapula

B. Is formed by 7 slips

C. Is supplied by the dorsal scapular nerve

D. Is not covered by fascia

Option

Explanation

A

Correct. Serratus anterior originates from the upper eight or nine ribs and inserts on the costal surface of the scapula; its primary action is to protract (abduct) the scapula, holding it against the thoracic wall.

B

Incorrect. Serratus anterior is typically formed by eight (sometimes nine) slips from ribs 1–8 (and occasionally the 9th), not seven slips.

C

Incorrect. The muscle is innervated by the long thoracic nerve (roots C5–C7), not the dorsal scapular nerve (which supplies levator scapulae and rhomboids).

D

Incorrect. Like other trunk muscles, serratus anterior is covered by deep fascia (specifically, it lies deep to the clavipectoral and pectoral fascia anteriorly and is invested by its own fascial sheath).

74

Muscles of the rotator cuff include all the following, with the exception of?

A. Teres minor

B. Teres major

C. Infraspinatus

D. Supraspinatus

Option

Explanation

A

Teres minor is a rotator cuff muscle. It originates on the lateral border of the scapula and inserts on the greater tubercle of the humerus, aiding in external rotation.

B

Teres major is not a rotator cuff muscle. It originates on the inferior angle of the scapula and inserts on the medial lip of the bicipital groove of the humerus, functioning in internal rotation and adduction.

C

Infraspinatus is a rotator cuff muscle. It arises from the infraspinous fossa of the scapula and inserts on the greater tubercle of the humerus, providing external rotation of the shoulder.

D

Supraspinatus is a rotator cuff muscle. It originates from the supraspinous fossa of the scapula and inserts on the greater tubercle of the humerus, initiating abduction of the arm.

75

Which bone is not part of the axial skeleton?

A. Thoracic vertebrae

B. Hyoid bone

C. Scapulae

D. Sacrum

Option

Explanation

A

Thoracic vertebrae are part of the vertebral column, which is a core component of the axial skeleton.

B

Hyoid bone lies in the anterior neck and, although it does not articulate directly with other bones, is considered part of the axial skeleton.

C

Scapulae are components of the pectoral (shoulder) girdle, which belong to the appendicular skeleton—not the axial skeleton.

D

Sacrum is the fused series of vertebrae at the base of the vertebral column, forming part of the axial skeleton.

76

Which myotome is responsible for adduction of the fingers?

A. C7

B. C6

C. C8

D. T1

Option

Explanation

A

C7: Primarily contributes to elbow extension and wrist flexion; it does not supply the intrinsic hand muscles responsible for finger adduction.

B

C6: Mainly involved in elbow flexion and wrist extension; it does not innervate the interossei or other intrinsic hand muscles that adduct the fingers.

C

C8: Governs finger flexion (e.g., flexor digitorum profundus to the fingers) but does not control the interossei muscles that adduct the digits.

D

T1: Correct. T1 is the single myotome for the intrinsic muscles of the hand (including the palmar interossei), which are responsible for adduction of the fingers.

77

What is the narrowest point of the oesophagus?

A. Broncho-aortic constriction

B. Pharyngo-oesophageal junction

C. Oesophageal hiatus of the diaphragm

D. Oesophageal cardiac constriction

Here's the detailed analysis for your anatomy MCQ:

 

Question: What is the narrowest point of the oesophagus?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Broncho-aortic constriction

❌ Incorrect

This is a physiological narrowing where the left main bronchus and aortic arch cross the oesophagus (~T4 level), but it is not the narrowest point.

B. Pharyngo-oesophageal junction

✅ Correct

Also known as the upper oesophageal sphincter or cricopharyngeal junction, this is the narrowest and most constricted part of the oesophagus. It occurs at the C5–C6 level, just below the pharynx.

C. Oesophageal hiatus of the diaphragm

❌ Incorrect

This is a normal narrowing at the T10 level, where the oesophagus passes through the diaphragm, but it’s not the tightest.

D. Oesophageal cardiac constriction

❌ Incorrect

This is where the oesophagus joins the stomach at the cardiac orifice (~T11), and is one of the constrictions, but not the narrowest.

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Pharyngo-oesophageal junction

🧠 Bonus: The 3 (or 4) constrictions of the oesophagus

  1. Pharyngo-oesophageal junction (C6) – narrowest
  2. Aortic arch (T4)
  3. Left main bronchus (T4–T5) — often grouped with aortic
  4. Diaphragmatic hiatus (T10)

Let me know if you'd like a labeled diagram or clinical correlations (e.g. sites for foreign body lodgment or stricture formation).

78

Regarding the anatomical snuff box, which of the following statements isFALSE?The cephalic vein begins in the roof of anatomical snuffbox is confusing. I have checked Last's and Moore only mentioned as a content of Anatomical snuffbox

A. The cephalic vein begins in the roof of the anatomical snuffbox

B. Branches of the radial nerve can be palpated over the tendons

C. The bones palpable are the radial styloid, scaphoid, trapezium and the base of the first metacarpal

D. The tendons of abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis longus form one boundary

Option

Explanation

A

True. The cephalic vein arises from the dorsal venous network on the radial side of the hand, which lies superficial to the anatomical snuff box; from there it ascends in the roof of the snuff box.

B

True. The superficial branch of the radial nerve passes over the tendons bordering the snuff box (just deep to the skin) and can be palpated as it crosses this region.

C

True. In the floor of the snuff box you can feel the radial styloid process proximally, then—moving distally—the scaphoid and trapezium, and finally the base of the first metacarpal.

D

False. The lateral (anterior) boundary of the snuff box is formed by the tendons of abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis, while the medial (posterior) boundary is formed solely by the tendon of extensor pollicis longus.

79

Loss of the greater tuburcle (can be called tuberosity) of the humerus leads to loss of which movement?

A. Adduction and medial rotation

B. Abduction and lateral rotation

C. Abduction and medial rotation

D. Adduction and lateral rotation

Option

Explanation

A

Adduction and medial rotation: These movements are primarily mediated by muscles inserting on the lesser tubercle (e.g., subscapularis for medial rotation, pectoralis major, latissimus dorsi for adduction). Loss of the greater tubercle does not affect these.

B

Abduction and lateral rotation: Correct. The greater tubercle serves as the attachment for supraspinatus (initiates abduction), infraspinatus, and teres minor (both perform lateral rotation). Without the greater tubercle, these muscles cannot function.

C

Abduction and medial rotation: Medial rotation is performed by subscapularis (inserts on the lesser tubercle) and other muscles; loss of the greater tubercle would not directly disrupt medial rotation.

D

Adduction and lateral rotation: Adduction is largely via muscles inserting elsewhere (latissimus dorsi, teres major, pectoralis major), so loss of the greater tubercle would not impair adduction, though lateral rotation would be affected.

80

Regarding digital nerves, which isCORRECT?

A. Digital nerves are only sensory

B. Digital nerve lie posterior to digital artery

C. Palmar nerves only supply palmar surface

D. Common digital nerves lie superficial to superficial palmer arch

Option

Explanation

A

Incorrect. Although proper digital nerves primarily carry sensory fibers to the fingers, they also contain autonomic (sympathetic) fibers for vascular regulation; thus they are not strictly “only sensory.”

B

Incorrect. In the finger’s neurovascular bundle, the digital nerves run more superficially (closer to the skin) than the digital arteries, not posterior to them.

C

Incorrect. Palmar digital nerves supply sensation to both the palmar surfaces of the fingers and the dorsal distal phalanges; they are not limited to the palmar side.

D

Correct. The common digital nerves (branches of the median and ulnar nerves) pass superficial to the superficial palmar arch before dividing into proper digital nerves in the web spaces.

81

The dorsal column pathways synapse in which of the following?

A. Gracile and cuneate nuclei

B. Midbrain

C. Cerebellum

D. Pons

 

82

Which nerve is not contained within the carotid sheath?

A. Upper part of the hypoglossal nerve

B. Vagus nerve

C. Upper part of the accessory nerve

D. Cervical sympathetic trunk

 

The correct answer is:

 

D. Cervical sympathetic trunk

 

Explanation:

  • The carotid sheath contains the common and internal carotid arteries, the internal jugular vein, and the vagus nerve (CN X)2349.
  • In the upper part of the carotid sheath, portions of the hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) and accessory nerve (CN XI) may be present briefly before they exit the sheath356.
  • The cervical sympathetic trunk, however, is not contained within the carotid sheath; it lies posterior and medial to the sheath, embedded in the prevertebral fascia2356.

Therefore, among the options listed, the cervical sympathetic trunk is not contained within the carotid sheath.

 

 

83

Which of the following statements in relation to pectoralis major is correct?

A. Attaches to the glenoid tuberosity

B. Abducts the arm

C. Only the costal part has a bony attachment

D. Is an accessory muscle of respiration

Option

Explanation

A

Incorrect. Pectoralis major inserts on the lateral lip of the bicipital groove of the humerus, not on the glenoid tuberosity of the scapula.

B

Incorrect. Its primary actions are adduction and medial rotation of the humerus; it does not abduct the arm.

C

Incorrect. All parts of pectoralis major have bony attachments: the clavicular head to the clavicle, and the sternocostal (costal) head to the sternum and costal cartilages.

D

Correct. When the humerus is fixed, pectoralis major can elevate the thorax, acting as an accessory muscle of respiration during deep or forced inspiration.

84

In relation to the hip joint, which of the following statements is correct?

A. The nerve supply is via the obturator and sciatic nerves only

B. It is limited in full extension by the pubofemoral ligament

C. It has the ischiofemoral as its strongest ligament

D. It derives stability largely from its articular surfaces

Option

Explanation

A

Incorrect. The hip joint receives articular branches not only from the obturator nerve but also from the femoral nerve (via its nerve to rectus femoris), the superior gluteal nerve, and the nerve to quadratus femoris. The sciatic nerve proper does not supply the hip joint capsule.

B

Incorrect. Although the pubofemoral ligament becomes taut in extension (and limits abduction), the primary restraint against hyperextension of the hip is the iliofemoral ligament. The pubofemoral ligament contributes, but it is not the main limiting structure in full extension.

C

Incorrect. The strongest ligament of the hip is the Y-shaped iliofemoral ligament (sometimes called the ligament of Bigelow). The ischiofemoral ligament is thinner and is not the principal stabilizer.

D

Correct. The deep, cup-like acetabulum (enhanced by the fibrocartilaginous labrum) provides a highly congruent articulation with the femoral head, conferring the majority of the hip’s stability. Strong ligaments and surrounding muscles contribute, but the bony architecture is the dominant stabilizing factor.

85

Which ciliary ganglion-cranial nerve pairing is CORRECT?

A. Pterygopalatine ganglion: CN VII

B. Ciliary ganglion: CN II

C. Otic ganglion: CN X

D. Submandibular ganglion: CN IX

Here's the detailed table analysis for your cranial nerve–ganglion pairing MCQ:

 

Question: Which ciliary ganglion–cranial nerve pairing is CORRECT?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Pterygopalatine ganglion: CN VII

✅ Correct

The pterygopalatine ganglion receives preganglionic parasympathetic fibers from CN VII (facial nerve) via the greater petrosal nerve. It supplies the lacrimal gland, nasal mucosa, and palate.

B. Ciliary ganglion: CN II

❌ Incorrect

CN II (optic nerve) is purely sensory and has no parasympathetic function. The ciliary ganglion is associated with CN III (oculomotor nerve) for parasympathetic innervation of the iris and ciliary body.

C. Otic ganglion: CN X

❌ Incorrect

The otic ganglion is associated with CN IX (glossopharyngeal nerve), not CN X. It provides parasympathetic fibers to the parotid gland via the lesser petrosal nerve and auriculotemporal nerve.

D. Submandibular ganglion: CN IX

❌ Incorrect

The submandibular ganglion is associated with CN VII (facial nerve) via the chorda tympani, not CN IX. It supplies the submandibular and sublingual glands.

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Pterygopalatine ganglion: CN VII

Let me know if you want a clean summary table or mnemonic for all four cranial parasympathetic ganglia and their pathways!

86

Regarding the interossei in the hand, which of the following is true?

A. Palmar interossei have two heads

B. They arise from the tendons of Flexor digitorum superficialis

C. They abduct the fingers only

D. They aid in flexion of metacarpo-phalangeal joints & extension of interphalangeal joints

Option

Explanation

A

Incorrect. Palmar interossei are unipennate (single-headed) muscles arising from the sides of metacarpal bones, not bipennate (two-headed).

B

Incorrect. Interossei originate from the metacarpal bones, not from the tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis.

C

Incorrect. Only the dorsal interossei abduct the fingers; palmar interossei adduct the fingers. Thus, interossei are not solely abductors.

D

Correct. Both palmar and dorsal interossei insert into the extensor expansion on the proximal phalanx, allowing them to flex the metacarpophalangeal joints while extending the interphalangeal joints.

87

Which is true regarding venous drainage of the lower limb?

A. The deep veins lie in the deep fascia

B. The superficial veins have more valves than the deep veins

C. Passage of flow in the deep veins of the lower limbs is: from the the deep veins to the popliteal vein to the femoral vein to the internal iliac vein

D. The deep veins are contained within a vascular sheath with the artery, whose pulsations also help compress and move blood in the veins.

Option

Explanation

A

False. Deep veins of the lower limb lie deep to the deep (investing) fascia alongside arteries, not within the fascia itself.

B

False. Deep veins actually have more valves than the superficial veins.

C

False. The typical pathway is: deep veins → popliteal vein → femoral vein → external iliac vein (not internal iliac).

D

True. Deep veins run in a vascular sheath alongside the corresponding artery; arterial pulsations help compress these veins and assist venous return.

88

A patient is stabbed in the anterior chest to the left of the sternum. Which structure is most likely damaged?

A. Left ventricle

B. Right ventricle

C. Right atrium

D. Left atrium

Here's a detailed analysis of this high-yield clinical anatomy MCQ:

 

Question: A patient is stabbed in the anterior chest to the left of the sternum. Which structure is most likely damaged?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Left ventricle

❌ Incorrect

Although the left ventricle is the strongest and thickest chamber, it lies posteriorly and to the left, not directly behind the sternum. It forms the apex, not the anterior surface.

B. Right ventricle

✅ Correct

The right ventricle forms the majority of the anterior (sternocostal) surface of the heart. It lies just deep to the sternum and left parasternal region — making it the most likely chamber injured by an anterior stab wound in this location.

C. Right atrium

❌ Incorrect

The right atrium is located more to the right of the sternum, forming the right heart border. An injury left of the sternum is unlikely to involve it.

D. Left atrium

❌ Incorrect

The left atrium is the most posterior cardiac chamber, lying directly in front of the esophagus. It would be injured in posterior trauma, not anterior.

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Right ventricle

Let me know if you want a diagram of the heart’s surface anatomy or trauma zones!

89

The straight sinus is formed by:

A. Superior sagittal sinus and great vertebral veins

B. Inferior sagittal sinus and great cerebral veins

C. Super sagittal sinus and inferior sagittal sinus

D. Super sagittal sinus and great cerebral veins

The correct answer is: B. Inferior sagittal sinus and great cerebral veins

 

✅ Explanation:

The straight sinus is formed by the union of:

  • The inferior sagittal sinus, which runs along the free edge of the falx cerebri
  • The great cerebral vein (of Galen), which drains deep brain structures like the internal cerebral veins

 

📍 Pathway Summary:

 

Inferior sagittal sinus + Great cerebral vein → Straight sinus → Confluence of sinuses

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

  • A. Superior sagittal sinus and great vertebral veins
    → Incorrect: The superior sagittal sinus drains directly into the confluence of sinuses and has no connection to the so-called "great vertebral veins" (which is not a standard anatomical term).
  • C. Superior sagittal sinus and inferior sagittal sinus
    → Incorrect: These two do not directly join to form any sinus.
  • D. Superior sagittal sinus and great cerebral veins
    → Incorrect: The superior sagittal sinus does not join with the great cerebral vein.

 

✅ Final Answer: B. Inferior sagittal sinus and great cerebral veins

90

Which of the following structuresdo notpass through the transpyloric plane?

A. Hila of the kidneys

B. Gastro-oesophageal junction

C. L1-L2 lumbar disc

D. Origin of the superior mesenteric artery

Here's the detailed table analysis for this anatomy MCQ:

 

Question: Which of the following structures do not pass through the transpyloric plane?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Hila of the kidneys

✅ Correct

The renal hila lie around the transpyloric plane (L1), especially the right hilum (slightly lower than left due to the liver). This is a correctly associated structure.

B. Gastro-oesophageal junction

❌ Incorrect → Correct Answer

The gastro-oesophageal junction lies at approximately the level of T10–T11, above the transpyloric plane. Therefore, it does not pass through the transpyloric plane.

C. L1–L2 lumbar disc

✅ Correct

The transpyloric plane is typically at the L1 vertebral level, so it includes the L1–L2 disc area.

D. Origin of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA)

✅ Correct

The SMA arises from the aorta at the level of L1, right on the transpyloric plane.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Gastro-oesophageal junction

 

Would you like a labeled diagram or a quick table on what lies on the transpyloric plane (e.g., pylorus, pancreas, SMA, etc.)?

91

The right costal line of pleural reflection begins at the mid-clavicular line. Which rib does this correspond to?

A. 10th

B. 6th

C. 12th

D. 8th

✅ Correct Answer: B. 6th rib

 

🫁 Explanation:

The costal line of pleural reflection refers to the inferior border of the parietal pleura where it changes direction from the thoracic wall onto the diaphragm.

At specific anatomical landmarks, it corresponds to certain ribs:

Surface Landmark

Rib level of pleural reflection

Midclavicular line

6th rib

Midaxillary line

8th rib

Paravertebral line

12th rib

 

🧠 Remember:

"Pleura: 6–8–10, Lungs: 6–8–10 minus 2"

  • At rest, the lungs end 2 ribs higher than the parietal pleura in each region.

 

❌ Why other options are incorrect:

  • A. 10th rib – too low; matches midscapular/vertebral line
  • C. 12th rib – vertebral line only
  • D. 8th rib – matches midaxillary line, not midclavicular

 

Would you like a visual diagram showing lung and pleural surface markings on the chest wall?

92

With respect to the great saphenous vein, which of the following is true?

A. It runs between the two heads of gastrocnemius

B. It is a continuation of the lateral marginal vein of the foot

C. It pierces the cribriform fascia covering the saphenous opening

D. It does not communicate directly with the superficial vein varicosities

Option

Explanation

A

Incorrect. The small saphenous vein runs between the two heads of gastrocnemius, not the great saphenous vein.

B

Incorrect. The great saphenous vein is a continuation of the medial marginal vein of the foot, not the lateral marginal vein.

C

Correct. The great saphenous vein ascends the medial thigh and pierces the cribriform fascia at the saphenous opening to join the femoral vein.

D

Incorrect. The great saphenous vein communicates with superficial varicosities via perforating veins, so it does directly connect with varicose channels.

93

A lumbar puncture needle passes through which correct series of layers to get CSF?

A. Skin, subcutaneous tissue, ligamentum flavum, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, dura, arachnoid

B. Skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, interspinous ligament, dura, arachnoid

C. Skin, subcutaneous tissue, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, supraspinous ligament, dura, arachnoid

D. Skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, dura, arachnoid
    • Skin
    • Subcutaneous tissue
    • Supraspinous ligament
    • Interspinous ligament
    • Ligamentum flavum
    • Epidural space
    • Dura mater
    • Arachnoid mater → Into the subarachnoid space where CSF is obtained. |

94

Which istrueregarding the pleural reflections

A. There are 3 pleural reflection lines: sternal, costal and mediastinal

B. The right and left side pleural reflections are symmetrical

C. The reflection lines are lines along which the visceral pleural changes direction as it passes form one wall of the pleural cavity to another

D. The sternal line of pleural reflection on the right side deviates at the level of the 6th coastal cartilage, but on the left at the 4th costal cartilage

Question

Which is true regarding the pleural reflections?

Options

Evaluation

A. There are 3 pleural reflection lines: sternal, costal and mediastinal

❌ Incorrect – There are three major lines of pleural reflection, but they are sternal, costovertebral (vertebral), and costal reflections. “Mediastinal” is not a standard classification in this context.

B. The right and left side pleural reflections are symmetrical

❌ Incorrect – The pleural reflections are not symmetrical. The left side deviates earlier due to the presence of the cardiac notch, making the left sternal reflection different from the right.

C. The reflection lines are lines along which the visceral pleura changes direction as it passes from one wall of the pleural cavity to another

❌ Incorrect – This is a misstatement. The reflection lines mark where the parietal pleura changes direction (e.g., from costal to diaphragmatic or mediastinal surfaces), not the visceral pleura.

D. The sternal line of pleural reflection on the right side deviates at the level of the 6th costal cartilage, but on the left at the 4th costal cartilage

✅ Correct – On the right, the sternal line continues down to the 6th costal cartilage before turning laterally. On the left, due to the presence of the heart (cardiac notch), the reflection deviates laterally at the 4th costal cartilage, creating a noticeable asymmetry.

 

 

 

95

Which of the following long bones is the last to completely ossifiy?

A. Fibula

B. Clavicle

C. Femur

D. Radius

Option

Explanation

A

Fibula: The fibula begins ossification in utero and its epiphyses fuse by about age 20, earlier than the clavicle. It is not the last long bone to complete ossification.

B

Clavicle: Correct. The clavicle is the first long bone to begin ossification (5th–6th embryonic weeks) but is the last to finish: its sternal‐end epiphysis fuses between ages 25 and 31. This is the last epiphysis of all long bones to unite with its shaft .

C

Femur: The femur’s head epiphysis fuses with the shaft around age 18–20, earlier than the clavicle’s final fusion, so it is not the last.

D

Radius: The distal radial epiphysis typically fuses by about age 17–18, and the proximal epiphysis by around age 20, also well before the clavicle.

96

In relation to the stomach, which of the following statements isfalse?

A. The cardia is situated at T12

B. It is completely invested by peritoneum

C. The pyloric opening is at L1

D. It is supplied by branches of the coeliac trunk

The false statement is:

B. It is completely invested by peritoneum

 

Explanation of Each Option:

✅ A. The cardia is situated at T12

  • True
  • The cardia (where the esophagus enters the stomach) lies approximately at the T11–T12 vertebral level, just left of the midline.

❌ B. It is completely invested by peritoneum

  • False
  • The stomach is intraperitoneal, meaning it is mostly covered by peritoneum, but not completely.
  • The posterior surface is related to the lesser sac and may lack complete peritoneal covering in certain areas (especially where vessels and ligaments attach).

✅ C. The pyloric opening is at L1

  • True
  • The pylorus lies at the L1 vertebral level, also known as the transpyloric plane.

✅ D. It is supplied by branches of the coeliac trunk

  • True
  • The stomach receives arterial supply from:
    • Left gastric artery
    • Right gastric artery
    • Left gastroepiploic artery
    • Right gastroepiploic artery
    • Short gastric arteries
      All of these are branches or sub-branches of the coeliac trunk.

 

Let me know if you'd like to review peritoneal reflections or stomach vascular anatomy!

97

Which portion of the urethra is most likely to be damaged with insertion of an indwelling urinary catheter?

A. Prostatic part

B. Intermediate part

C. Spongy part

D. External part

Here’s a concise and clinically accurate breakdown of this question:

 

Question: Which portion of the urethra is most likely to be damaged with insertion of an indwelling urinary catheter?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Prostatic part

❌ Incorrect

This part is wide and relatively protected by the prostate. Not commonly injured during catheterization.

B. Intermediate part (Membranous urethra)

✅ Correct

The intermediate (membranous) urethra is the narrowest and least distensible part of the urethra (after the external meatus) and is most commonly injured during catheter insertion. It is fixed as it passes through the external urethral sphincter and the deep perineal pouch, making it susceptible to trauma.

C. Spongy part

❌ Incorrect

The spongy (penile) urethra is long and mobile, and while it can be injured (e.g., during perineal trauma), it is less likely to be damaged by routine catheter insertion.

D. External part

❌ Incorrect

If referring to the external urethral meatus, this is the narrowest point of the urethra but is not the most likely site of significant injury during catheterization. It's superficial and usually passed with initial lubrication and care.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Intermediate part (membranous urethra)

Let me know if you’d like a clinical case or diagram to reinforce this concept!

98

Which muscle and resultant scapula movement is INCORRECT?

A. Protraction- Serratus anterior

B. Elevation- Trapezius (descending part)

C. Downward rotation- Lattisimus dorsi

D. Depression- Rhomboids

Option

Explanation

A

Protraction – Serratus anterior: Correct. Serratus anterior protracts (abducts) the scapula by pulling its medial border forward against the thoracic wall.

B

Elevation – Trapezius (descending part): Correct. The descending (superior) fibers of trapezius elevate the scapula, as when shrugging the shoulders.

C

Downward rotation – Latissimus dorsi: Correct. Latissimus dorsi, acting with pectoralis major and others, contributes to downward rotation of the scapula by drawing the inferior angle posteromedially.

D

Depression – Rhomboids: Incorrect. Rhomboids elevate, retract, and downwardly rotate the scapula; they do not depress it.

99

Which myotome causes big toe abduction?

A. L3

B. S2

C. L5

D. L4

Option

Explanation

A

L3: Incorrect. The L3 myotome primarily contributes to hip flexion and knee extension, not to movements of the great toe.

B

S2: Correct. The abductor hallucis muscle abducts the great toe (moves it away from the second toe) and is innervated by the medial plantar nerve with spinal segments S2–S3 (primarily S2). Thus, abduction of the big toe corresponds to the S2 myotome .

C

L5: Incorrect. The L5 myotome is best tested by dorsiflexion and extension of the great toe via extensor hallucis longus, not abduction.

D

L4: Incorrect. The L4 myotome is mainly involved in ankle dorsiflexion (tibialis anterior), not in intrinsic foot movements like big toe abduction.

100

In relation to the internal anal sphincter, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It has longitudinal fibres

B. It is skeletal muscle

C. It has no bony attachment

D. It extends along the length of the anal canal

Here’s a detailed analysis for this anatomy MCQ:

 

Question: In relation to the internal anal sphincter, which of the following statements is correct?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. It has longitudinal fibres

❌ Incorrect

The internal anal sphincter is composed of circular smooth muscle, not longitudinal fibres. The longitudinal muscle layer is part of the surrounding rectal wall but not part of the sphincter itself.

B. It is skeletal muscle

❌ Incorrect

The internal anal sphincter is made of involuntary smooth muscle. It contrasts with the external anal sphincter, which is skeletal (voluntary) muscle.

C. It has no bony attachment

✅ Correct

The internal anal sphincter is a smooth muscle thickening of the circular layer of the rectum and does not attach to bone. In contrast, the external sphincter (and associated perineal muscles) has bony and fascial attachments.

D. It extends along the length of the anal canal

❌ Incorrect

The internal anal sphincter extends only the upper two-thirds of the anal canal, not the full length. The external sphincter surrounds the full length.

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. It has no bony attachment

Let me know if you'd like a comparison table between internal and external anal sphincters or a cross-sectional diagram of the anal canal.

101

Running superior to inferior, branches of the aorta include

A. Coeliac, supra-renal, gonadal, superior mesenteric

B. Coeliac, gonadal, renal, inferior mesenteric

C. Coeliac, superior mesenteric, supra-renal, renal

D. Coeliac, superior mesenteric, renal, gonadal

The correct answer is: D. Coeliac, superior mesenteric, renal, gonadal

 

✅ Explanation – Branches of the Abdominal Aorta (superior to inferior):

Here is the typical order of major branches off the abdominal aorta:

  1. Coeliac trunk – at the level of T12
  2. Superior mesenteric artery – at L1
  3. Middle suprarenal arteries – around L1, just below SMA
  4. Renal arteries – at L1–L2
  5. Gonadal arteries (testicular/ovarian) – at L2
  6. Inferior mesenteric artery – at L3

 

Let's assess the options:

A. Coeliac, supra-renal, gonadal, superior mesenteric ❌

  • Gonadal comes after superior mesenteric, not before → Incorrect order.

B. Coeliac, gonadal, renal, inferior mesenteric ❌

  • Gonadal comes after renal → Incorrect order.

C. Coeliac, superior mesenteric, supra-renal, renal ❌

  • While this is close, suprarenal is a small lateral branch, and renal arteries are more prominent and come slightly lower.

D. Coeliac, superior mesenteric, renal, gonadal ✅

  • This is the correct anatomical order of the main unpaired and paired branches superior to inferior.

 

🧠 Mnemonic (for unpaired arteries):

"CSI"

  • Coeliac
  • Superior mesenteric
  • Inferior mesenteric

Let me know if you’d like a diagram or quick summary chart of aortic branches!

102

With regard to the coronary arteries, which of the following statements is correct?

A. Left coronary artery (LCA) supplies the AV node in 80% of patients

B. Right coronary artery (RCA) arises from the posterior coronary sinus

C. Right coronary artery (RCA) supplies the SA node in 60% of patients

D. There are no arteriolar anastomoses between left and right

 

Here's a detailed breakdown of this high-yield cardiac anatomy MCQ:

 

Question: With regard to the coronary arteries, which of the following statements is correct?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Left coronary artery (LCA) supplies the AV node in 80% of patients

❌ Incorrect

In about 80–90% of individuals, the AV node is supplied by a branch of the right coronary artery (RCA) — specifically, the AV nodal branch, which usually arises near the crux of the heart. Only about 10–20% have AV nodal supply from the LCA.

B. Right coronary artery (RCA) arises from the posterior coronary sinus

❌ Incorrect

The RCA arises from the anterior (right) aortic sinus, also called the right coronary sinus, not from the posterior sinus. The posterior aortic sinus usually has no coronary artery origin.

C. Right coronary artery (RCA) supplies the SA node in 60% of patients

✅ Correct

The SA node is supplied by the RCA in ~60–70% of individuals via the SA nodal artery. In the remaining ~30–40%, the LCA (via the circumflex branch) supplies it. This is the correct statement.

D. There are no arteriolar anastomoses between left and right

❌ Incorrect

While large branches of LCA and RCA are functionally end arteries, there are small arteriolar anastomoses between them — especially between LAD and PDA, and between circumflex and RCA. These can be important in chronic ischemia.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Right coronary artery (RCA) supplies the SA node in 60% of patients

Let me know if you'd like a labeled diagram of coronary artery dominance or a table on coronary artery distributions.

 

103

The primary motor centre is found in which lobe?

A. Frontal

B. Parietal

C. Temporal

D. Occipital

The correct answer is:

A. Frontal

 

Explanation:

  • The primary motor cortex is located in the precentral gyrus, which is part of the frontal lobe.
  • It is responsible for voluntary motor control, especially fine motor movements.

 

Locations of Other Key Areas:

  • Parietal lobe → Primary somatosensory cortex (postcentral gyrus)
  • Temporal lobe → Auditory cortex, language (Wernicke’s area)
  • Occipital lobe → Primary visual cortex

 

Let me know if you'd like a labeled brain diagram or functions of each lobe!

104

The following is true about the submandibualr gland EXCEPT?

A. The submental arteries supply the gland

B. Parasympathetic secretomotor fibres is supplied by vagus

C. Lymphatic drainage is chiefly via the jugulo-omohyoid node

D. It is larger than the sublingual gland

The false statement is:

B. Parasympathetic secretomotor fibres are supplied by vagus

 

✅ Corrected Explanation:

  • Parasympathetic innervation of the submandibular gland is via the facial nerve (CN VII), not the vagus nerve (CN X).
    • Specifically, via the chorda tympani branch, which joins the lingual nerve (a branch of CN V3).
    • These fibres synapse in the submandibular ganglion and provide secretomotor stimulation to the gland.

 

✔️ Other options are true:

  • A. The submental arteries supply the gland
    • True: The submental branch of the facial artery contributes to the blood supply of the submandibular gland.
  • C. Lymphatic drainage is chiefly via the jugulo-omohyoid node
    • True: This deep cervical lymph node is a key drainage point for the submandibular and submental regions.
  • D. It is larger than the sublingual gland
    • True: The submandibular gland is the second-largest salivary gland, larger than the sublingual but smaller than the parotid.

 

Let me know if you’d like a diagram of the salivary gland anatomy or innervation pathways!

105

Which of the following statements is correct regarding the oesophagus?

A. Begins at the lower border of the thyroid cartilage

B. Is narrowest at the commencement at the cricopharyngeal sphincter

C. Ends at the cardiac orifice of the stomach at level T10

D. Is 28cm long

The correct answer is:

B. Is narrowest at the commencement at the cricopharyngeal sphincter

 

✅ Explanation of Each Option:

A. Begins at the lower border of the thyroid cartilage

  • ❌ Incorrect
  • The oesophagus begins at the lower border of the cricoid cartilage (C6), not the thyroid cartilage.

B. Is narrowest at the commencement at the cricopharyngeal sphincter

  • ✅ Correct
  • The upper esophageal sphincter at the cricopharyngeus muscle (around C6) is the narrowest part of the oesophagus and a common site for foreign body impaction.

C. Ends at the cardiac orifice of the stomach at level T10

  • ❌ Incorrect
  • The oesophagus passes through the diaphragm at T10, but it ends slightly below this, around the T11 vertebral level, where it meets the stomach at the cardiac orifice.

D. Is 28 cm long

  • ❌ Incorrect
  • The average length of the adult oesophagus is about 25 cm from the upper incisor teeth to the gastroesophageal junction.

 

Let me know if you'd like a visual of the esophageal constrictions and their clinical importance!

106

In which ganglion do the cell bodies of afferent taste fibres of the anterior two thirds of the tongue occur?

A. Genicular

B. Submandibular

C. Otic

D. Trigeminal

✅ Correct Answer: A. Genicular ganglion

 

🧠 Explanation:

  • Taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is carried by the chorda tympani, a branch of the facial nerve (CN VII).
  • The cell bodies of these afferent taste fibers are located in the geniculate ganglion, which is the sensory ganglion of the facial nerve.
  • The geniculate ganglion lies in the facial canal within the temporal bone.

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

Option

Ganglion Type

Associated Nerve

Why Incorrect

B. Submandibular

Parasympathetic (motor)

Facial nerve (CN VII)

Supplies submandibular and sublingual glands, not sensory

C. Otic

Parasympathetic (motor)

Glossopharyngeal (CN IX)

Supplies parotid gland, not involved in taste

D. Trigeminal

Sensory

Trigeminal nerve (CN V)

General sensation (touch/pain), not special sensation (taste)

 

Would you like a diagram showing the taste pathways from the tongue to the brainstem?

107

Which is the correct linkage between a myotome and its action?

A. L3,4-knee extension

B. S1/S2-hip abduction

C. L5/S1 inversion of the ankle

D. L2,3-hip extension

Option

Myotome–Action

Explanation

A

L3,4 – knee extension

Correct. The quadriceps femoris, responsible for knee extension, is innervated by the femoral nerve carrying fibers from L3 and L4. Testing knee extension assesses the L3–L4 myotome.

B

S1/S2 – hip abduction

Incorrect. Hip abduction is primarily mediated by gluteus medius and minimus (superior gluteal nerve), corresponding to L4–L5 (mainly L5), not S1–S2.

C

L5/S1 – ankle inversion

Incorrect. Ankle inversion is performed by tibialis anterior (deep fibular nerve, L4–L5) and tibialis posterior (tibial nerve, L4–L5). The L5 myotome is involved, but S1 is not essential for inversion.

D

L2,3 – hip extension

Incorrect. Hip extension is primarily via gluteus maximus (inferior gluteal nerve, L5–S1). The L2–L3 myotomes contribute to hip flexion (iliopsoas), not extension.

 

108

The infratrochlear nerve supplies which of the following areas?

A. Labial portion of the gum

B. Upper incisors

C. Bridge of the nose

D. Skin of the lower eyelid

The infratrochlear nerve is a terminal branch of the nasociliary nerve (which itself is a branch of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve, CN V1).

Let me analyze each option:

A. Labial portion of the gum - This is incorrect. The labial portion of the gum is supplied by branches of the maxillary nerve (CN V2), not the infratrochlear nerve.

B. Upper incisors - This is incorrect. The upper incisors are innervated by the anterior superior alveolar nerve, a branch of the maxillary nerve (CN V2).

C. Bridge of the nose - This is correct. The infratrochlear nerve supplies sensory innervation to the skin of the bridge of the nose, as well as the medial part of the upper eyelid and the medial canthus of the eye.

D. Skin of the lower eyelid - This is incorrect. The skin of the lower eyelid is primarily supplied by the infraorbital nerve (a branch of CN V2), not the infratrochlear nerve.

The correct answer is C.

The infratrochlear nerve exits the orbit medially, below the trochlea (hence its name), and provides sensory innervation to the skin over the bridge of the nose and the medial aspect of the upper eyelid.

109

Cerebrospinal fluid communicates with the subarachnoid space via which of the following?

A. 3rd ventricle

B. 4th ventricle

C. Choroid plexus

D. Tela Choroidia

The correct answer is: B. 4th ventricle

 

✅ Explanation:

Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) enters the subarachnoid space from the 4th ventricle through:

  • One median aperture (foramen of Magendie)
  • Two lateral apertures (foramina of Luschka)

These are the only normal anatomical openings through which CSF flows from the ventricular system into the subarachnoid space, where it surrounds the brain and spinal cord.

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

  • A. 3rd ventricle
    → CSF flows from the 3rd ventricle to the 4th via the cerebral aqueduct, but it does not directly communicate with the subarachnoid space.
  • C. Choroid plexus
    → This produces CSF, but does not allow communication between the ventricles and subarachnoid space.
  • D. Tela choroidea (tela choroidea)
    → This is a vascular membrane that helps form the choroid plexus, but it doesn’t provide a communication pathway for CSF to the subarachnoid space.

 

✅ Final Answer: B. 4th ventricle

110

Regarding pectoralis major, which of the following statements is correct?

A. Inserts to the medial lip of bicipital groove

B. Is quadrilateral in shape

C. Is supplied by all 5 segments of the brachial plexus

D. Has a head arising from the posterior surface of the clavicle

 

Thought for 8 seconds

Option

Explanation

A

Incorrect. Pectoralis major inserts on the lateral lip of the bicipital (intertubercular) groove of the humerus—not the medial lip Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Incorrect. The muscle is described as fan-shaped, not quadrilateral Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Correct. Pectoralis major is innervated by the lateral pectoral nerve (C5–C7) and medial pectoral nerve (C8–T1), thus receiving fibers from all five brachial plexus segments (C5, C6, C7, C8, T1) Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Incorrect. Its clavicular head originates from the anterior surface of the medial half of the clavicle, not the posterior surface Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

111

Which is primarily responsible for the peripheral sensory supply to the diaphragm?

A. Intercostal nerves

B. Phrenic nerve

C. Vagus nerve

D. Subcostal nerves

Here's the detailed breakdown for this neuroanatomy MCQ:

 

Question: Which is primarily responsible for the peripheral sensory supply to the diaphragm?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Intercostal nerves

✅ Correct

The peripheral (outer rim) of the diaphragmatic pleura and peritoneum is supplied by the lower intercostal nerves (T7–T11) and the subcostal nerve (T12). These nerves provide somatic sensory innervation to the peripheral diaphragm, especially the costal and lateral aspects.

B. Phrenic nerve

❌ Incorrect

The phrenic nerve (C3–C5) provides motor innervation to the entire diaphragm and sensory innervation to its central portion — including the central pleura, pericardium, and peritoneum — not the periphery.

C. Vagus nerve

❌ Incorrect

The vagus nerve is involved in visceral sensory and parasympathetic innervation (e.g., thoracic and abdominal viscera), but not somatic sensory to the diaphragm.

D. Subcostal nerves

❌ Incorrect (but partially true)

The subcostal nerve (T12) may contribute a little to peripheral diaphragmatic sensation, but it is considered secondary to the intercostal nerves, which do the majority of the work.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Intercostal nerves

Let me know if you'd like a diagram showing sensory territories of the diaphragm or a table comparing motor and sensory supply.

112

Regarding the adductor canal, which of the following statements is correct?

A. The vein is medial to the artery throughout

B. The nerve to vastus lateralis passes through it

C. The femoral artery lies between the saphenous nerve and femoral vein

D. Adductor longus forms the roof

Option

Explanation

A

Incorrect. Although the femoral vein accompanies the artery in the canal, it lies posterolateral (and then posterior) to the femoral artery as it ascends through the adductor canal, not strictly medial to it .

B

Incorrect. The nerve to vastus medialis, not vastus lateralis, travels through the adductor canal alongside the femoral vessels and the saphenous nerve .

C

Correct. Within the adductor canal, the femoral artery is situated between the saphenous nerve (anteromedially) and the femoral vein (posterolaterally) .

D

Incorrect. The roof of the canal is formed by the sartorius muscle (and its overlying fascia), not by adductor longus. Adductor longus lies posterior to the canal rather than forming its roof .

113

In the cubital fossa, which of the following is lateral to the tendon of biceps?

A. Median nerve

B. Brachial artery

C. radial nerve

D. median cubital vein

Option

Explanation

A. Median nerve

Incorrect. The median nerve lies medial to the biceps tendon within the cubital fossa.

B. Brachial artery

Incorrect. The brachial artery is directly medial or slightly inferomedial to the biceps tendon, not lateral.

C. Radial nerve

Correct. The radial nerve lies lateral to the biceps tendon as it passes through the cubital fossa before dividing into its deep and superficial branches.

D. Median cubital vein

Incorrect. The median cubital vein is a superficial structure crossing the roof of the cubital fossa; it is neither deep nor immediately lateral to the tendon.

114

In relation to the lateral compartment of the leg, which of the following statements is correct?

A. Contains peroneus longus, brevis and tertius

B. Peroneus longus lies in the groove on the posterior ridge of the cuboid bone

C. Contains the deep peroneal nerve and the superficial peroneal nerve

D. Peroneus brevis passes above the peroneal  trochlea to be inserted into the tubercle at the base of the 5th metatarsal

Option

Explanation

A

Incorrect. The lateral compartment contains peroneus (fibularis) longus and brevis only; peroneus tertius is in the anterior compartment.

B

Incorrect. Peroneus longus passes under the foot through a groove on the plantar surface of the cuboid, not on a “posterior ridge” of the cuboid bone.

C

Incorrect. The lateral compartment is innervated by the superficial peroneal nerve only; the deep peroneal nerve lies in the anterior compartment.

D

Correct. The tendon of peroneus brevis passes above the peroneal trochlea on the lateral calcaneus before inserting on the tuberosity at the base of the 5th metatarsal.

115

Protrusion of the jaw is a function of which cranial nerve?

A. CN VII

B. CN V

C. CN IX

D. CN X

Here's the analysis for this cranial nerve function MCQ:

 

Question: Protrusion of the jaw is a function of which cranial nerve?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. CN VII (Facial nerve)

❌ Incorrect

CN VII controls muscles of facial expression, not jaw movement. It innervates muscles like orbicularis oris and buccinator, but not the muscles of mastication.

B. CN V (Trigeminal nerve)

✅ Correct

Specifically, the mandibular division (V3) of CN V supplies the muscles of mastication, including the lateral pterygoid muscle, which is responsible for protrusion of the jaw.

C. CN IX (Glossopharyngeal nerve)

❌ Incorrect

CN IX is involved in swallowing and taste (posterior 1/3 of tongue) but has no role in jaw movement.

D. CN X (Vagus nerve)

❌ Incorrect

CN X controls laryngeal, pharyngeal, and soft palate muscles, not the muscles of mastication or jaw movement.

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. CN V (Mandibular division – V3)

💡 Key muscle: Lateral pterygoid – "opens the jaw and pushes it forward."

Let me know if you'd like a summary table of cranial nerve motor functions!

116

The intercostals increase the volume of the thorax in which dimension?

A. Lateral

B. Oblique

C. Vertical

D. Anterior-posterior

The correct answer is:

A. Lateral

 

Explanation:

The intercostal muscles, particularly the external intercostals, assist in inspiration by elevating the ribs. This movement increases the volume of the thoracic cavity in the lateral dimension — often described as the “bucket-handle” movement of the ribs.

 

Three Dimensions of Thoracic Expansion During Inspiration:

  1. Vertical – via diaphragm contraction (not intercostals)
  2. Lateral – via bucket-handle motion of ribs (done by intercostals) ✅
  3. Anterior-posterior – via pump-handle motion of the sternum (also aided by intercostals)

 

So, while intercostals contribute to anterior-posterior expansion as well, their most characteristic and prominent action is in the lateral direction.

Let me know if you'd like a diagram or comparison of all three movements!

117

Which myotome/myotomes is/are associated with shoulder abduction?

A. C5, 6, 7

B. C6, 7

C. C5, 6

D. C5

Option

Explanation

A

Incorrect. While C5 and C6 are essential for abduction, C7 does not contribute significantly to this movement.

B

Incorrect. C6 contributes, but C5 is the primary myotome driving shoulder abduction; C7 is not involved.

C

Correct. Shoulder abduction is initiated by supraspinatus (C5) and continued by deltoid (C5–C6). Thus, both C5 and C6 are required.

D

Incorrect. C5 is crucial, but C6 also contributes via the deltoid; relying on C5 alone is incomplete.

118

Regarding the brachial plexus, which of the following statements is correct?

A. All branches originate from roots, divisions or cords

B. Serratus anterior is supplied by C6/7/8

C. Suprascapular nerve comes off the posterior cord

D. Dorsal scapular nerve comes off C5

The correct answer is:

D. Dorsal scapular nerve comes off C5

 

✅ Explanation of Each Option:

A. All branches originate from roots, divisions or cords

  • ❌ Incorrect
  • Most branches arise from roots, trunks, or cords, not divisions.
    • The divisions (anterior/posterior) of the brachial plexus do not give off any branches.

B. Serratus anterior is supplied by C6/7/8

  • ❌ Incorrect
  • The long thoracic nerve (which supplies serratus anterior) arises from C5, C6, and C7 — not C8.

C. Suprascapular nerve comes off the posterior cord

  • ❌ Incorrect
  • The suprascapular nerve comes off the upper trunk, not the posterior cord.

D. Dorsal scapular nerve comes off C5

  • ✅ Correct
  • The dorsal scapular nerve arises directly from the C5 root of the brachial plexus and supplies the rhomboid major, rhomboid minor, and levator scapulae.

 

Let me know if you’d like a simplified diagram of the brachial plexus to help visualize this!

119

Which abdominal artery bifurcates into the splenic and common hepatic arteries

A. Celiac trunk

B. Superior mesenteric artey

C. Hepatic artery

D. Inferior mesenteric artery

The correct answer is: A. Celiac trunk

 

✅ Explanation:

The celiac trunk is a major branch of the abdominal aorta, arising at the T12 level, and it immediately trifurcates into three major branches:

  1. Left gastric artery
  2. Splenic artery
  3. Common hepatic artery

This classic trifurcation is sometimes called the "Tripod of Haller".

 

120

Which muscle takes origin from the tibia and the fibula?

A. Tibialis posterior

B. Peroneus longus

C. Flexor hallucis longus

D. Flexor digitorium longus (FDL)

Option

Explanation

A

Tibialis posterior originates from both the posterior surfaces of the tibia and fibula (and the intervening interosseous membrane), so this is the correct choice.

B

Peroneus longus arises from the head and upper lateral shaft of the fibula only; it does not take origin from the tibia.

C

Flexor hallucis longus originates from the inferior two-thirds of the posterior fibula (and interosseous membrane), not from the tibia.

D

Flexor digitorum longus arises from the posterior surface of the tibia alone; it does not originate from the fibula.

121

The thoraco-acromial artery is a branch of which artery?

A. Vertebral

B. Subclavian

C. Axillary

D. Superior intercostal

Option

Explanation

A

Incorrect. The vertebral artery is a branch of the subclavian that ascends to supply the brain; it does not give rise to the thoraco-acromial artery.

B

Incorrect. Although the axillary artery is a continuation of the subclavian, the thoraco-acromial trunk specifically arises from the axillary, not directly from the subclavian.

C

Correct. The thoraco-acromial artery (trunk) is a branch of the second part of the axillary artery, supplying nearby pectoral and shoulder regions.

D

Incorrect. The superior intercostal artery comes from the costocervical trunk of the subclavian and supplies the upper intercostal spaces; it is not related to the thoraco-acromial.

122

Which nerve is affected by fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus?

A. Musculocutaneous nerve

B. Median nerve

C. Radial nerve

D. Axillary nerve

Option

Explanation

A. Musculocutaneous

Incorrect. The musculocutaneous nerve passes through the anterior arm, piercing coracobrachialis, and lies far from the surgical neck of the humerus.

B. Median nerve

Incorrect. The median nerve runs medial to the brachial artery in the anterior arm and is not located near the surgical neck; it is more at risk with distal humeral injuries.

C. Radial nerve

Incorrect. The radial nerve courses in the radial (spiral) groove of the humeral shaft (midshaft), so midshaft fractures, but not surgical neck fractures, endanger it.

D. Axillary nerve

Correct. The axillary nerve wraps around the surgical neck of the humerus, so fractures at this location commonly injure the axillary nerve, affecting deltoid function and sensation over the lateral shoulder.

123

Regarding the axillary vein which of the following isFALSE?

A. The axillary vein ends at the lateral border of the first rib and becomes the subclavian vein

B. The axillary vein is formed by the union of the brachial vein and the cephalic vein

C. The axillary vein receives anastomoses from the superficial veins of the inguinal region

D. The axillary vein lies initially (distally) on the anteromedial side of the axillary artery, with its terminal part anteroinferior to the artery

Option

Explanation

A

True. The axillary vein continues from the basilic and brachial veins and ends at the lateral border of the first rib, where it becomes the subclavian vein.

B

False. The axillary vein is formed by the union of the brachial veins and the basilic vein; the cephalic vein is a tributary that joins it more proximally, not a primary contributor to its formation.

C

True. Via the thoracoepigastric system, superficial veins from the inguinal region (through the superficial epigastric veins) can anastomose with the axillary vein through connections with the lateral thoracic vein.

D

True. In the axilla, the vein lies initially on the anteromedial side of the axillary artery; as it ascends toward the thorax, its terminal portion lies anteroinferior to the artery.

124

What is the blood supply to the body of the pancreas?

A. Left Gastric artery

B. Splenic artery

C. Hepatic artery

D. Left gastroepiploic artery

🩺 Summary:

  • Head of pancreas → Supplied by pancreaticoduodenal arteries
  • Body & Tail → Supplied by branches of the splenic artery ✅

125

Which of the following structures exits the skull through the stylomastoid foramen?

A. Facial nerve

B. Occipital artery

C. Trigeminal nerve

D. Temporal artery

✅ Correct Answer: A. Facial nerve

 

🧠 Explanation:

The facial nerve (CN VII) exits the skull through the stylomastoid foramen, which is located between the mastoid and styloid processes of the temporal bone.

  • After exiting:
    • It gives off the posterior auricular nerve and branches to stylohyoid and posterior belly of digastric.
    • Then enters the parotid gland, where it divides into five terminal motor branches.

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

Option

Structure

Reason

B. Occipital artery

Exits via posterior neck region, not a cranial foramen

❌ Not through stylomastoid foramen

C. Trigeminal nerve (CN V)

Its divisions exit through V₁: SOF, V₂: rotundum, V₃: ovale

❌ Does not pass through stylomastoid foramen

D. Temporal artery

A terminal branch of the external carotid artery (superficial)

❌ Travels in scalp, not through any skull foramen

 

Would you like a labeled diagram of the skull foramina and what passes through each?

126

Corneal sensation pathway involves which ganglion?

A. Optic

B. Geniculate

C. Ciliary

D. Trigeminal

✅ Correct Answer: D. Trigeminal ganglion

 

🧠 Explanation:

Corneal sensation (i.e., touch, pain, temperature from the cornea) is mediated by the:

  • Ophthalmic division (V₁) of the trigeminal nerve (CN V), specifically via the nasociliary branch.
  • The sensory neuron cell bodies for this pathway reside in the trigeminal (Gasserian or semilunar) ganglion.

 

Pathway Summary:

  1. Stimulus to cornea →
  2. Via long ciliary nerves → branch of nasociliary nerve →
  3. → Ophthalmic division (V₁) → Trigeminal ganglion →
  4. → Sensory nuclei in brainstem

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

Option

Associated With

Why Incorrect

A. Optic

Visual signals from retina (CN II)

❌ Involved in vision, not corneal sensation

B. Geniculate

Facial nerve sensory ganglion

❌ Taste from anterior tongue, not cornea

C. Ciliary

Parasympathetic ganglion (CN III related)

❌ Controls pupil/lens, not sensory

 

Would you like to review the corneal reflex arc as well (afferent = CN V₁, efferent = CN VII)?

127

In terms of the relationship of structures within the cubital fossa, which of the following is correct?

A. The ulnar artery lies superficial to the pronator teres

B. The radial nerve is medial to biceps tendon

C. The radial artery is a direct continuation of the brachial artery

D. The median nerve lies lateral to the brachial artery

Option

Explanation

A

False. The ulnar artery in the cubital fossa lies deep to the pronator teres as it descends into the forearm; it does not run superficial to that muscle.

B

False. The radial nerve (before dividing) lies lateral to the biceps tendon in the cubital fossa, not medial.

C

False. The brachial artery terminates in the cubital fossa by dividing into the radial and ulnar arteries; the radial artery is a branch (terminal division), not a straight continuation.

D

False. The median nerve runs medial to the brachial artery in the cubital fossa, not lateral.

Conclusion: None of the four statements is correct.

128

Which of the following  is an example of a secondary cartilaginous joint?

A. An intervertebral disc

B. costochondral joint

C. Temporomandibular joint

D. lambdoid suture

Option

Explanation

A

Correct. An intervertebral disc is a symphysis, a secondary cartilaginous joint composed of fibrocartilage between vertebral bodies.

B

Incorrect. The costochondral joint is a primary cartilaginous joint (synchondrosis) where the rib meets its costal cartilage; it is not a secondary cartilaginous joint.

C

Incorrect. The temporomandibular joint is a synovial (synovial hinge) joint, not cartilaginous.

D

Incorrect. The lambdoid suture is a fibrous joint (a suture) between skull bones, not a cartilaginous joint.

129

Which part of bone is a correct match?

A. Coronoid process of the humerus

B. Coronoid fossa of the ulna

C. Radial notch of the radius

D. Trochlear notch of the ulna

Option

Explanation

A

Coronoid process of the humerus: Incorrect. The coronoid process is a feature of the ulna, projecting anteriorly to form part of the trochlear notch. The humerus has a coronoid fossa (not a process) on its distal anterior surface to receive the ulna’s coronoid process during elbow flexion .

B

Coronoid fossa of the ulna: Incorrect. The coronoid fossa is on the humerus, not the ulna. The ulna has a coronoid process; its fossa for the humeral coronoid process is called the olecranon fossa (posterior) and coronoid fossa (anterior) on the humerus .

C

Radial notch of the radius: Incorrect. The radial notch is on the ulna (lateral surface of the proximal ulna), where the head of the radius articulates. The radius itself features an ulnar notch distally for articulation with the ulna, not a radial notch .

D

Trochlear notch of the ulna: Correct. The trochlear notch is a large, C-shaped indentation on the proximal ulna, formed by the olecranon and coronoid processes, which articulates with the trochlea of the humerus to allow hinge movements of the elbow .

130

Which is true regarding the cruciate ligaments of the knee?

A. The anterior cruciate is stronger than the posterior cruciate ligament

B. The anterior cruciate ligament prevents hyperextension of the knee

C. The posterior cruciate helps prevent posterior displacement of the femur on the tibia

D. The posterior cruciate attaches to the posterior part of the lateral surface of the medial condyle of the femur

 

Option

Explanation

A

False. The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) is actually the weaker of the two cruciate ligaments. The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) is stronger.

B

True. The ACL prevents hyperextension of the knee, as well as posterior displacement of the femur on the tibia.

C

False. The PCL prevents anterior displacement of the femur on the tibia (or, equivalently, posterior displacement of the tibia on the femur), not posterior displacement of the femur on the tibia.

D

False. The PCL attaches to the anterior part of the lateral surface of the medial femoral condyle, not the posterior part.

 

131

Which of the following muscles is not used in forced expiration?

A. diaphragm

B. rectus abdominis

C. external oblique muscles

D. internal oblique muscles

The correct answer is:

A. Diaphragm

 

Explanation:

  • The diaphragm is the primary muscle of inspiration, not expiration.
    • During inspiration, it contracts and flattens, increasing thoracic volume.
    • During expiration, especially forced expiration, it relaxes — it is not actively involved.

 

Muscles Used in Forced Expiration (All are active):

  • ✅ Rectus abdominis
  • ✅ External oblique
  • ✅ Internal oblique
  • ✅ Transversus abdominis
  • ✅ Internal intercostals (except interchondral part)

These muscles act to compress the abdominal cavity, push the diaphragm upward, and reduce thoracic volume, forcing air out.

 

Let me know if you'd like a breakdown of respiratory muscle activity in quiet vs. forced breathing!

132

A patient suffers a fracture of the femoral neck. Which of the following features of the fractures are false?

A. Fractures of the femoral neck results in medial rotation of the lower limb

B. Aseptic avascular necrosis of the femoral head is a common complication of a neck of femur fracture

C. Most of the blood supply to the head and neck of the femur is via the medial circumflex femoral artery

D. Femoral neck fractures (NOF) are common in people >60yrs old,

Option

Explanation

A

False. Femoral neck fractures typically result in lateral rotation of the lower limb due to unopposed external rotators, not medial rotation.

B

True. Aseptic avascular necrosis of the femoral head is a common complication because fracture disrupts blood supply from retinacular vessels.

C

True. The majority of blood supply to the femoral head and neck is via the medial circumflex femoral artery and its retinacular branches.

D

True. Femoral neck fractures are most common in older adults (usually > 60 years) due to osteoporosis and increased fall risk.

133

Which is the correct myotome for elbow extension?

A. C6/7

B. C5/6

C. C5/C6/C7

D. C7/C8

Wtf

In Moore’s “Segmental innervation of movements of the upper limb” (Figure 6.20), elbow extension is shown as primarily a C7 myotome (with C8 contributing) . Thus, loss of C7 alone markedly weakens or abolishes elbow extension. Of the given options, the pairing that best matches this is D. C7/C8, since C7 is the bolded (main) segment for triceps‐mediated extension, and C8 provides auxiliary fibers.

 

134

Which of the following nerves has roots from C6, C7 and C8?

A. Long thoracic nerve

B. Thoracodorsal nerve

C. Nerve to subclavius

D. Suprascapular nerve

 

Option

Nerve

Explanation

A

Long thoracic nerve

Incorrect. The long thoracic nerve arises from the anterior rami of C5, C6, and C7, not C6–C8. It innervates serratus anterior. Moore - Clinically Orie…

B

Thoracodorsal nerve

Correct. The thoracodorsal nerve (middle subscapular) originates from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus with fibers from C6, C7, and C8. It supplies latissimus dorsi. Moore - Clinically Orie…

C

Nerve to subclavius

Incorrect. The nerve to subclavius derives from the superior trunk, carrying fibers primarily from C5 and C6. Moore - Clinically Orie…

D

Suprascapular nerve

Incorrect. The suprascapular nerve arises from the superior trunk with contributions from C5 and C6 (and often C4), not C6–C8. Moore - Clinically Orie…

 

135

The motor supply to the diaphragm is by the follwing nerve

A. Phrenic nerve

B. Vagus nerve

C. Intercostal nerves

D. Subcostal nerves

The correct answer is:

A. Phrenic nerve

 

✅ Explanation:

  • The phrenic nerve is the sole motor supply to the diaphragm.
  • It arises from C3, C4, and C5 spinal nerve roots
    👉 "C3, 4, 5 keep the diaphragm alive."

 

❌ Other Options:

  • B. Vagus nerve:
    • Supplies parasympathetic innervation to thoracic and abdominal organs, not motor to the diaphragm.
  • C. Intercostal nerves:
    • Supply intercostal muscles and parts of the parietal pleura, not the diaphragm (except some sensory innervation to peripheral diaphragm).
  • D. Subcostal nerves:
    • Are the T12 intercostal nerves, supply abdominal wall muscles, not motor to diaphragm.

 

Let me know if you’d like details on sensory innervation or diaphragm-related pathologies!

136

A gentleman presents with shingles across his right cheek, which nerve in likely involved?

A. Zygomatic

B. Buccal

C. Supraorbital

D. Infraorbital

✅ Correct Answer: D. Infraorbital nerve

 

🧠 Explanation:

  • Shingles (Herpes Zoster) is caused by reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus in a sensory nerve ganglion.
  • Involvement of the right cheek indicates reactivation in a branch of the maxillary division (V₂) of the trigeminal nerve (CN V).
  • The infraorbital nerve is the main terminal branch of V₂ and provides sensory innervation to the cheek, lower eyelid, and upper lip.

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

Option

Nerve

Region Supplied

Why Incorrect

A. Zygomatic

Branch of V₂

Temple and cheek (minor role)

❌ Less direct sensory supply to cheek skin

B. Buccal

Branch of V₃ (Mandibular)

Mucosa & skin of cheek, not the anterior cheek

❌ Cheek mucosa mainly, not the skin of the face

C. Supraorbital

Branch of V₁ (Ophthalmic)

Forehead and scalp

❌ Supplies upper forehead, not cheek

 

📍 Clinical Tip:

  • Herpes zoster in V₁ → watch for ocular involvement (emergency).
  • V₂ involvement → rash over cheek and upper lip, often painful.

Would you like a dermatome map of the trigeminal nerve for quick reference?

137

Which muscle controls vocal cord abduction in the larynx?

A. Transverse arytenoid

B. Lateral cricoarytenoid

C. Posterior cricoarytenoid

D. Aryepiglottic

The correct answer is:

A. Posterior cricoarytenoid

Explanation:

  • The posterior cricoarytenoid is the only muscle that abducts (opens) the vocal cords by rotating the arytenoid cartilages laterally.
  • This action is crucial for breathing, as it opens the rima glottidis (space between the vocal cords).

Other options:

  • B. Aryepiglottic – helps close the laryngeal inlet during swallowing.
  • C. Cricothyroid – tenses and elongates the vocal cords (increases pitch), but does not abduct them.
  • D. Thyroarytenoid – relaxes the vocal cords (lowers pitch), also not involved in abduction.

Let me know if you’d like a visual of laryngeal muscles or innervation details!

138

Which is true in respect of the anatomy of the trachea?

A. It has a 3.5cm diameter in adults

B. It is 20cm long and bifurcates below the manubrium sterni

C. In the first year of life the trachea is10mm in diameter

D. Trachea extends from the inferior end of the larynx at the level of C6 vertebrae

The correct answer is:

D. Trachea extends from the inferior end of the larynx at the level of C6 vertebra

 

✅ Explanation of Each Option:

A. It has a 3.5 cm diameter in adults

  • ❌ Incorrect
  • The average adult tracheal diameter is about 1.8–2.5 cm, not 3.5 cm.

B. It is 20 cm long and bifurcates below the manubrium sterni

  • ❌ Incorrect
  • The trachea is typically 10–12 cm long in adults.
  • It bifurcates at the level of the sternal angle (manubriosternal joint), which corresponds to T4/T5, not below the manubrium.

C. In the first year of life the trachea is 10 mm in diameter

  • ❌ Incorrect
  • In infants, the tracheal diameter is usually around 4–5 mm, not 10 mm.

D. Trachea extends from the inferior end of the larynx at the level of C6 vertebra

  • ✅ Correct
  • The trachea begins at the cricoid cartilage, which is located at the C6 vertebral level.

 

Let me know if you'd like a diagram of the trachea or key anatomical landmarks!

139

Regarding the deltoid muscle, which is correct?

A. It attaches to the spine of scapula, acromion, clavicle and deltoid tuberosity

B. It initiates abduction

C. It has anterior and middle unipennate parts and a multipennate posterior part

D. It is supplied by the axillary nerve (C4,C5)

Option

Explanation

A

Correct. The deltoid originates from the lateral third of the clavicle, the acromion, and the spine of the scapula, and inserts on the deltoid tuberosity of the humerus .

B

Incorrect. The deltoid does not initiate abduction—supraspinatus begins the first 15° of abduction. Only after abduction is underway does the deltoid become the prime mover .

C

Incorrect. The deltoid has unipennate anterior and posterior parts and a multipennate middle part—not anterior and middle unipennate with a multipennate posterior part .

D

Incorrect. The deltoid is innervated by the axillary nerve carrying fibers from C5 and C6, not from C4 and C5 .

140

All of the following drain into the great saphenous vein except?

A. Superficial circumflex iliac

B. Superficial epigastric

C. Deep external pudendal

D. Deep circumflex iliac

You’re right to notice that the deep external pudendal vein also does not drain into the great saphenous vein—it enters the femoral vein directly.

However, among the four choices, textbooks (including Moore) list the superficial external pudendal as a true tributary of the GSV; the deep external pudendal empties into the femoral vein. Likewise, the deep circumflex iliac drains into the external iliac vein, not the GSV. In other words, both C and D fail to empty into the great saphenous.

In most sources, the “classic” answer given for this question is:

  • D. Deep circumflex iliac

because it never even communicates with the superficial venous network (instead draining to the external iliac). The deep external pudendal does at least communicate with superficial veins before joining the femoral (but still not the GSV). So if you must pick a single “exception” as usually tested, it’s D.

141

In relation to the anatomy of the lateral ventricles of the brain, which of the following statements is correct?

A. The posterior horn is in the temporal lobe

B. The choroid plexus extends into the canal

C. The inferior horn is in the occipital lobe

D. The caudate nucleus is in the roof of the lateral ventricle

The correct answer is: D. The caudate nucleus is in the roof of the lateral ventricle

 

✅ Explanation of the Correct Answer:

  • The caudate nucleus, specifically its head and body, forms part of the lateral wall and roof of the anterior horn and body of the lateral ventricle.
  • It closely follows the curvature of the lateral ventricle, especially in the frontal lobe.

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

  • A. The posterior horn is in the temporal lobe
    → Incorrect: The posterior horn of the lateral ventricle extends into the occipital lobe, not the temporal lobe.
  • B. The choroid plexus extends into the canal
    → Incorrect: While the choroid plexus is found in parts of the lateral ventricles (mainly the body and inferior horn), it does not extend into the cerebral aqueduct or canal (likely referencing the cerebral aqueduct, which has no choroid plexus).
  • C. The inferior horn is in the occipital lobe
    → Incorrect: The inferior horn of the lateral ventricle extends into the temporal lobe, not the occipital lobe.

 

✅ Final Answer: D. The caudate nucleus is in the roof of the lateral ventricle

142

All the following ligaments in the knee joint are extra-capsular except?

A. Transverse ligament

B. Oblique popliteal ligament

C. Patellar ligament

D. Tibial collateral ligament

Option

Explanation

A

Correct (exception). The transverse ligament (anterior meniscal ligament) is located within the joint capsule, connecting the anterior horns of the medial and lateral menisci.

B

Incorrect. The oblique popliteal ligament is an extracapsular ligament reinforcing the posterior capsule.

C

Incorrect. The patellar ligament is extracapsular, connecting the patella to the tibial tuberosity.

D

Incorrect. The tibial (medial) collateral ligament lies outside the joint capsule along the medial side of the knee.

143

Which myotome is responsible for plantar flexion of the ankle?

A. L3-4

B. L2-3

C. L4-5

D. S1-2

Option

Explanation

A

L3–4: Incorrect. These roots mainly contribute to knee extension (quadriceps, L3–4) and hip adduction (L2–4), not plantar flexion.

B

L2–3: Incorrect. These roots are primarily involved in hip flexion (iliopsoas) and adduction, not ankle movements.

C
