L4–5: Incorrect. These roots contribute to ankle dorsiflexion (tibialis anterior, L4–5) and toe extension (extensor digitorum longus, L5), not plantar flexion.

D

S1–2: Correct. The triceps surae (gastrocnemius and soleus), which produce plantar flexion, are innervated by the tibial nerve carrying fibers from S1 (primary) and S2 (supporting). Thus, plantar flexion corresponds to the S1–S2 myotome.

144

Which of the following is an example of a secondary cartilaginous joint?

A. Intervertebral disc

B. Subtalar joint

C. Epiphyseal growth plate

D. Atlanto-axial joint

Option

Explanation

A

Correct. An intervertebral disc is a symphysis, classified as a secondary cartilaginous joint composed of fibrocartilage between vertebral bodies, allowing limited movement and providing shock absorption.

B

Incorrect. The subtalar joint (between the talus and calcaneus) is a synovial joint, not cartilaginous.

C

Incorrect. The epiphyseal growth plate is a primary cartilaginous joint (synchondrosis) made of hyaline cartilage; it is temporary and ossifies in adulthood.

D

Incorrect. The atlanto-axial joint is a synovial pivot joint between C1 and C2, permitting head rotation; it is not cartilaginous.

145

Which istrueregarding the right vagus and phrenic nerves and their relations in the superior mediastinum?

A. Right vagus nerve enter the superior mediastinum posterior to the sternoclavicular joint and common carotid artery

B. Right phrenic nerve enters the superior mediastinum between the brachiocephalic trunk and the origin of the brachiocepahlic vein

C. Right vagus nerve passes through the superior mediastinum to the right of the trachea, posterior to the right brachiocephalic vein, SVC and root of the right lung

D. Right phrenic nerve passes along the left side of the right brachiocepahlic vein, SVC and the pericardium over the right atrium

✅ Correct

  • The right vagus nerve runs:
    • Posterior to the right brachiocephalic vein
    • Posterior to the SVC
    • Posterior to the root of the right lung
    • And to the right of the trachea
  • It then gives off the right pulmonary plexus and continues into the esophageal plexus.

 

146

Regarding the acromio-clavicular joint, which of the following statements is correct?

A. No muscles connect the articulating bones to move the AC joint

B. AC joint is innervated by the lateral supraclavicular, medial pectoral and axillary nerve

C. The coracoid and the trapezoid ligaments make up the coracoclavicular ligamment

D. AC joint is supplied by the subscapular and thoracoacromial arteries

Option

Explanation

A

Correct. No muscle originates on one articulating bone and inserts on the other to directly move the AC joint; instead, axio‐appendicular muscles (e.g., trapezius, deltoid) move the scapula, causing the acromion to glide on the clavicle .

B

Incorrect. The AC joint is innervated by the lateral pectoral and axillary nerves, along with the cutaneous lateral supraclavicular nerve; it is not supplied by the medial pectoral nerve .

C

Incorrect. The coracoclavicular ligament is made up of the conoid and trapezoid ligaments (not “coracoid” and trapezoid) .

D

Incorrect. The AC joint is supplied by the suprascapular and thoracoacromial arteries, not the subscapular artery .

147

Regarding the relationship of the 4 parts of the duodenum, which is correct?

A. The third part lies at the hilum of the right kidney

B. The fourth part lies on the left psoas muscle and left sympathetic trunk, to reach the lower border of the spleen

C. The second part is covered in front by peritoneum and crossed by the attachment of the transverse mesocolon

D. The first part runs to the right, upwards and forwards form the pylorus

✅ Explanation of Each Option:

A. The third part lies at the hilum of the right kidney

  • ❌ Incorrect
  • The third (horizontal) part of the duodenum passes anterior to the aorta and inferior vena cava, at the level of L3, and lies inferior to the hilum of the right kidney, not at it.

B. The fourth part lies on the left psoas muscle and left sympathetic trunk, to reach the lower border of the spleen

  • ❌ Incorrect
  • The fourth (ascending) part of the duodenum ascends on the left side of the aorta to reach the duodenojejunal flexure, near L2, not the spleen (which is higher and more lateral).

C. The second part is covered in front by peritoneum and crossed by the attachment of the transverse mesocolon

  • ✅ Correct
  • The second (descending) part of the duodenum is retroperitoneal but has anterior peritoneal covering, and the transverse mesocolon is attached to it anteriorly, forming an important landmark.

D. The first part runs to the right, upwards and forwards from the pylorus

  • ❌ Incorrect
  • The first part of the duodenum runs posteriorly, upwards and to the right from the pylorus, not forwards.

 

 

148

Which of the following does not pass through the clavipectoral fascia?

A. Lymphatics

B. Thoracoacromial artery

C. Cephalic vein

D. Medial pectoral nerve

The medial pectoral nerve does not pierce the clavipectoral fascia. In Moore, the clavipectoral fascia is described as being pierced by the cephalic vein, thoracoacromial vessels, lateral pectoral nerve, and lymphatics – but not by the medial pectoral nerve.

149

In relation to the popliteal fossa, which of the following is correct?

A. The popliteal vein lies between the popliteal artery and tibial nerve

B. The infero-medial border is soleus muscle

C. The roof is formed by biceps femoris

D. The sural nerve branches from the common peroneal nerve only

Option

Explanation

A

Correct. In the popliteal fossa, from superficial to deep are the tibial nerve, popliteal vein, and popliteal artery—so the vein lies between artery and nerve.

B

Incorrect. The inferior border medially is formed by the medial head of gastrocnemius, not soleus.

C

Incorrect. The roof of the popliteal fossa is formed by skin and superficial and deep fascia; biceps femoris forms the superolateral border, not the roof.

D

Incorrect. The sural nerve arises from contributions of both the tibial nerve (medial sural cutaneous branch) and the common peroneal nerve (lateral sural cutaneous branch), not from the common peroneal nerve alone.

150

Which of the following statements regarding the mitral valve isCORRECT?

A. The mitral valve is located posterior to the sternum at the level of the 3rd costal cartilage

B. The mitral valve has two cusps, anterior and posterior.

C. The cusps receives tendinous cords from only one papillary muscle

D. The anterior cusp is weaker than the posterior cusp

Here's the detailed analysis for this cardiac anatomy MCQ:

 

Question: Which of the following statements regarding the mitral valve is CORRECT?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. The mitral valve is located posterior to the sternum at the level of the 3rd costal cartilage

❌ Incorrect

The mitral valve is located posterior to the left side of the sternum, but more accurately at the level of the 4th costal cartilage. The pulmonary valve lies near the 3rd costal cartilage.

B. The mitral valve has two cusps, anterior and posterior.

✅ Correct

This is the correct answer. The mitral valve is a bicuspid (two-leaflet) valve with an anterior cusp and a posterior cusp. It controls blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle.

C. The cusps receive tendinous cords from only one papillary muscle

❌ Incorrect

Each cusp of the mitral valve receives chordae tendineae from both the anterior and posterior papillary muscles. This dual support helps prevent valve prolapse during ventricular contraction.

D. The anterior cusp is weaker than the posterior cusp

❌ Incorrect

The anterior cusp is actually larger, thicker, and stronger than the posterior cusp. It plays a major role in sealing the valve during systole.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. The mitral valve has two cusps, anterior and posterior.

Let me know if you’d like a labeled diagram of the mitral valve or a comparison with other heart valves.

151

Which isfalsewith respect to the lateral intermuscular septum?

A. Pierced by middle collateral branch of profunda brachii artery

B. It is the origin of medial head of triceps

C. Pierced by radial nerve

D. Brachioradilais and extensor carpi radialis longus attach to the septum

 

Option

Status

Explanation

A

Incorrect

The lateral intermuscular septum is pierced by the radial collateral artery, not the middle collateral branch of the profunda brachii. The middle collateral descends in the posterior compartment and does not perforate the septum .

B

Incorrect

The medial head of the triceps originates from the posterior humerus below the radial groove, not from the lateral intermuscular septum. It lies deep to the long head and does not use the septum as its origin .

C

Correct

The radial nerve indeed pierces the lateral intermuscular septum near mid-humerus to enter the anterior compartment, traveling between brachialis and brachioradialis distal to the septum .

D

Correct

The brachioradialis and extensor carpi radialis longus arise, in part, from the lateral intermuscular septum (and adjacent lateral supracondylar ridge), confirming their attachment to that septum .

 

152

Regarding lymphatic drainage of the upper limb, which of the following statements is INCORRECT?

A. Superficial lymphatics follow arteries

B. Superficial lymphatic drainage passes from the palm to the dorsum of the hand

C. Deep lymphatics follow the veins

D. Some lymphatics of the hand drain into cubital lymph nodes

 

Option

Status

Explanation

A

Incorrect

In Moore’s description, superficial lymphatic vessels ascend mostly with the superficial veins (e.g., cephalic and basilic), not with arteries Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Correct

Figure 6.17 and accompanying text state that most drainage from the palm passes to the dorsum of the hand Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Correct

Moore specifies that deep lymphatic vessels accompany the major deep veins (radial, ulnar, and brachial) in the upper limb Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Correct

The text notes that some superficial lymphatic vessels accompanying the basilic vein enter the cubital lymph nodes (located proximal to the medial epicondyle) Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

153

Which of the following statements is correct in relation to the appendix?

A. Drains to inguinal nodes

B. Usually lies in a retroileal position

C. Has no mesentry

D. Opens into the caecum 2 cm below the ileocaecal valve

You're absolutely right to question that — let’s re-evaluate the options carefully with that in mind.

 

Question: Which of the following statements is correct in relation to the appendix?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Drains to inguinal nodes

❌ Incorrect

The appendix drains to ileocolic lymph nodes, not inguinal nodes. Inguinal nodes drain lower limb and superficial perineum, not abdominal viscera.

B. Usually lies in a retroileal position

❌ Incorrect

As you correctly pointed out, the most common position of the appendix is retrocecal, not retroileal. Retroileal is a variant, but not the usual location.

C. Has no mesentery

❌ Incorrect

The appendix does have a mesentery, called the mesoappendix, which contains its vascular supply (appendicular artery).

D. Opens into the caecum 2 cm below the ileocaecal valve

✅ Correct

This is anatomically accurate. The appendix opens into the posteromedial wall of the caecum, approximately 2 cm below the ileocecal valve — this is the correct and best-supported answer.

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Opens into the caecum 2 cm below the ileocaecal valve

Thanks for catching that — sharp observation! Let me know if you'd like a breakdown of appendix positions or lymphatic drainage maps.

154

Regarding the medulla oblongata, which of the following statements is correct?

A. Is largely within the middle cranial fossa

B. It is the part of the brainstem between the pons and spinal cord

C. Is supplied by anterior inferior cerebellar artery

D. Cranial nerves 8-12 arise from it

Here’s the detailed breakdown of your neuroanatomy MCQ on the medulla oblongata:

 

Question: Regarding the medulla oblongata, which of the following statements is correct?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Is largely within the middle cranial fossa

❌ Incorrect

The medulla oblongata is located in the posterior cranial fossa, not the middle. The middle cranial fossa contains the temporal lobes and related structures.

B. It is the part of the brainstem between the pons and spinal cord

✅ Correct

This is anatomically correct. The medulla oblongata lies inferior to the pons and superior to the spinal cord, forming the lowest part of the brainstem.

C. Is supplied by anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA)

❌ Incorrect

The AICA mainly supplies the lateral inferior pons. The medulla is supplied by the anterior spinal artery, posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), and vertebral arteries.

D. Cranial nerves 8–12 arise from it

❌ Incorrect

Only cranial nerves IX, X, XI, and XII arise from the medulla. CN VIII arises at the pontomedullary junction, technically associated with the pons. So this statement is slightly over-inclusive.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. It is the part of the brainstem between the pons and spinal cord

Let me know if you’d like a brainstem cross-section or cranial nerve emergence diagram for quick review!

155

Which part of the pelvis isleastlikely to be fractured in trauma?

A. Ilium alae

B. Body of the ilium

C. Pubic rami

D. Acetabulum

Option

Status

Explanation

A

Incorrect

Moore notes that the alae of the ilium are among the “weak areas of the pelvis, where fractures often occur” in trauma Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Correct

The body of the ilium is not listed among the common fracture sites. According to Moore, weak areas include the alae of the ilium, pubic rami, and acetabula; the body of the ilium remains relatively resistant to fracture Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Incorrect

The pubic rami are explicitly identified as a site where fractures commonly occur during anteroposterior compression of the pelvis in trauma Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Incorrect

The acetabulum (or the bone immediately surrounding it) is also listed as a frequent fracture site, especially when forces drive the femoral head into the pelvis Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

156

Which of the following is correct in relation to flexor digitorum profundus?

A. Is supplied, 10% of the time, purely by the median nerve

B. Assists pronator quadratus (PQ) in pronation

C. Is the strongest muscle of the forearm

D. Has its action enhanced by wrist flexion

 

Option

Status

Explanation

A

Incorrect

Moore describes that the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) is typically innervated by two nerves: the medial part (to digits 4 and 5) by the ulnar nerve, and the lateral part (to digits 2 and 3) by the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve. There is no mention that “10 % of the time” it is supplied purely by the median nerve; the standard dual‐innervation pattern applies .

B

Incorrect

The FDP flexes the distal interphalangeal joints of the fingers (and assists in flexion of the hand at the wrist), but it does not contribute to pronation of the forearm. Pronation is performed by pronator quadratus and pronator teres; FDP has no pronatory action .

C

Correct

While Moore does not explicitly label FDP as “the strongest” forearm muscle, it emphasizes that FDP is a very thick muscle that “clothes the anterior aspect of the ulna” and is uniquely capable of flexing the distal interphalangeal joints of the medial four fingers. Functionally, because FDP must generate enough force to flex all distal phalanges (especially under resistance), it is effectively the most powerful (strongest) flexor in the forearm .

D

Incorrect

Moore explains that when the wrist is flexed simultaneously with finger flexion, the long flexors (including FDP) are operating over a shortened length and thus produce a weaker grip. In contrast, extending the wrist increases their operating distance and makes their contractions more efficient. Therefore, FDP’s action is weakened, not enhanced, by wrist flexion .

 

157

Which of the following statements is false regarding the bony scapula?

A. The lateral angles bears the glenoid cavity

B. The scapula has three angles and three borders

C. The thick medial border lies adjacent to the coracoid

D. The subscapular fossa is found on the costal surface

 

 

Option

Status

Explanation

A

Correct

The lateral (axillary) angle of the scapula is the thickest part of the bone and bears the glenoid cavity, which articulates with the humeral head Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Correct

The scapula has three angles (superior, lateral, inferior) and three borders (superior, medial/vertebral, lateral/axillary) Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Incorrect

The medial border of the scapula is described as thin, running parallel to the vertebral column; it is not thick, nor does it lie adjacent to the coracoid process (which projects from the lateral aspect) .

D

Correct

The subscapular fossa is the large concave surface on the costal (anterior) aspect of the scapula, providing attachment for subscapularis; thus it is indeed on the costal surface Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

158

A patient is unable to abduct or flex their shoulder, and has sensory loss over the lateral aspect of their shoulder. Which nerve root is likely affected?

A. C6

B. C5

C. C7

D. C8

 

Thought for 9 seconds

Option

Status

Explanation

A (C6)

Incorrect

The C6 dermatome covers the lateral forearm and thumb, not the lateral shoulder. Lesion of C6 would impair wrist flexion/extension and sensation over the thumb, but not abduction or flexion of the shoulder. According to Moore’s dermatome map, C6 innervates the lateral forearm and thumb, rather than the lateral aspect of the arm (shoulder region) Moore - Clinically Orie….

B (C5)

Correct

The C5 root contributes the main motor fibers to the axillary nerve (which supplies the deltoid and teres minor) and to the suprascapular nerve (which supplies supraspinatus). Both deltoid (acrомial fibers) and supraspinatus are essential for initiating and maintaining abduction, and the anterior fibers of deltoid assist in flexion. A C5 lesion therefore abolishes shoulder abduction and flexion. Moreover, the superior lateral cutaneous branch of the axillary nerve (C5–6) supplies skin over the lateral shoulder; damage at the C5 root produces sensory loss in that region (lateral arm) .

C (C7)

Incorrect

The C7 dermatome covers the middle three fingers and the center of the posterior forearm. A C7 lesion typically impairs wrist and finger extension rather than shoulder movement, and sensation loss would be felt over the middle finger, not the lateral shoulder Moore - Clinically Orie….

D (C8)

Incorrect

The C8 dermatome spans the little finger and medial hand/forearm. Injury to C8 would affect finger flexion (particularly the medial two digits) and produce sensory loss along the ulnar side of the forearm and hand, not the lateral shoulder. It would not abolish shoulder abduction or flexion Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

159

Which of the following cranial nerves (Cn) has its nucleus outside the brainstem?

A. CN V

B. CN VII

C. CN X

D. CN XI

✅ Correct Answer: D. CN XI (Accessory nerve)

 

🧠 Explanation:

The spinal part of the accessory nerve (CN XI) is unique because its nucleus lies outside the brainstem, specifically in the cervical spinal cord (C1–C5 segments), within the anterior horn.

 

📌 CN XI Pathway:

  • Origin: Spinal accessory nucleus in the cervical spinal cord (not brainstem).
  • Fibers ascend through the foramen magnum → briefly enter the cranial cavity → exit skull via the jugular foramen → innervate:
    • Sternocleidomastoid
    • Trapezius

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

Option

Cranial Nerve

Nucleus Location

Why Incorrect

A. CN V

Trigeminal

Brainstem (pons & midbrain)

❌ Inside brainstem

B. CN VII

Facial

Brainstem (pons)

❌ Inside brainstem

C. CN X

Vagus

Medulla oblongata

❌ Inside brainstem

 

 

Would you like a summary table of all cranial nerves and their nuclei locations?

160

Which of the following statements is correct regarding the duodenum?

A. Is 25cm in length

B. Is a retro-peritoneal structure

C. Lies between the levels of L2-L4

D. In its 4th part, it lies to the right of the aorta

Option

Statement

True/False

Explanation

a)

The duodenum is a retroperitoneal structure

✅ True

The duodenum is mostly retroperitoneal, except the first 2 cm (duodenal cap) which is intraperitoneal. Overall, considered retroperitoneal.

b)

The duodenum is 25 cm long

✅ True

Standard anatomical length of the duodenum is ~25 cm (10 inches).

c)

It lies between the levels of L2–L4

❌ False

The duodenum spans L1 to L3 (not L4). The fourth part ends at L2 near the duodenojejunal flexure.

d)

Its fourth part lies to the right of the aorta

❌ False

The fourth part of the duodenum lies to the left of the aorta, ascending to the duodenojejunal flexure.

161

Which zone of the neck is most commonly injured following a penetrating trauma?

A. Zone II

B. Zone I

C. Zone III

D. Zone Ia

Here's the detailed breakdown for this surgical anatomy MCQ:

 

Question: Which zone of the neck is most commonly injured following a penetrating trauma?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Zone II

✅ Correct

Zone II (between cricoid cartilage and angle of mandible) is the most commonly injured zone in penetrating neck trauma. It's also the easiest to explore surgically, which is why injuries here are more frequently identified and treated.

B. Zone I

❌ Incorrect

Zone I (from clavicles/sternal notch to cricoid cartilage) contains major vessels and the apex of the lungs, but it's less commonly injured and harder to access surgically.

C. Zone III

❌ Incorrect

Zone III (from angle of mandible to base of skull) includes the distal carotid artery, salivary glands, and cranial nerves, but is less frequently involved in penetrating trauma.

D. Zone Ia

❌ Incorrect

There is no such zone as "Zone Ia" in standard neck trauma classification — possibly a distractor or confusion with lymph node levels.

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Zone II

 

📌 Quick Summary of Neck Zones (for Penetrating Trauma):

Zone

Boundaries

Structures

Zone I

Clavicle → Cricoid cartilage

Subclavian vessels, apex of lungs, trachea, esophagus

Zone II

Cricoid cartilage → Angle of mandible

Carotid arteries, jugular veins, trachea, esophagus, larynx

Zone III

Angle of mandible → Base of skull

Distal carotid, pharynx, cranial nerves IX–XII

Let me know if you'd like a diagram or a table comparing zones vs lymph node levels in the neck!

162

In a patient with Carpel Tunnel Syndrome, weakness will be evident in testing of which of the following muscles on examination?

A. Abductor Pollicis Longus

B. Abductor Pollicis Brevis

C. Flexor Pollicis Longus

D. Extensor Pollicis Longus

 

 

Option

Status

Explanation

A

Incorrect

Abductor pollicis longus (APL) is innervated by the posterior interosseous branch of the radial nerve, not the median nerve; carpal tunnel compression does not affect its function Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Correct

Abductor pollicis brevis (APB) is supplied by the recurrent branch of the median nerve, which passes through the carpal tunnel. In carpal tunnel syndrome, compression of the median nerve weakens or paralyzes the thenar muscles, including APB .

C

Incorrect

Flexor pollicis longus (FPL) is innervated by the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve in the forearm, proximal to the carpal tunnel. Its motor branch does not pass through the tunnel, so FPL function remains intact in carpal tunnel syndrome .

D

Incorrect

Extensor pollicis longus (EPL) is innervated by the posterior interosseous nerve (a branch of the radial nerve) and lies outside the carpal tunnel. Carpal tunnel compression does not impair EPL function .

 

163

Which is TRUE regarding the extracapsular ligaments of the knee?

A. The patellar ligament receives the medial and lateral retinacula

B. The arcuate popliteal ligament arises from the posterior aspect of the tibia

C. The tibial collateral is stronger than the fibular collateral ligament

D. The extracapsular ligaments of the knee comprise of 4 ligaments

 

Option

Status

Explanation

A

Correct

The patellar ligament “receives the medial and lateral patellar retinacula” (aponeurotic expansions of vastus medialis and lateralis) as it descends from the patella to the tibial tuberosity, reinforcing the joint capsule on each side of the patella Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Incorrect

The arcuate popliteal ligament arises from the posterior aspect of the fibular head, not the tibia, and spreads over the posterolateral capsule of the knee Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Incorrect

The tibial collateral ligament (medial collateral) is actually weaker than the fibular collateral ligament (lateral collateral) and is more often injured Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Incorrect

There are five extracapsular ligaments (patellar, fibular collateral, tibial collateral, oblique popliteal, and arcuate popliteal), not four Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

164

Which is not a branch of the axillary artery?

A. superior thoracic, 1st part

B. Thoraco-acromial, 2nd part

C. posterior circumflex humeral, 3rd part

D. Circumflex scapula, 3rd part

Option

Status

Explanation

A

Incorrect

The superior thoracic artery is indeed a branch of the first part of the axillary artery. Moore specifies that the first part gives off only the superior thoracic artery Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Incorrect

The thoraco-acromial artery arises from the second part of the axillary artery. Moore states that the second part gives off the thoraco-acromial (and lateral thoracic) arteries Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Incorrect

The posterior circumflex humeral artery is one of the branches of the third part of the axillary artery. Moore lists it alongside the anterior circumflex humeral and subscapular arteries Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Correct

The circumflex scapular artery is not a direct branch of the axillary artery but a branch of the subscapular artery (which itself is a branch of the third part). Moore explains that the subscapular divides into the circumflex scapular and thoracodorsal arteries .

 

165

The biceps femoris is innervation by which two nerves

A. Tibial division of sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2)

B. Sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2)

C. Fibular division of sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2)

D. Long head- fibular division and short head-tibial division of the sciatic nerve

 

Thought for 18 seconds

Option

Status

Explanation

A

Incorrect

This option names only the tibial division of the sciatic nerve. In reality, only the long head of biceps femoris is supplied by the tibial division (L5, S1, S2); the short head is supplied by the common fibular division. Thus, A is incomplete .

B

Incorrect

Referring simply to “sciatic nerve” is too general. Although both heads arise from the sciatic, they split into two distinct branches: the long head receives fibers from the tibial division, and the short head receives fibers from the common fibular division. Saying “sciatic nerve” does not convey this bifurcation .

C

Incorrect

This option names only the fibular (peroneal) division of the sciatic nerve. In reality, the short head is supplied by the fibular division (L5, S1, S2), but the long head comes from the tibial division. Therefore, C is incomplete .

D

Incorrect

Option D reverses the true pattern. The correct innervation is:

 

  • Long head → tibial division of the sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2)
  • Short head → common fibular division of the sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2)
    But D says “long head – fibular division” and “short head – tibial division,” which is exactly opposite . |

Correct innervation pattern (from Moore):

  • Long head of biceps femoris → tibial division of sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2)
  • Short head of biceps femoris → common fibular division of sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2) .

 

 

166

With respect to dermatomal nerve supply, which of the following is correct?

A. C7 supplies the index finger

B. The umbilicus is supplied by T12

C. The anterior axial line divides C6 and C7

D. T6 lies at level of the nipple

The correct answer is:

A. C7 supplies the index finger

Here’s the explanation based on dermatomal distributions:

  • C7: This dermatome includes the middle finger and may partially supply the index finger. The index finger is typically a border zone between C6 (thumb and lateral forearm) and C7. C7 is often considered to supply the index and middle fingers.
  • B. The umbilicus is supplied by T10, not T12.
  • C. The anterior axial line demarcates the border between dermatomes that do not overlap (e.g., C5 and T2), not between C6 and C7, which do overlap.
  • D. T4, not T6, is at the level of the nipple.

Thus, A is the most accurate statement according to Moore’s anatomyMoore - Clinically Orie….

167

Which of the following statements is correct with regard to the ureters?

A. They lie lateral to the transverse processes of the lumbar vertebrae

B. They are approximately 31 cm in length

C. An intact innervation of the ureter is not necessary for peristalsis

D. The pelvo-ureteric junction (PUJ) is the widest diameter

The correct answer is:

C. An intact innervation of the ureter is not necessary for peristalsis

Explanation based on Moore's Clinically Oriented Anatomy:

  • A. Incorrect: The ureters descend anterior to the psoas major muscle and lie medial, not lateral, to the transverse processes of the lumbar vertebrae.
  • B. Incorrect: The ureters are typically 25–30 cm long in adults, not 31 cm specifically.
  • C. Correct: Ureteric peristalsis is myogenic in origin and does not require intact innervation to continue. This means that peristalsis can persist even if neural connections are severed.
  • D. Incorrect: The pelvi-ureteric junction (PUJ) is one of the three natural constrictions of the ureter, but it is not the widest; it is actually one of the narrowest points along the ureter and is a common site for obstruction by kidney stones.

Thus, C is the accurate and correct choice based on the anatomical facts from MooreMoore - Clinically Orie….

168

A patient is noted to have a drop in their contralateral, unsupported hip when standing on one leg. Injury to which nerve could be responsible for this deficit?

A. Superior gluteal nerve

B. Inferior gluteal nerve

C. Femoral nerve

D. Obturator nerve

 

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Correct

Injury to the superior gluteal nerve causes paralysis of gluteus medius and minimus, which normally abduct the femur and stabilize the pelvis during single-leg stance. When these muscles are nonfunctional on the stance side, the contralateral pelvis drops (a positive Trendelenburg sign) .

B

Incorrect

The inferior gluteal nerve innervates gluteus maximus, which is a powerful hip extensor but not a primary pelvic stabilizer during single-leg stance. Lesion here impairs hip extension but does not cause contralateral pelvic drop .

C

Incorrect

The femoral nerve supplies anterior thigh muscles (iliopsoas, quadriceps) for hip flexion and knee extension. It does not innervate gluteus medius or minimus, so its injury does not result in a Trendelenburg sign .

D

Incorrect

The obturator nerve innervates medial thigh adductors and provides articular branches to the hip. It does not supply the abductors (gluteus medius/minimus), so its injury does not cause pelvic drop on single-leg stance .

 

169

Regarding triceps, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It is supplied by the radial nerve

B. The blood supply is from the posterior interosseous artery

C. It stabilises the shoulder in abduction resisting inferior dislocation.

D. It has two heads

 

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Correct

The triceps brachii is innervated by the radial nerve (C6, C7, C8). This is explicitly stated in Moore: “Triceps brachii … Innervation: Radial nerve (C6, C7, C8)” Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Incorrect

The main arterial supply to the triceps comes from the profunda brachii (deep artery of the arm), not the posterior interosseous artery. In Moore’s description of the posterior compartment, the profunda brachii accompanies the radial nerve in the radial groove to supply the triceps .

C

Incorrect

The long head of triceps does help resist inferior displacement of the humeral head by acting as a shunt muscle, but this function occurs when the shoulder is adducted, not abducted. Moore states: “Because its long head crosses the glenohumeral joint, the triceps helps stabilize the adducted glenohumeral joint by serving as a shunt muscle, resisting inferior displacement of the head of the humerus” .

D

Incorrect

The triceps brachii has three heads (long, lateral, and medial), not two. Moore clearly notes: “As indicated by its name, the triceps has three heads: long, lateral, and medial” .

 

170

Which structure passes directly behind the hilum of the right lung?

A. Right vagus nerve

B. Right phrenic nerve

C. Internal mammary artery

D. Hemi-azygous vein

✅ Correct Answer: A. Right vagus nerve

 

🧠 Explanation:

The hilum of the right lung is the entry/exit point for the bronchi, pulmonary vessels, lymphatics, and nerves. Various important structures pass either anterior or posterior to the hilum.

 

🔍 Relations of the Right Lung Hilum:

Position Relative to Hilum

Key Structures

Anterior

✅ Right phrenic nerve

✅ Pericardiacophrenic vessels

Posterior

✅ Right vagus nerve

✅ Azygos vein

✅ Posterior pulmonary plexus

Superior

✅ Arch of azygos vein (loops over root to join SVC)

 

 

❌ Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:

Option

Reason

B. Right phrenic nerve

Passes anterior to the hilum, along pericardium over right atrium

C. Internal mammary artery

Now called internal thoracic artery; stays anterior on thoracic wall, far from hilum

D. Hemiazygos vein

Lies on left side of vertebral column and drains into azygos vein; does not pass behind right hilum

 

 

✅ Therefore, the structure that passes directly behind the hilum of the right lung is the:

Right vagus nerve.

171

Which of the following arteries to not supply the duodenum?

A. Right gastroepiploic artery

B. Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery

C. Hepatic artery

D. Left gastric artery

The correct answer is: D. Left gastric artery

 

✅ Explanation:

The duodenum receives its blood supply from branches of both the celiac trunk and the superior mesenteric artery (SMA):

 

Arteries that supply the duodenum:

  • Superior pancreaticoduodenal artery
    → From the gastroduodenal artery (a branch of the common hepatic artery, which comes from the celiac trunk)
  • Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery
    → From the superior mesenteric artery (SMA)
  • Right gastroepiploic artery
    → Branch of the gastroduodenal artery; supplies part of the first part of the duodenum (indirectly via the pancreaticoduodenal arcade)
  • Common hepatic artery
    → Its branch (gastroduodenal artery) contributes to duodenal supply

 

Artery that does NOT supply the duodenum:

  • D. Left gastric artery ❌
    ✘ Supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach and the lower esophagus.
    ✘ It does not supply the duodenum.

 

Summary:

Artery

Supplies Duodenum?

Notes

Right gastroepiploic

✅ Yes

Indirectly via GDA branches

Inferior pancreaticoduodenal

✅ Yes

From SMA

Hepatic artery (via GDA)

✅ Yes

Supplies upper duodenum

Left gastric artery

❌ No

Stomach/esophagus only

Let me know if you'd like a diagram of the duodenal blood supply!

172

Which is true regarding the development of the cranium?

A. The sternocleidomastoid muscles help complete the development of the mastoid processes, which are absent at birth

B. Eruption of permanent teeth is complete by year 15.

C. The bones of the calvaria and cranial base develop by intramembranous ossification only

D. The two halves of the mandible at birth fuse by the 5th year of life

Here's a detailed breakdown of this MCQ on cranium development in table format:

Question

Which is true regarding the development of the cranium?

Options

Evaluation

A. The sternocleidomastoid muscles help complete the development of the mastoid processes, which are absent at birth

✅ Correct – This is true. The mastoid processes are not present at birth; they develop postnatally as the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscles pull on that region of the temporal bone, stimulating growth.

B. Eruption of permanent teeth is complete by year 15.

❌ Incorrect – This is partially true but not entirely accurate. Most permanent teeth (except third molars) erupt by about 12–13 years, but third molars ("wisdom teeth") may erupt between 17–25 years, or may not erupt at all. Hence, eruption is not complete by age 15 for most individuals.

C. The bones of the calvaria and cranial base develop by intramembranous ossification only

❌ Incorrect – This is a misstatement. While calvarial bones (e.g., frontal, parietal) develop via intramembranous ossification, the cranial base develops through endochondral ossification. So both ossification types are involved.

D. The two halves of the mandible at birth fuse by the 5th year of life

❌ Incorrect – The two halves of the mandible typically fuse at the symphysis menti within the first year of life, usually by 6–9 months, not as late as the 5th year.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: A

Let me know if you'd like the next question analyzed or want a focused review on head and neck development.

173

Which is true about the axillary artery?

A. The thoraco-acromial branch is the largest of the branches of the axillary artery

B. The axillary vein lies distally on the anterolateral side of the artery

C. Is a continuation of the subclavian as it passes under the medial 1/3 of clavicle

D. Becomes the brachial artery at the inferior border of teres major

 

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

The thoraco-acromial artery is one of two branches of the second part of the axillary artery, but it is not the largest branch overall. The largest branch of the axillary artery is the subscapular artery, which arises from the third part and has the greatest diameter of any branch .

B

Incorrect

The axillary vein lies anteromedial to the axillary artery, not anterolateral. Specifically, it lies initially (distally) on the anteromedial side of the artery, with its terminal part antero‐inferior to the artery .

C

Incorrect

The axillary artery is the direct continuation of the subclavian artery, but this occurs as it crosses the lateral border of the first rib—not under the medial third of the clavicle. It begins at the lateral border of the first rib, medial to pectoralis minor Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Correct

The axillary artery extends from the lateral border of the first rib to the inferior border of teres major, at which point it becomes the brachial artery. This transition is described in Moore’s text: “...the third part of the axillary artery extends from the lateral border of pectoralis minor to the inferior border of teres major, where it becomes the brachial artery” .

 

174

The dermatome that typically involves the medial knee?

A. L3

B. L2

C. L4

D. L5

 

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Correct

The L3 dermatome covers the medial aspect of the knee. In Figure 5.17 (Foerster’s map), the zone labeled L3 is centered over the medial femoral condyle and the area just below the knee on its medial side Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Incorrect

The L2 dermatome lies proximal to the knee, covering the anterior and medial thigh above the level of the knee, not the medial knee itself Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Incorrect

The L4 dermatome extends over the medial leg and medial foot, down from just below the knee, but does not include the medial knee; it begins distal to that region Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Incorrect

The L5 dermatome covers the dorsum of the foot and the lateral aspect of the leg, not the medial knee; it is located distal and lateral to the knee region Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

175

What is the least mobile part of the uterus?

A. Fundus

B. Cervix

C. Body

D. Isthmus

Here's the detailed breakdown for this gynecological anatomy MCQ:

 

Question: What is the least mobile part of the uterus?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Fundus

❌ Incorrect

The fundus is the most superior and mobile part of the uterus. It moves freely with bladder and bowel filling and is commonly palpated during pregnancy.

B. Cervix

✅ Correct

The cervix is the least mobile part of the uterus. It is firmly anchored to surrounding structures by ligaments (e.g. cardinal and uterosacral ligaments) and connects directly with the vagina, limiting its mobility.

C. Body

❌ Incorrect

The body of the uterus is relatively mobile, especially during filling of adjacent pelvic organs and pregnancy. It moves with changes in bladder volume.

D. Isthmus

❌ Incorrect

The isthmus is the narrow region between the body and cervix. While it is less mobile than the fundus, it is not as fixed as the cervix.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Cervix

Let me know if you’d like a diagram of uterine support structures or the clinical implications of uterine mobility (e.g. prolapse).

176

Which of the following is incorrect regarding the lateral intermuscular septum?

A. It has brachioradialis as an anterior relation

B. Medial head of triceps arises from it

C. It is pierced by the median nerve

D. It extends along the lateral suprachondylar line and fades out behind the insertion of the deltoid

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Correct

The lateral intermuscular septum lies deep to the brachioradialis, which originates from the lateral supracondylar ridge and adjacent septum. Thus, brachioradialis is indeed an anterior relation to the septum .

B

Correct

The medial head of the triceps originates from the posterior humeral shaft, but fibers immediately adjacent to the lateral septum use it as part of their proximal attachment. In other words, part of the medial head’s origin lies on the posterior surface of the humerus and the adjacent lateral septum .

C

Incorrect

The lateral intermuscular septum is pierced by the radial nerve, not the median nerve. After winding around the humerus in the radial groove, the radial nerve perforates the lateral septum to enter the anterior compartment; the median nerve remains on the medial side and does not penetrate this septum .

D

Correct

The septum attaches along the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus and fades out posteriorly just behind the deltoid’s insertion. This reflects its proximal-to-distal course along the ridge before blending with the deep fascia beneath the deltoid insertion .

 

 

177

What is the primary movement that occurs at the sub-talar joint?

A. Inversion and eversion

B. Flexion and extension

C. Flexion and inversion

D. Eversion and extension

 

Thought for 4 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Correct

The subtalar (talocalcaneal) joint is a plane synovial joint whose primary movements are inversion and eversion of the foot .

B

Incorrect

Flexion and extension occur primarily at the ankle (talocrural) joint, not the subtalar joint. The subtalar joint’s main motions are inversion and eversion Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Incorrect

Although inversion is a motion of the subtalar joint, flexion (plantarflexion/dorsiflexion) takes place at the ankle joint. The subtalar joint does not produce flexion Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Incorrect

Eversion is a function of the subtalar joint, but extension (dorsiflexion/plantarflexion) happens at the ankle joint. The subtalar joint does not generate extension movements Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

178

Which of the following is not a branch of the common peroneal nerve?

A. Lateral cutaneous nerve of the calf

B. Superior genicular

C. Recurrent genicular

D. Medial sural cutaneous nerve

 

Thought for 12 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

The lateral cutaneous nerve of the calf (lateral sural cutaneous nerve) is indeed a branch of the common peroneal nerve. It descends from the common fibular division of the sciatic nerve and supplies skin over the posterolateral leg Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Incorrect

There is no “superior genicular” nerve arising directly from the common peroneal nerve. The common peroneal’s articular branch to the knee is typically called the recurrent genicular (or articular) branch, not a “superior genicular” nerve. Thus, “superior genicular” does not represent a recognized branch of the common peroneal nerve Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Incorrect

The recurrent genicular (articular) nerve that supplies the knee joint originates from the common peroneal nerve as it winds around the neck of the fibula. This branch is commonly termed the recurrent genicular branch and provides innervation to the knee capsule Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Correct

The medial sural cutaneous nerve arises from the tibial nerve—not the common peroneal. In the popliteal fossa, the medial sural cutaneous branch of the tibial nerve joins the sural communicating branch from the common peroneal to form the sural nerve. Therefore, the medial sural cutaneous is not a branch of the common peroneal nerve Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

 

179

Shoulder stability in abduction is due to which of the following?

A. The glenohumeral ligaments

B. The glenoid labrum

C. The musculotendinous cuff of the rotator cuff muscles

D. The pectoralis major muscle insertion

 

Thought for 8 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

The glenohumeral ligaments reinforce the anterior capsule of the shoulder joint but are relatively lax when the arm is abducted. As Moore explains, these ligaments “radiate laterally and inferiorly from the glenoid labrum … blending with the fibrous layer of the capsule” Moore - Clinically Orie…. However, they do not provide the primary active stabilization when the arm is held in abduction; rather, their tension becomes most relevant at extremes of rotation and when the joint is threatened by inferior or anterior displacement.

B

Incorrect

The glenoid labrum is a fibrocartilaginous rim that deepens the glenoid cavity, modestly increasing passive stability of the humeral head within the socket Moore - Clinically Orie…. While it contributes to joint congruence, it does not actively stabilize the shoulder during abduction; passive glenoid depth alone is insufficient to hold the head of the humerus in place when the arm is elevated.

C

Correct

The musculotendinous cuff formed by the rotator cuff muscles (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, and subscapularis) exerts a compressive force that “holds the relatively large head of the humerus in the much smaller and shallow glenoid cavity of the scapula,” providing dynamic stabilization throughout abduction Moore - Clinically Orie…. As the arm is raised, these SITS muscles maintain joint integrity by pulling the humeral head medially and resisting translations.

D

Incorrect

Although pectoralis major functions powerfully in adduction and medial rotation of the humerus, its insertion on the lateral lip of the intertubercular sulcus does not contribute to stabilizing the shoulder during abduction. This muscle’s primary role is generating force for movements of the humerus, not maintaining the humeral head within the glenoid when the arm is held overhead Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

180

Which synovial joint and its movements areINCORRECT?

A. Saddle joints: Flexion, extension, abduction and adduction.

B. Plane joints: gliding and sliding movements

C. Hinge joints: Flexion and extension only

D. Condyloid joints: Flexion, extension, medial and lateral rotation

 

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

Saddle joints are biaxial and permit flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction, as well as limited circumduction. Moore states: “Saddle joints permit abduction and adduction as well as flexion and extension, movements occurring around two axes at right angles to each other; thus saddle joints are biaxial joints” .

B

Incorrect

Plane joints allow gliding or sliding movements. Moore describes: “Plane joints permit gliding or sliding movements in the plane of the articular surfaces” Moore - Clinically Orie…. Thus B’s statement is correct regarding plane joints.

C

Incorrect

Hinge joints permit flexion and extension only (uniaxial), as Moore explains: “Hinge joints permit flexion and extension only, movements that occur in one plane (sagittal) around a single axis that runs transversely; thus hinge joints are uniaxial joints” Moore - Clinically Orie…. Therefore, C’s description is accurate.

D

Correct

Condyloid (ellipsoid) joints allow flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, and circumduction, but they do not permit true medial or lateral rotation. Moore specifies: “Condyloid joints permit flexion and extension as well as abduction and adduction; thus condyloid joints are also biaxial. … Circumduction, more restricted than that of saddle joints, is also possible” Moore - Clinically Orie…. Since medial and lateral rotation are not among the permitted movements, D is incorrect.

 

181

All of the following are branches of the femoral artery except?

A. Superficial circumflex iliac

B. Obturator

C. Profunda femoris

D. Superficial epigastric

 

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

The superficial circumflex iliac artery arises from the proximal anterior aspect of the femoral artery, running in the subcutaneous tissue along the inguinal ligament. It supplies the superficial abdominal wall and adjacent anterior thigh .

B

Correct

The obturator artery is not a branch of the femoral artery. Instead, it usually originates from the internal iliac artery (or, in about 20% of individuals, from the inferior epigastric as an accessory obturator). It passes through the obturator foramen to enter the medial thigh .

C

Incorrect

The profunda femoris (deep artery of the thigh) is the largest branch of the femoral artery, arising 1–5 cm inferior to the inguinal ligament. It courses posterior to adductor longus and gives off perforating branches to the posterior and medial thigh compartments .

D

Incorrect

The superficial epigastric artery also arises from the anterior aspect of the proximal femoral artery and ascends in the subcutaneous tissue toward the umbilicus, supplying the superficial abdominal wall .

 

182

Regarding tibialis anterior, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It arises from the upper two thirds of the fibula

B. It platarflexes and everts the foot

C. It inserts into the medial cuneiform and the adjacent first metatarsal bone

D. It shares its site of insertion with peroneus tertius

 

Thought for 9 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

Tibialis anterior originates from the lateral condyle and superior half of the lateral surface of the tibia, along with the interosseous membrane; it does not arise from the fibula. Moore - Clinically Orie…

B

Incorrect

Tibialis anterior dorsiflexes the ankle and inverts the foot. It does not plantarflex or evert. Moore - Clinically Orie…

C

Correct

Its distal attachment is on the medial and inferior surfaces of the medial cuneiform and base of the first metatarsal. Moore - Clinically Orie…

D

Incorrect

Peroneus tertius inserts on the dorsum of the base of the fifth metatarsal, not on the medial cuneiform or first metatarsal. Therefore, it does not share an insertion site with tibialis anterior. Moore - Clinically Orie…

 

183

Which ligament prevents anterior rolling of the femur on the extended knee?

A. Posterior cruciate ligamen

B. Anterior cruciate ligament

C. Medial collateral ligament

D. Lateral collateral ligament

 

 

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Correct

The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) limits anterior rolling of the femur on the tibial plateau during knee extension, converting that motion into a spin. Moore states: “The PCL limits anterior rolling of the femur on the tibial plateau during extension, converting it to spin” .

B

Incorrect

The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) prevents posterior rolling of the femoral condyles on the tibial plateau during flexion and also prevents hyperextension, but it does not limit anterior rolling during extension. Moore notes: “The ACL limits posterior rolling (turning and traveling) of the femoral condyles on the tibial plateau during flexion, converting it to spin” .

C

Incorrect

The medial collateral ligament (MCL) resists valgus forces and stabilizes the medial side of the knee, but it does not control the sagittal-plane rolling of the femur. It does not prevent anterior rolling of the femur during extension Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Incorrect

The lateral collateral ligament (LCL) stabilizes the lateral side of the knee against varus forces; it does not influence anterior–posterior rolling of the femur. Thus, it does not prevent anterior rolling during knee extension Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

184

Which of the following structures are not involved in the control of posture and movement?

A. Lateral reticulo-spinal tract

B. Tractus solitarius

C. Vestibulo-spinal tract

D. Spino-cerebellar tracts

Here’s a detailed breakdown of this neuroanatomy MCQ on posture and movement control:

Question

Which of the following structures are not involved in the control of posture and movement?

Options

Evaluation

A. Lateral reticulo-spinal tract

❌ Incorrect – This is involved in posture and movement. It originates from the reticular formation and facilitates voluntary movements and muscle tone, especially in axial and proximal limb muscles.

B. Tractus solitarius

✅ Correct – The tractus solitarius (solitary tract) is primarily involved in visceral sensory functions, especially related to taste, baroreception, and chemoreception. It plays no direct role in posture or movement control.

C. Vestibulo-spinal tract

❌ Incorrect – This tract is critically involved in maintaining balance and posture, via input from the vestibular nuclei, helping adjust muscle tone in response to head position and movement.

D. Spino-cerebellar tracts

❌ Incorrect – These tracts relay proprioceptive information from the body to the cerebellum, which uses that input to coordinate movement and maintain posture.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Tractus solitarius

Let me know if you'd like to continue with more neuro or expand into related systems.

185

Regarding the deep fascia, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It passes freely over bone

B. It allows for muscle expansion

C. It is absent in the face

D. It Is a dense, organised layer of tissue containing fat

The correct answer is:

C. It is absent in the face

Explanation from Moore's Clinically Oriented Anatomy:

  • A. Incorrect: Deep fascia does not pass freely over bone; where it contacts bone, it blends firmly with the periosteum.
  • B. Incorrect: Deep fascia limits rather than allows muscle expansion. It helps compress muscles, aiding venous return (e.g. in the musculovenous pump).
  • C. Correct: Distinct layers of deep fascia are absent in the face, which allows for the mobility of facial muscles used in expression.
  • D. Incorrect: Deep fascia is a dense, organized connective tissue but is devoid of fat—this distinguishes it from subcutaneous tissue (superficial fascia), which contains fat.

Thus, C is the correct statement regarding deep fasciaMoore - Clinically Orie….

186

Regarding the radial nerve which of the following statements isINCORRECT?

A. The radial nerve is the largest branch of the brachial plexus

B. The radial nerve is a continuation of the posterior cord of the brachial plexus

C. It crosses the lower border of the posterior axillary wall lying on the tendon of lattisimus dorsi

D. It passes through the quadrangular space into the upper arm

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Correct

The radial nerve is indeed the largest terminal branch of the brachial plexus, arising from the posterior cord and containing fibers from C5–T1. Moore states: “Radial: larger terminal branch of posterior cord (largest branch of plexus), receiving fibers from C5–T1” Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Correct

The radial nerve is a direct continuation of the posterior cord of the brachial plexus. This is affirmed by Moore’s description: “Radial nerve … larger terminal branch of posterior cord” Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Correct

As it exits the axilla, the radial nerve crosses the inferior border of the posterior axillary wall by passing over the tendon of latissimus dorsi (which forms part of that wall). Moore describes the posterior wall of the axilla as including latissimus dorsi and shows the radial nerve in close relation to this tendon as it leaves the axilla .

D

Incorrect

The radial nerve does not pass through the quadrangular space; that space transmits the axillary nerve (with the posterior circumflex humeral artery). Instead, the radial nerve exits the axilla via the triangular interval, then descends in the posterior compartment of the arm. Moore specifies that the axillary nerve (not radial) traverses the quadrangular space .

 

187

Which nerve supplies the pinna of the ear?

A. Facial nerve

B. Vagus nerve

C. Mandibular nerve

D. Maxillary nerve

Explanation:

The pinna (auricle) of the ear has a complex sensory innervation involving multiple nerves, but among the options listed, the facial nerve (CN VII) does supply part of the pinna, specifically via its posterior auricular branch.

 

Option

Reason

B. Vagus nerve

Supplies concha and auditory canal (not main supply to pinna)

C. Mandibular nerve (V₃)

Gives off auriculotemporal nerve → anterior ear, but not the main pinna supplier

D. Maxillary nerve (V₂)

Does not supply the ear at all

 

 

188

Regarding the coronary arteries, which of the following statements is correct?

A. 50% of atrio-ventricular (AV) nodes are supplied by the right coronary artery

B. The right coronary artery has a posterior interventricular branch

C. 40% of sino-atrial (SA) nodes are supplied by the right coronary artery

D. The circumflex is the artery most affected by disease

The correct answer is:

B. The right coronary artery has a posterior interventricular branch

Explanation from Moore's Clinically Oriented Anatomy:

  • A. Incorrect: Approximately 80% of AV nodes are supplied by the right coronary artery (RCA), not 50%.
  • B. Correct: The right coronary artery (RCA) typically gives rise to the posterior interventricular branch (also known as the posterior descending artery or PDA) in a right-dominant heart (which occurs in ~70% of people).
  • C. Incorrect: The SA node is supplied by the RCA in ~60% of individuals, not 40%.
  • D. Incorrect: The left anterior descending (LAD) artery, a branch of the left coronary artery, is the artery most commonly affected by coronary artery disease, not the circumflex.

Therefore, B is the correct and most accurate statement.

189

Which structures passes through the foramen spinosum

A. Internal carotid artery

B. Facial nerve

C. Mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve

D. Middle meningeal artery

✅ Correct Answer: D. Middle meningeal artery

 

🧠 Explanation:

The foramen spinosum, a small opening in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone, transmits:

Structure

Function

✅ Middle meningeal artery

Major arterial supply to the dura mater

✅ Middle meningeal vein

Venous drainage of the meninges

✅ Meningeal branch of CN V₃ (nervus spinosus)

Sensory innervation to the dura

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

Option

Reason

A. Internal carotid artery

Passes through the carotid canal, not foramen spinosum

B. Facial nerve (CN VII)

Passes through internal acoustic meatus → stylomastoid foramen

C. Mandibular nerve (CN V₃)

Passes through the foramen ovale, not spinosum

 

📌 Mnemonic:

"Spiny artery spins through spinosum"

(to remember middle meningeal artery → foramen spinosum)

Let me know if you'd like a full chart of skull foramina and their contents!

190

The axillary sheath is an extension of which of the following fascia ?

A. Brachial fascia

B. Cervical fascia

C. Axillary fascia

D. Deltoid fascia

 

Thought for 10 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

The axillary sheath is not an extension of the brachial fascia. Instead, the brachial fascia is a deep fascia of the arm that is continuous with the deltoid, pectoral, and axillary fascias, but it does not form the protective sleeve around the neurovascular bundle in the axilla.

B

Correct

The axillary sheath is a lateral continuation of the prevertebral layer of deep cervical fascia. Moore describes that the prevertebral fascia “extends laterally as the axillary sheath, which surrounds the axillary vessels and brachial plexus” .

C

Incorrect

The axillary fascia forms the floor of the axilla (the skin and subcutaneous tissue covering) but does not itself envelop the axillary vessels and cords; that role is performed by the axillary sheath derived from cervical (prevertebral) fascia.

D

Incorrect

The deltoid fascia invests the deltoid muscle and is continuous with pectoral and infraspinous fascias, but it does not contribute to the axillary sheath. The sheath is derived from the deep cervical fascia, not from the superficial deltoid fascia.

 

191

Which of the following muscles causes inversion of the foot?

A. Peroneus brevis

B. Extensor halliucis brevis

C. Tibialis posterior

D. Peroneus tertius

 

Thought for 11 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

Peroneus (fibularis) brevis is located in the lateral compartment of the leg and functions as an evertor of the foot (it depresses the lateral margin of the foot and resists inversion), not an invertor Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Incorrect

Extensor hallucis brevis’s primary action is to aid in extending the great toe at the metatarsophalangeal joint; it does not participate in inversion or eversion of the foot Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Correct

Tibialis posterior is the key invertor of the foot; it inverts (and also plantarflexes) by pulling the plantar surface medially. Table 5.13.II in Moore’s Anatomy lists “inverts foot” as one of its main actions Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Incorrect

Peroneus (fibularis) tertius inserts on the dorsum of the base of the 5th metatarsal and acts as a weak dorsiflexor and evertor of the foot, not as an invertor Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

192

Which of the following statements is false in relation to latissimus dorsi?

A. Arises from spinous processes of T5 to L5

B. Arises from the posterior third of the iliac crest

C. Internally rotates the humerus

D. Inserts into intertubecular groove of humerus

 

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

Moore states that latissimus dorsi originates from the spinous processes of T7–T12 (inferior six thoracic vertebrae), not from T5 to L5 Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Correct

The muscle arises from the iliac crest (specifically its posterior part) as part of its proximal attachments, as noted by Moore: “Spinous processes of inferior 6 thoracic vertebrae, thoracolumbar fascia, iliac crest, and inferior 3 or 4 ribs” Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Correct

One of latissimus dorsi’s main actions is medial (internal) rotation of the humerus. Moore lists “extends, adducts, and medially rotates humerus” among its functions Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Correct

Distally, the muscle inserts into the floor of the intertubercular sulcus (groove) of the humerus, which lies between the greater and lesser tubercles. Moore describes the distal attachment as “Floor of intertubercular sulcus of humerus” Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

193

The posterior triangle of the neck contains all of the following except?

A. Accessory nerve

B. cervical lymph nodes

C. Cervical plexus

D. Superior belly of omohyoid

 

194

Why do patients receiving epidural anaesthesia develop headache less frequently than with spinal anaesthesia?

A. Fibrillar meshwork surrounding the dura mater absorbs epidural substance

B. The arachnoid does not extend to the level at which an epidural is undertaken

C. The dura mater is impermeable at the level of an epidural

D. The epidural space ends at the foramen magnum
    • Spinal anaesthesia = intentional dural puncture → CSF leak → ↓ CSF pressure → postural headache
    • Epidural anaesthesia = dura usually intact → much lower risk of headache

195

Which is true regarding the aortic arch and its relations?

A. Ligamentum venosum connects the left pulmonary artery to the aortic arch

B. The aortic arch becomes the descending aorta at the level of T4

C. The trachea lies behind and to the left of the aortic arch.

D. The bifurcation of the pulmonary artery and the right main bronchus are found at the level of the arch

Here's the detailed analysis of this MCQ on aortic arch and its relations:

Question

Which is true regarding the aortic arch and its relations?

Options

Evaluation

A. Ligamentum venosum connects the left pulmonary artery to the aortic arch

❌ Incorrect – The ligamentum arteriosum (not venosum) connects the left pulmonary artery to the aortic arch. The ligamentum venosum is a remnant of the fetal ductus venosus and is related to the liver, not the aortic arch.

B. The aortic arch becomes the descending aorta at the level of T4

✅ Correct – The aortic arch ends and continues as the descending thoracic aorta at the level of the lower border of T4, typically at the sternal angle (Angle of Louis).

C. The trachea lies behind and to the left of the aortic arch

❌ Incorrect – The trachea lies posterior and to the right of the aortic arch. The arch curves over the left main bronchus and the left side of the trachea.

D. The bifurcation of the pulmonary artery and the right main bronchus are found at the level of the arch

❌ Incorrect – These structures lie below the level of the aortic arch. The pulmonary artery bifurcation is around the T5–T6 level. The right main bronchus lies below and posterior to the arch.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. The aortic arch becomes the descending aorta at the level of T4

Let me know if you'd like a labeled diagram or memory aids for thoracic anatomy relations.

196

Which nerve supplies sensation to the dorsum of the foot, between the 1st and 2nd toes?

A. Superficial fibular nerve

B. Tibial nerve

C. Deep fibular nerve

D. Saphenous nerve

 

Thought for 11 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

The superficial fibular (peroneal) nerve supplies most of the skin on the dorsum of the foot but explicitly excludes the web space between the 1st and 2nd toes .

B

Incorrect

The tibial nerve (and its branches) supplies the plantar (sole) aspect of the foot and does not provide cutaneous innervation to the dorsum between the 1st and 2nd toes Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Correct

The deep fibular (peroneal) nerve innervates a small area of skin on the dorsum of the foot—specifically the interdigital cleft between the 1st and 2nd toes .

D

Incorrect

The saphenous nerve supplies the medial side of the foot (as far anteriorly as the head of the 1st metatarsal), not the web space between the 1st and 2nd toes on the dorsum Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

197

Which part of the heart does the right coronary artery NOT SUPPLY?

A. The right atrium

B. Most of the right ventricle

C. Usually the posterior third of the interventricular septum

D. The posterior inferior surface of the left ventricle

The correct answer is: D. The posterior inferior surface of the left ventricle

 

Explanation (based on Moore's Clinically Oriented Anatomy):

The right coronary artery (RCA) typically supplies:

  • ✅ Right atrium
  • ✅ Most of the right ventricle
  • ✅ Part of the left ventricle (diaphragmatic surface)
  • ✅ The SA node (in about 60% of people)
  • ✅ The AV node (in about 80% of people)
  • ✅ The posterior third of the interventricular septum (via the posterior interventricular branch in right-dominant circulation)Moore - Clinically Orie….

However:

  • ❌ The posterior inferior surface of the left ventricle is mainly supplied by the circumflex branch of the left coronary artery (LCA), especially in left-dominant or co-dominant coronary circulationMoore - Clinically Orie….

 

✅ Therefore, the RCA does not typically supply the posterior inferior surface of the left ventricle — D is correct.

198

Regarding dermatomes which of the following statements is correct?

A. dermatome is the area of skin and muscle supplied by a single spinal nerve

B. They do not overlap in the chest

C. They overlap at axial lines

D. dermatome is separated from a discontinuous segment of the spinal cord by an axial line

Let's break down each statement regarding dermatomes:

  • A. Dermatome is the area of skin and muscle supplied by a single spinal nerve1
    This statement is incorrect. A dermatome is specifically the area of skin supplied by a single spinal nerve.2 The muscle supply by a single spinal nerve (or more accurately, by the motor fibers of a single spinal nerve root) is referred to as a myotome.3
  • B. They do not overlap in the chest
    This statement is incorrect. Dermatomes do overlap significantly in the chest, and in fact, throughout the trunk and limbs. This overlap is clinically important because it means that if one spinal nerve is damaged, there isn't a complete loss of sensation in its corresponding dermatome; adjacent dermatomes can often provide some sensory innervation to the area.4
  • C. They overlap at axial lines
    This statement is incorrect. Axial lines are areas where there is no overlap between dermatomes.5 Instead, axial lines mark a sharp transition between the sensory supply of non-adjacent spinal nerves, meaning there's a skip in the dermatome sequence across these lines. For example, the axial line in the upper limb separates areas supplied by cervical dermatomes from those supplied by thoracic dermatomes.
  • D. Dermatome is separated from a discontinuous segment of the spinal cord by an axial line
    This statement is correct. Axial lines represent areas where there's an abrupt change in the sensory innervation, essentially skipping over intervening dermatomes. This means that a dermatome (e.g., C5) might be adjacent to another dermatome (e.g., T2) across an axial line, even though C6, C7, C8, and T1 dermatomes are "skipped" along that specific boundary. This concept is fundamental to understanding dermatome maps and clinical presentations of nerve damage.

The final answer is D​

199

All the following are branches of the external carotid except?

A. Facial artery

B. Lingual artery

C. Ascending pharyngeal artery

D. Hypoglossal artery

The correct answer is: D. Hypoglossal artery

 

🧠 Explanation:

Let’s review each option:

Option

Branch of External Carotid?

Details

A. Facial artery

✅ Yes

Anterior branch of the external carotid; supplies face

B. Lingual artery

✅ Yes

Anterior branch; supplies tongue and floor of mouth

C. Ascending pharyngeal artery

✅ Yes

Medial branch; small but consistent; supplies pharynx and prevertebral muscles

D. Hypoglossal artery

❌ No

This is not a normal branch of the external carotid; rather, the hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) is often confused with it. Rarely, an anomalous artery called the "persistent hypoglossal artery" (from the internal carotid) exists embryologically, but this is not a standard branch in normal adult anatomy

 

✅ Therefore, the Hypoglossal artery is NOT a branch of the external carotid artery.

200

Which lobe of the brain is responsible for processing sense of smell?

A. Frontal lobe

B. Temporal lobe

C. Pituitary gland

D. Occipital cortex

Here's the detailed breakdown for this neuroanatomy MCQ:

 

Question: Which lobe of the brain is responsible for processing sense of smell?

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A. Frontal lobe

❌ Incorrect

While the olfactory bulb and tract run along the inferior frontal lobe, actual processing of smell occurs elsewhere, mainly in the temporal lobe. The frontal lobe is more involved in higher cognitive functions.

B. Temporal lobe

✅ Correct

The primary olfactory cortex is located in the medial temporal lobe, specifically in the uncus and piriform cortex. This region processes smell signals from the olfactory bulb.

C. Pituitary gland

❌ Incorrect

The pituitary gland is an endocrine organ, not involved in sensory processing. It lies inferior to the hypothalamus and has no role in olfaction.

D. Occipital cortex

❌ Incorrect

The occipital lobe is dedicated to visual processing, not smell.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Temporal lobe

Would you like a diagram showing the olfactory pathway or a table comparing sensory cortex locations by modality?

201

Which fascia encloses the retropharyngeal space anteriorly?

A. Buccopharyngeal fascia

B. Deep cervical fascia

C. Alar fascia

D. Investing fascia

 

202

A patient is unable to remove a food bolus from their cheek. Which nerve is likely damaged?

A. Vagus

B. Trigeminal

C. Facial

D. Hypoglossal

✅ Correct Answer: C. Facial nerve (CN VII)

 

🧠 Explanation:

  • The buccinator muscle is responsible for compressing the cheek, which helps keep food between the teeth during chewing.
  • It is innervated by the buccal branch of the facial nerve (CN VII).
  • Damage to the facial nerve → buccinator paralysis → food collects in the vestibule of the mouth (cheek pouch).

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

Option

Function

Why Incorrect

A. Vagus (CN X)

Palate, pharynx, larynx

Does not innervate buccinator or facial muscles

B. Trigeminal (CN V)

Mastication muscles (V₃) + sensory

Motor to mastication, not facial expression

D. Hypoglossal (CN XII)

Tongue movement

Does not affect cheek movement or buccinator

 

🧪 Clinical Sign:

  • Patients with facial nerve palsy may present with food pooling in the cheek, difficulty smiling, and drooping of the mouth on the affected side.

Would you like a summary chart of muscles of facial expression and their innervation?

203

Regarding the relations of the abdominal aorta, which is true?

A. The abdominal aorta extends the transpyloric plane to a point inferior and to the left of the umbilicus at the level of the supracristal plane

B. The 3rd part of the duodenum passes anterior

C. The thoracic duct runs to the left of the aorta

D. The abdominal aorta descends anterior to the vertebral bodies T12-L5

Here’s a detailed breakdown of this MCQ on relations of the abdominal aorta:

Question

Regarding the relations of the abdominal aorta, which is true?

Options

Evaluation

A. The abdominal aorta extends the transpyloric plane to a point inferior and to the left of the umbilicus at the level of the supracristal plane

❌ Incorrect – The abdominal aorta extends from the aortic hiatus at T12 to its bifurcation at L4, which is just above the umbilicus, not below it or at the supracristal plane (which is L4, level of iliac crest). It also lies just left of midline, but not as far lateral as suggested.

B. The 3rd part of the duodenum passes anterior

✅ Correct – The 3rd (horizontal) part of the duodenum passes anterior to the abdominal aorta, at the level of L3. It is sandwiched between the aorta (posteriorly) and the superior mesenteric vessels (anteriorly).

C. The thoracic duct runs to the left of the aorta

❌ Incorrect – In the abdomen, the thoracic duct originates from the cisterna chyli, which lies posterior and slightly to the right of the aorta, not to the left. It only ascends to the left in the thoracic region.

D. The abdominal aorta descends anterior to the vertebral bodies T12–L5

❌ Incorrect – The abdominal aorta descends anterior to the vertebral bodies, yes, but only from T12 to L4 (not L5). It bifurcates at L4, making this statement inaccurate.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. The 3rd part of the duodenum passes anterior

🔍 Quick anatomy tip:

The 3rd part of the duodenum is an important landmark:

Aorta behind, SMA in front → clinically relevant in SMA syndrome.

Let me know if you’d like a cross-sectional diagram of these relations!

204

Which myotome(s) is responsible for adduction of the fingers

A. C8 T1

B. T1

C. C8

D. C7 C8

 

Thought for 13 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

Although the ulnar nerve fibers to the interossei derive from C8 and T1, the intrinsic hand muscles—including the palmar interossei that adduct the fingers—constitute a single myotome, T1. C8 contributes but is not the primary myotome for finger adduction Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Correct

The intrinsic muscles of the hand (palmar interossei) that adduct the fingers are innervated predominantly by T1. Moore states: “The intrinsic muscles of the hand constitute a single myotome (T1)” Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Incorrect

C8 fibers supply many intrinsic hand muscles, but finger adduction specifically tests T1. C8 alone is not sufficient for the adductor interossei, whose main segmental innervation is T1 Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Incorrect

C7 is not involved in innervating the palmar interossei. Adduction of the fingers relies on T1 (with C8 as a minor contributor), not on a C7–C8 myotome Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

205

Regarding the nasal cavity. Which is INCORRECT?

A. 5 arteries supply the nasal cavity with blood

B. Lymph node drainage of the nasal cavity is to the deep cervical, submandibular and retropharyngeal nodes

C. Nerve supply of the nasal cavity is only V1 and V2 of the trigeminal nerve

D. Mucosa lines the entire nasal cavity

Here's the analysis of the MCQ on nasal cavity anatomy, with focus on identifying the incorrect statement:

Question

Regarding the nasal cavity, which is INCORRECT?

Options

Evaluation

A. 5 arteries supply the nasal cavity with blood

✅ Correct – The nasal cavity has a rich vascular supply from five main arteries:

 

  1. Sphenopalatine (from maxillary)
  2. Greater palatine
  3. Anterior ethmoidal (from ophthalmic)
  4. Posterior ethmoidal
  5. Superior labial (from facial)
    These contribute to     Kiesselbach’s plexus (Little’s area). |
    |     B. Lymph node drainage of the nasal cavity is to the deep cervical, submandibular and retropharyngeal nodes | ✅ Correct – This is accurate.
  • Anterior nasal cavity drains to submandibular nodes
  • Posterior parts drain to retropharyngeal and then to deep cervical nodes. |
    |     C. Nerve supply of the nasal cavity is only V1 and V2 of the trigeminal nerve | ❌ Incorrect – This is the false statement.
    While     V1 (ophthalmic) and V2 (maxillary) branches of the trigeminal nerve provide general sensory innervation, the olfactory nerve (CN I) is also involved in special sensory (smell) innervation in the upper part of the nasal cavity (olfactory epithelium). |
    |     D. Mucosa lines the entire nasal cavity | ✅ Correct – The entire nasal cavity is lined by mucosa:
  • Respiratory mucosa (pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium) in most areas
  • Olfactory mucosa in the superior part (near the cribriform plate) |

 

❌ Correct Answer (the INCORRECT statement): C. Nerve supply of the nasal cavity is only V1 and V2 of the trigeminal nerve

🧠 Key point: Don't forget CN I (olfactory nerve) for smell, in addition to V1/V2 for general sensation.

Let me know if you'd like a labeled diagram or a clinical correlation (e.g., epistaxis zones or anosmia causes).

206
