Which muscles isnotsupplied by the tibial component of the sciatic nerve?

A. Semimembranosus

B. Short head of biceps femoris

C. The hamstring part of adductor magnus

D. Semitendinosus

 

Thought for 4 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

Semimembranosus is innervated by the tibial component of the sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2). Moore lists semimembranosus under the hamstring muscles “innervated by the tibial division of the sciatic nerve” Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Correct

The short head of biceps femoris is supplied by the common fibular (peroneal) division of the sciatic nerve, not the tibial component. Moore states “Short head: common fibular division of sciatic nerve” Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Incorrect

The hamstring part of adductor magnus is innervated by the tibial part of the sciatic nerve (L4). Moore describes “Hamstring part: tibial part of sciatic nerve” under adductor magnus Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Incorrect

Semitendinosus is innervated by the tibial component of the sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2). Moore lists semitendinosus as a hamstring supplied by the tibial division of the sciatic nerve Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

207

A patient sustains an injury to the lateral cord of the brachial plexus. Which movement of the upper limb is least likely to be affected?

A. Extension

B. Flexion

C. Rotation

D. Supination

 

Thought for 24 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Correct

Elbow and shoulder extension are mediated by the triceps brachii, an extensor in the posterior compartment of the arm, which is supplied by the radial nerve—a branch of the posterior cord of the brachial plexus. Because a lateral cord injury does not involve the posterior cord, extension remains intact. Moore describes the triceps as the “chief extensor of the forearm,” innervated by the radial nerve (C6–C8) arising from the posterior cord .

B

Incorrect

Elbow flexion relies primarily on the biceps brachii and brachialis, both innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve (C5–C7), which originates from the lateral cord. A lesion of the lateral cord therefore disrupts musculocutaneous function, significantly weakening flexion at the elbow. Moore lists these muscles as flexors supplied by the musculocutaneous nerve, a direct branch of the lateral cord .

C

Incorrect

Rotational movements of the shoulder (medial and lateral rotation) involve muscles that do not derive their innervation from the lateral cord. Medial rotation is produced by subscapularis (upper and lower subscapular nerves from the posterior cord), teres major (lower subscapular), and latissimus dorsi (thoracodorsal from the posterior cord). Lateral rotation is mediated by infraspinatus (suprascapular nerve from the upper trunk) and teres minor (axillary nerve from the posterior cord). However, pectoralis major (clavicular head)—which also contributes to medial rotation—is innervated by the lateral pectoral nerve from the lateral cord. Thus, while most rotators remain functional, some medial rotation by pectoralis major is lost, so rotation is partially affected .

D

Incorrect

Supination of the forearm depends heavily on the biceps brachii (innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve from the lateral cord) when power is required, and secondarily on the supinator muscle (radial nerve). A lateral cord injury removes the biceps contribution, markedly weakening supination. Moore states that “when the forearm is flexed to about 90° and power is needed, the biceps is the primary supinator” .

 

208

A patient develops infection on the medial aspect of his foot. Which group of lymph nodes will react?

A. Deep inguinal lymph nodes

B. Superficial inguinal lymph nodes

C. Popliteal lymph nodes

D. External iliac lymph nodes

 

Thought for 7 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

Deep inguinal lymph nodes receive lymph from superficial inguinal nodes and deep veins of the lower limb but are not the first to react to an infection on the medial foot. The medial superficial lymphatic vessels from the foot drain first to the superficial inguinal nodes, then onward to the deep inguinal nodes .

B

Correct

The medial side of the dorsum and sole of the foot drains via superficial lymphatic vessels that accompany the great saphenous vein to the vertical group of superficial inguinal lymph nodes. Thus, an infection on the medial foot will produce enlargement of these superficial inguinal nodes .

C

Incorrect

Popliteal lymph nodes receive lymph from the lateral side of the foot via vessels accompanying the small saphenous vein, not from the medial aspect. Therefore, a medial foot infection would not primarily involve the popliteal nodes .

D

Incorrect

External iliac lymph nodes receive lymph only after it passes through the superficial and deep inguinal nodes. They are not the initial group to react to a medial foot infection. The first-line nodes are the superficial inguinal nodes Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

209

FAST scans are a useful investigation for initial assessment and as an early guide to management in the emergency department. They are performed on patients in the supine position. In the supine position, the most gravity dependent region in a FAST scan is:

A. Left paracolic gutter

B. Right paracolic gutter

C. Hepatorenal recess

D. Splenorenal recess

Here's the detailed analysis of this FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) scan MCQ:

Question

In the supine position, the most gravity-dependent region in a FAST scan is:

Options

Evaluation

A. Left paracolic gutter

❌ Incorrect – While this is a dependent space on the left side, it is not the most gravity-dependent region when the patient is supine. Also, fluid tends to track more easily to the right due to anatomical continuity.

B. Right paracolic gutter

❌ Incorrect – It is more dependent than the left, and fluid does flow down it from the subhepatic space, but it is not the lowest point in the supine position.

C. Hepatorenal recess

✅ Correct – Also known as Morrison's pouch, this is the most gravity-dependent area in a supine patient. It lies between the liver and the right kidney, and is typically the first place intraperitoneal fluid collects in trauma. This is a primary target in FAST scans.

D. Splenorenal recess

❌ Incorrect – This is the left-sided equivalent of the hepatorenal space, located between the spleen and the left kidney, but it is less gravity-dependent than Morrison’s pouch in a supine patient.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Hepatorenal recess

🧠 Clinical pearl: In a supine trauma patient, Morrison’s pouch is the first and most sensitive spot for detecting free intraperitoneal fluid (e.g., from a ruptured liver or spleen).

Let me know if you want a FAST scan image interpretation guide or quick review of the 4 FAST windows.

210

A soccer player suffers an avulsion fracture of his anterior inferior iliac spine whist kicking a ball. Which muscle is likely to be affected?

A. Adductor longus

B. Sartorius

C. Vastus lateralis

D. Rectus femoris

 

Thought for 5 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

Adductor longus arises from the body of the pubis inferior to the pubic crest, not from the AIIS Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Incorrect

Sartorius originates from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS), not the anterior inferior iliac spine .

C

Incorrect

Vastus lateralis originates from the greater trochanter and the lateral lip of the linea aspera, not from the AIIS Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Correct

Rectus femoris has its straight head originating from the anterior inferior iliac spine (AIIS). An avulsion at the AIIS would therefore affect the rectus femoris, commonly called the “kicking muscle” due to its role in powerful hip flexion and knee extension during kicking .

 

211

Which is FALSE regarding the course of the sciatic nerve?

A. It descends in posterior thigh deep to biceps femoris

B. The nerve rests on the ischium and then passes posterior to the obturator internus, quadratus femoris and the adductor muscles

C. The sciatic nerve runs inferolaterally under the gluteus maximus muscle, midway between the greater trochanter and the ischial tuberosity

D. The sciatic nerve is the most medial nerve entering the greater sciatic foramen

 

Thought for 14 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Correct

The sciatic nerve descends in the posterior thigh deep to the biceps femoris. Moore states: “Enters gluteal region via greater sciatic foramen inferior to piriformis; descends in posterior thigh deep to biceps femoris” Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Correct

The nerve rests on the ischium and then passes posterior to the obturator internus, quadratus femoris, and adductor magnus. As Moore describes: “The nerve rests on the ischium and then passes posterior to the obturator internus, quadratus femoris, and adductor magnus muscles” Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Correct

After leaving the pelvis, the sciatic nerve runs inferolaterally under cover of the gluteus maximus, positioned midway between the greater trochanter and the ischial tuberosity. Moore notes: “The sciatic nerve runs inferolaterally under cover of the gluteus maximus” and is surface-marked “from a point midway between the greater trochanter and ischial tuberosity” .

D

Incorrect

The sciatic nerve is not the most medial structure in the greater sciatic foramen; it is the most lateral. Moore specifies that “the sciatic nerve is the most lateral structure emerging through the greater sciatic foramen,” whereas “the pudendal nerve is the most medial structure to exit the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen” .

 

212

Injury to the median nerve will result in this muscle's dysfunction

A. Palmer interossei 1st-3rd

B. Palmaris brevis

C. Extensor carpi radialis longus

D. Abductor pollicis brevis

 

Thought for 14 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

The palmar interossei are innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve, not the median nerve .

B

Incorrect

The palmaris brevis is supplied by the superficial branch of the ulnar nerve, not the median nerve .

C

Incorrect

The extensor carpi radialis longus is innervated by the radial nerve (C6, C7), not the median nerve Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Correct

The abductor pollicis brevis is innervated by the recurrent (thenar) branch of the median nerve (C8, T1). Injury to the median nerve would paralyze this muscle, impairing thumb abduction .

 

213

The deep branch of the radial nerve supplies all the following EXCEPT?

A. Extensor pollicis longus

B. Extensor carpi ulnaris

C. Supinator

D. Extensor carpi radialis longus

 

Thought for 4 seconds

The deep branch of the radial nerve (often called the posterior interosseous nerve after it pierces supinator) innervates most of the extensor and supinator muscles in the posterior compartment of the forearm. Specifically:

  • Extensor pollicis longus is supplied by the posterior interosseous nerve (continuation of the deep branch) .
  • Extensor carpi ulnaris is also innervated by the deep branch (posterior interosseous) .
  • Supinator receives its motor innervation directly from the deep branch of the radial nerve before it becomes the posterior interosseous nerve .
  • Extensor carpi radialis longus, however, is supplied by the (superficial) radial nerve itself (radial nerve proper) before it divides. It is not a target of the deep branch/posterior interosseous .

Therefore, the only muscle not innervated by the deep branch is D. Extensor carpi radialis longus.

214

Injury to the median nerve at the flexor retinaculum produces the following deficits EXCEPT?

A. Sensation loss over the thumb and adjacent two and a half fingers

B. Sensation loss of the skin of the central palm

C. Paralysis of the first two lumbricles

D. Paralysis of the thenar muscles

 

Thought for 12 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

In carpal tunnel compression (median nerve under flexor retinaculum), sensation over the thumb and adjacent two and a half fingers is lost because the digital branches of the median nerve pass through the tunnel to supply these digits Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Correct

The palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve arises proximal to the flexor retinaculum and does not traverse the carpal tunnel. Therefore, sensation in the central palm remains intact despite median-nerve compression under the retinaculum Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Incorrect

The first two lumbricals (to digits 2 and 3) receive innervation from the median nerve distal to the flexor retinaculum. Median-nerve injury at this site paralyzes these lumbricals, impairing flexion of the metacarpophalangeal joints of the index and middle fingers Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Incorrect

The recurrent (thenar) branch of the median nervecourses through the flexor retinaculum and supplies the thenar muscles (abductor pollicis brevis, opponens pollicis, superficial head of flexor pollicis brevis). Injury under the retinaculum therefore paralyzes these muscles, preventing opposition and abduction of the thumb Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

215

Regarding the ventricles of the brain, which is incorrect?

A. The cerebral aqueduct connects the third and fourth ventricles

B. The choroid plexuses are not found in the 4th ventricle

C. The lateral ventricles consist of a body and anterior, posterior and inferior horns

D. CSF drains form the 4th ventricle via the foramen of Magendis and Luschka into the subarachnoid space

The incorrect statement is:

B. The choroid plexuses are not found in the 4th ventricle

 

✅ Corrected Explanation:

  • B is incorrect because the choroid plexus is present in the 4th ventricle and plays a key role in CSF production.

 

✔️ Explanation of other options:

  • A. The cerebral aqueduct connects the third and fourth ventricles
    → Correct. The cerebral aqueduct (of Sylvius) runs through the midbrain and connects the third to the fourth ventricle.
  • C. The lateral ventricles consist of a body and anterior, posterior and inferior horns
    → Correct. This describes the anatomy of the lateral ventricles accurately.
  • D. CSF drains from the 4th ventricle via the foramen of Magendie and Luschka into the subarachnoid space
    → Correct. CSF exits the 4th ventricle through:
    • Foramen of Magendie (median aperture)
    • Foramina of Luschka (lateral apertures)

 

✅ Final Answer: B. The choroid plexuses are not found in the 4th ventricle

216

A 45-year-old man suffers an acute myocardial infarction and is brought to your emergency department for acute management.He develops a left ventricular wall thrombus with motion artefact. This is most likely due to occlusion of which vessel?

A. Left anterior descending artery

B. Left main coronary artery

C. Left circumflex artery

D. Right coronary artery

 

217

Which of the following features protects against inferior dislocation of the abducted shoulder?

A. Coraco-acromial arch

B. Long head of triceps

C. Gleno-humeral joint

D. Glenohumeral ligament

 

Thought for 13 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

The coracoacromial arch (acromion, coracoid process, and coracoacromial ligament) forms a “roof” over the humeral head, preventing superior migration, not inferior dislocation. When the arm is abducted, the head presses upward against this arch if cuff function is lost .

B

Correct

When the shoulder is abducted, the humeral head tends to slip inferiorly under the weight of the arm. The long head of triceps, crossing the glenohumeral joint, acts as a dynamic “shunt” muscle that pulls the head gently upward into the glenoid, resisting inferior displacement .

C

Incorrect

Referring simply to the “glenohumeral joint” is too generic. Passive stability comes from the capsule and ligaments, but without specifying which elements, this answer does not identify the actual structures that resist inferior dislocation in abduction.

D

Incorrect

Although the inferior glenohumeral ligament (part of the ligamentous complex) does provide some passive support, saying “glenohumeral ligament” without specifying the inferior band is incomplete. Moreover, the primary restraint against inferior displacement in abduction is provided dynamically by the long head of triceps and other muscles, rather than by the ligament alone Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

 

218

With regard to the lumbricals, which of the following statements is correct?

A. Arise from flexor digitorum superficialis

B. Oppose the actions of the interossei

C. Are all supplied by the ulnar nerve

D. Form a proprioceptive bridge between flexors and extensors

 

Thought for 10 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

Each lumbrical arises from a tendon of the flexor digitorum profundus, not from flexor digitorum superficialis. Moore states: “Lumbricals 1st and 2nd: lateral two tendons of flexor digitorum profundus … 3rd and 4th: medial three tendons of flexor digitorum profundus” Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Incorrect

The interossei and lumbricals work together (“Z‐movement”) to flex the metacarpophalangeal joints and extend the interphalangeal joints; they do not oppose one another. Moore explains: “Acting together, the dorsal and palmar interossei and the lumbricals produce flexion at the MP joints but extension at the PIP and DIP joints (the so‐called Z‐movement)” .

C

Incorrect

Only the 3rd and 4th lumbricals are supplied by the ulnar nerve. The 1st and 2nd lumbricals receive innervation from the median nerve. Moore clearly lists: “1st and 2nd lumbricals: median nerve (C8, T1); 3rd and 4th lumbricals: deep branch of ulnar nerve (C8, T1)” Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Correct

Lumbricals are small intrinsic muscles with a high density of muscle spindles, forming a “proprioceptive bridge” between flexor tendons and the extensor expansion to coordinate precise finger movements. Moore notes that small muscles (like lumbricals) have more spindles and thereby provide proprioceptive feedback linking flexion and extension Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

219

Which of the following is true regarding the quadrangular and triangular spaces?

A. Long head of triceps forms a border of both spaces

B. The circumflex scapular artery passes through the quadrangular space

C. The triangular space transmits the median nerve

D. Teres minor does not form a boundary of either space

 

Thought for 12 seconds

Answer: A

Explanation:

  • Long head of triceps forms a border of both spaces (True).
    • In the quadrangular space, the medial boundary is formed by the long head of triceps. The other boundaries are teres minor (superior), teres major (inferior), and the surgical neck of the humerus (lateral). Within this space travel the axillary nerve and posterior circumflex humeral artery .
    • In the triangular space, the lateral boundary is the long head of triceps. The other borders are teres minor (superior) and teres major (inferior). This space transmits the circumflex scapular artery (not a nerve) .
  • Why the other choices are false:
    • B. “The circumflex scapular artery passes through the quadrangular space” is incorrect because the circumflex scapular artery actually passes through the triangular space, not the quadrangular space.
    • C. “The triangular space transmits the median nerve” is incorrect; the triangular space transmits only the circumflex scapular artery (and accompanying veins), not any nerve.
    • D. “Teres minor does not form a boundary of either space” is incorrect because teres minor forms the superior border of both the quadrangular and triangular spaces.

Thus, option A is the only statement that correctly describes both spaces.

220

Referred pain from pancreatitis is felt at what level?

A. L1/2

B. T7/8

C. T3/4

D. T12/L1

Here's the analysis of the MCQ on referred pain from pancreatitis:

Question

Referred pain from pancreatitis is felt at what level?

Options

Evaluation

A. L1/2

❌ Incorrect – This level is typically associated with referred pain from lower abdominal organs like the kidneys, ureters, or lower gastrointestinal tract. Not typical for pancreatic pain.

B. T7/8

✅ Correct – The pancreas is a retroperitoneal organ located at the level of T6–T10, and its visceral afferent fibers enter the spinal cord around T7–T9. Hence, pain from pancreatitis is typically referred to the epigastrium and mid-back at the T7/8 level.

C. T3/4

❌ Incorrect – This level is more associated with pain from structures in the thorax, such as the heart or upper esophagus.

D. T12/L1

❌ Incorrect – These levels are associated with pelvic organs and lower GI structures like the sigmoid colon or bladder, not the pancreas.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. T7/8

🔍 Clinical clue: Pancreatitis pain is classically described as epigastric pain radiating to the back, corresponding to T7–T9 dermatomes.

Let me know if you’d like a dermatome-visceral referral chart or comparison with other abdominal organ pain patterns.

221

Under the extensor retinaculum, which is the most lateral structure?

A. The anterior tibial artery

B. The sural nerve

C. Extensor halucis longus

D. Peroneus tertius

Here’s a detailed breakdown of this MCQ on structures under the extensor retinaculum (ankle region):

Question

Under the extensor retinaculum, which is the most lateral structure?

Options

Evaluation

A. The anterior tibial artery

❌ Incorrect – This artery becomes the dorsalis pedis artery after crossing under the extensor retinaculum and is located just lateral to the extensor hallucis longus tendon, which places it more centrally, not laterally.

B. The sural nerve

❌ Incorrect – The sural nerve runs along the posterior aspect of the leg and ankle, near the lateral malleolus, and does not pass under the extensor retinaculum.

C. Extensor hallucis longus

❌ Incorrect – This tendon lies medial to the dorsalis pedis artery, placing it toward the medial side, not lateral.

D. Peroneus tertius

✅ Correct – The peroneus (fibularis) tertius tendon lies most laterally under the extensor retinaculum. It runs beside the extensor digitorum longus tendons and inserts on the base of the 5th metatarsal. It is the most lateral structure among those listed.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Peroneus tertius

🧠 Order of structures under extensor retinaculum (medial to lateral):

Tendon of tibialis anterior

Hallucis longus (extensor)

Artery (anterior tibial → dorsalis pedis)

Nerve (deep peroneal)

Digitorum longus (extensor)

Peroneus tertius

Mnemonic: "Tom Has A Nice Dog Pet" (Tibialis anterior to Peroneus tertius)

Let me know if you’d like an annotated diagram or mnemonic for flexor retinaculum contents too!

222

Which of the following statements is correct in relation to teres major?

A. Forms the lower border of the quadrangular space

B. Forms the lateral border of the triangular space

C. Is supplied by the axillary nerve

D. Arises from the medial border of the scapula

 

Thought for 7 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Correct

The inferior border of teres major forms the lower boundary of the quadrangular space. Moore states: “The inferior border of the teres major forms the inferior border of the lateral part of the posterior wall of the axilla,” and Figure 6.39 labels teres major as the inferior border of the quadrangular space .

B

Incorrect

The lateral border of the triangular space is formed by the long head of triceps, not teres major. Teres major forms the inferior border of the triangular space, with teres minor as its superior border and long head of triceps as its lateral border Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Incorrect

Teres major is innervated by the lower subscapular nerve (C5, C6), not the axillary nerve. Moore specifies: “Teres major … Innervation: Lower subscapular nerve (C5, C6)” Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Incorrect

Teres major originates from the posterior surface of the inferior angle and lower third of the lateral border of the scapula, not the medial border. Moore describes: “Proximal attachment: Posterior surface of inferior angle of scapula” Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

223

While transversing the temporal bone within the facial canal, CN VII gives rise to following nerves except?

A. Nerve to the stapedius

B. Greater pertrosal nerve

C. Chorda tympani nerve

D. Deep petrosal nerve

✅ Correct Answer: D. Deep petrosal nerve

 

🧠 Explanation:

While traversing the facial canal in the temporal bone, the facial nerve (CN VII) gives off several important branches. Here's what it does and does not give off:

 

✅ Branches of CN VII within the facial canal:

Branch

Function

1. Greater petrosal nerve

Parasympathetic to lacrimal gland and nasal/palatal glands via pterygopalatine ganglion

2. Nerve to stapedius

Motor to stapedius muscle (dampens sound vibrations)

3. Chorda tympani nerve

Taste to anterior 2/3 of tongue; parasympathetic to submandibular/sublingual glands via submandibular ganglion

 

❌ Deep petrosal nerve:

  • NOT a branch of CN VII
  • It is a sympathetic nerve, arising from the internal carotid plexus
  • Joins the greater petrosal nerve to form the nerve of the pterygoid canal (Vidian nerve)

 

✅ Therefore, the facial nerve does not give rise to the deep petrosal nerve.

 

Final Answer: D. Deep petrosal nerve

224

Regarding myotomal supply, which of the following is correct?

A. Shoulder abduction - C5/6

B. Plantar flexion - L4/5

C. Elbow extension - C6/C7

D. Opponens pollicis - C7/C8

 

Thought for 24 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Correct

Shoulder abduction is primarily a C5 myotome, with some C6 contribution. Figure 6.20 shows that abduction of the glenohumeral joint corresponds to C5/C6 spinal segments Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Incorrect

Plantar flexion of the foot is mediated by S1–S2 myotomes (e.g., gastrocnemius, soleus). Thus L4/L5 is not the correct myotomal level for plantar flexion.

C

Incorrect

Elbow extension (triceps) is a C7–C8 myotome, with C7 being dominant. C6 is not a primary contributor to triceps function, so C6/C7 is not accurate.

D

Incorrect

Opposition of the thumb (opponens pollicis) is an intrinsic hand movement supplied by T1 (median nerve recurrent branch). C7/C8 is not the correct myotomal level for opponens pollicis.

 

225

With regard to the bronchopulmonary segments, all of the following statements are trueexcept?

A. The lingular portion of the superior left lobe is divided into an upper and lower segment

B. There are approximately 9 segments in each lung

C. The superficial bronchial veins of the right main bronchus drain into the azygos vein

D. Material aspirated tends to lodge in basal segments of the right lower lobe

Certainly! Here's the properly formatted table and explanation for the question:

 

Question:

With regard to the bronchopulmonary segments, all of the following statements are true except:

Option

Statement

Evaluation

A

The lingular portion of the superior left lobe is divided into an upper and lower segment

✅ True – The lingula of the left upper lobe is equivalent to the middle lobe of the right lung. It consists of two bronchopulmonary segments: superior lingular and inferior lingular.

B

There are approximately 9 segments in each lung

❌ False – This is the incorrect statement and thus the correct answer to the MCQ. While the left lung may have some fused segments and is sometimes described as having 8–9 segments, anatomically each lung typically has 10 segments. So this statement is misleading.

C

The superficial bronchial veins of the right main bronchus drain into the azygos vein

✅ True – The superficial (extra-pulmonary) bronchial veins on the right drain into the azygos vein. On the left, they drain into the hemiazygos or left superior intercostal vein.

D

Material aspirated tends to lodge in basal segments of the right lower lobe

✅ True – The right main bronchus is more vertical and wider, making the posterior basal segment of the right lower lobe a common site for aspirated material, especially in supine patients.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. There are approximately 9 segments in each lung

Let me know if you'd like a chart or visual of all bronchopulmonary segments for each lung!

226

All of the following structures pass deep to the superior extensor retinaculum with the exception of?

A. Superficial peroneal nerve

B. Deep peroneal nerve

C. Peroneus tertius

D. Extensor digitorum longus

 

Thought for 8 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Correct

The superficial peroneal nerve does not pass deep to the superior extensor retinaculum. It pierces the deep fascia of the lateral compartment higher in the leg and runs superficial to the retinaculum before supplying the dorsum of the foot. Moore notes that only the tendons of the anterior compartment muscles, the deep fibular nerve, and the anterior tibial vessels pass deep to the superior extensor retinaculum Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Incorrect

The deep peroneal nerve (deep fibular nerve) accompanies the anterior tibial artery and passes deep to the superior extensor retinaculum to enter the dorsum of the foot, lying between the tendons of tibialis anterior and extensor hallucis longus at the ankle Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Incorrect

The peroneus tertius tendon (fibularis tertius) is one of the anterior compartment tendons that courses beneath the superior extensor retinaculum as it descends to insert on the base of the fifth metatarsal .

D

Incorrect

The extensor digitorum longus tendon passes deep to the superior extensor retinaculum on its way to the dorsum of the foot, running in the same compartment as the fibularis tertius tendon .

 

227

Which of the following dermatomes supplies the little toe?

A. S1

B. L5

C. S2

D. L4

 

Thought for 6 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Correct

The S1 dermatome covers the lateral aspect of the foot, including the little (5th) toe. In Foerster’s map, S1 is shown over the lateral foot and 5th toe region Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Incorrect

The L5 dermatome supplies the dorsum of the foot and the dorsum of the big toe and 2nd–3rd toes, not the little toe; L5 lies more medial and proximal, not over the lateralmost digit Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Incorrect

The S2 dermatome covers the posterior thigh and upper posterior leg, not the foot; it does not extend to the little toe region Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Incorrect

The L4 dermatome supplies the medial leg and foot (medial malleolus and medial big toe), not the little toe; it does not cover the lateral digit Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

228

With regard to the testicles, which of the following statements is correct?

A. The testicular artery only anastomoses with the cremasteric artery

B. The pampiniform plexus is a superficial venous plexus surrounding the testicular artery

C. Division of the testicular artery results in testicular infarction

D. The testes have a tough fibrous outer surface, the tunica vaginalis

The correct answer is: B. The pampiniform plexus is a superficial venous plexus surrounding the testicular artery

 

✅ Explanation (from Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy):

Let’s evaluate each option:

 

A. "The testicular artery only anastomoses with the cremasteric artery" – ❌ Incorrect

  • The testicular artery anastomoses with both:
    • The cremasteric artery (from the inferior epigastric artery), and
    • The artery to the ductus deferens (from the inferior vesical artery).
  • So it does not only anastomose with the cremasteric artery.

 

B. "The pampiniform plexus is a superficial venous plexus surrounding the testicular artery" – ✅ Correct

  • The pampiniform plexus is a network of interconnected veins that:
    • Surrounds the testicular artery in the spermatic cord.
    • Functions to cool the arterial blood before it reaches the testis (a heat-exchange mechanism).
  • It is superficial to the testicular artery and forms the testicular vein (right → IVC; left → left renal vein).

 

C. "Division of the testicular artery results in testicular infarction" – ❌ Incorrect

  • The testicular artery has collateral supply, especially via:
    • The cremasteric artery
    • The artery to the vas deferens
  • So division does not always lead to infarction.

 

D. "The testes have a tough fibrous outer surface, the tunica vaginalis" – ❌ Incorrect

  • The outer fibrous capsule of the testis is the tunica albuginea, not the tunica vaginalis.
  • The tunica vaginalis is a serous sac derived from the peritoneum; it surrounds the testis but does not form its fibrous surface.

 

✅ Final Answer: B. The pampiniform plexus is a superficial venous plexus surrounding the testicular artery

229

Which of the following is the deepest mid-forearm structure?

A. Median nerve

B. Flexor pollicis longus (FPL)

C. Radial artery

D. Ulnar nerve

 

Thought for 19 seconds

 

Deepest?

Brief Explanation

A. Median nerve

No

The median nerve travels in the neurovascular plane between the flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS) and flexor digitorum profundus (FDP), so it is superficial to the deep muscle layer. Moore - Clinically Orie…

B. Flexor pollicis longus (FPL)

Yes

FPL is a member of the deep (third) layer of anterior forearm muscles and lies deep to both FDS and FDP, making it the deepest structure in the mid-forearm. Moore - Clinically Orie…

C. Radial artery

No

The radial artery courses on top of the FDS and over the FPL tendon in the mid-forearm, placing it more superficial than FPL. Moore - Clinically Orie…

D. Ulnar nerve

No

The ulnar nerve passes between the heads of flexor carpi ulnaris and then descends superficial to FDP and FDS, so it is not as deep as FPL. Moore - Clinically Orie…

 

Answer: B Flexor pollicis longus

230

Which of the following passes through the lesser sciatic foramen?

A. Superior gluteal artery

B. The superior gemellus

C. Internal pudendal artery

D. Piriformis

 

Thought for 11 seconds

 

Passes?

Brief Explanation

A. Superior gluteal artery

No

The superior gluteal artery leaves the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen (above piriformis), not the lesser sciatic. Moore - Clinically Orie…

B. Superior gemellus

No

The superior gemellus is a muscle originating on the ischial spine/body and attaching to the femur; it does not traverse either sciatic foramen.

C. Internal pudendal artery

Yes

After exiting the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen, the internal pudendal artery hooks around the ischial spine and enters the perineum through the lesser sciatic foramen. Moore - Clinically Orie…

D. Piriformis

No

Piriformis leaves the pelvis by passing through the greater sciatic foramen to attach on the greater trochanter and never goes through the lesser foramen. Moore - Clinically Orie…

 

Answer: C Internal pudendal artery

231

Which structure does not travel through the jugular foramen?

A. Accessory nerve

B. Hypoglossal nerve

C. Glossopharyngeal nerve

D. Vagus nerve

✅ Correct Answer: B. Hypoglossal nerve

 

🧠 Explanation:

The jugular foramen transmits the following three cranial nerves and a major vein:

Structure

Passes Through Jugular Foramen?

Notes

CN IX – Glossopharyngeal

✅ Yes

Sensory and motor to pharynx and tongue

CN X – Vagus

✅ Yes

Parasympathetic to thorax & abdomen

CN XI – Accessory

✅ Yes

Motor to sternocleidomastoid & trapezius

Internal jugular vein

✅ Yes

Formed at the jugular foramen

CN XII – Hypoglossal

❌ No

Exits via the hypoglossal canal, not the jugular foramen

 

 

📝 Quick Summary:

Foramen

Cranial Nerves

Jugular Foramen

CN IX, X, XI

Hypoglossal Canal

CN XII

 

 

Let me know if you'd like a skull base diagram or a quiz to practice foramen contents!

232

Which of the following is not a branch of the opthalmic nerve?

A. infraorbital nerve

B. infratrochlear nerve

C. Supraorbital nerve

D. Supratrochlear nerve

✅ Correct Answer: A. Infraorbital nerve

 

🧠 Explanation:

The ophthalmic nerve (CN V₁) is the first division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) and is purely sensory. Its three main branches are:

  1. Frontal nerve → supratrochlear and supraorbital
  2. Nasociliary nerve → includes infratrochlear
  3. Lacrimal nerve

 

✅ True branches of the ophthalmic nerve (CN V₁):

Branch

From

Region Supplied

Infratrochlear nerve

Nasociliary branch (V₁)

Eyelids, nose bridge

Supraorbital nerve

Frontal branch (V₁)

Forehead, scalp

Supratrochlear nerve

Frontal branch (V₁)

Medial forehead, upper eyelid

 

 

❌ Incorrect option:

A. Infraorbital nerve

➤ Branch of the maxillary nerve (CN V₂)

➤ Exits via the infraorbital foramen

➤ Supplies: lower eyelid, upper lip, cheek

 

 

🔑 Mnemonic for V₁ branches: "NFL"

  • Nasociliary
  • Frontal
  • Lacrimal

Would you like a comparison table of V₁, V₂, and V₃ branches for revision?

233

Which of the following bones is not part of the transverse arch of the foot?

A. Base of all the metatarsals

B. Cuboid

C. Navicular

D. Cuneiform

 

Thought for 6 seconds

 

Part of Transverse Arch?

Brief Explanation

A. Base of all the metatarsals

Yes

The transverse arch is formed by the cuboid, cuneiforms, and the bases of the metatarsals; thus, the metatarsal bases are included. Moore - Clinically Orie…

B. Cuboid

Yes

The cuboid is one of the three tarsal bones that, along with the cuneiforms and metatarsal bases, create the transverse arch. Moore - Clinically Orie…

C. Navicular

No

The navicular lies proximal to the cuneiforms and is not part of the transverse arch; it contributes to the medial longitudinal arch instead. Moore - Clinically Orie…

D. Cuneiform

Yes

All three cuneiform bones (medial, intermediate, lateral) form the central keystone of the transverse arch alongside the cuboid and metatarsal bases. Moore - Clinically Orie…

 

Answer: C Navicular

234

Which of the following movements occurs at the subtalar joint?

A. Eversion

B. Dorsiflexion

C. Equinovarus

D. Plantarflexion

 

Thought for 4 seconds

 

Occurs at Subtalar Joint?

Brief Explanation

A. Eversion

Yes

The subtalar (talocalcaneal) joint is the primary site for inversion and eversion of the foot. Moore - Clinically Orie…

B. Dorsiflexion

No

Dorsiflexion occurs at the talocrural (ankle) joint, not at the subtalar joint. Moore - Clinically Orie…

C. Equinovarus

No

Equinovarus is a complex deformity combining inversion and plantarflexion; plantarflexion occurs at the ankle, so this specific composite does not solely occur at the subtalar joint. Moore - Clinically Orie…

D. Plantarflexion

No

Plantarflexion is produced at the talocrural (ankle) joint, not the subtalar joint. Moore - Clinically Orie…

 

Answer: A Eversion

235

A patient is stabbed in his axilla; it results in damage to the lateral cord of the brachial plexus. Which muscle will be denervated?

A. Supinator

B. Flexi carpi ulnaris

C. Coracobrachialis

D. Anconeus

Correct Answer: C. Coracobrachialis

Damage to the lateral cord directly interrupts fibers giving rise to the musculocutaneous nerve, denervating coracobrachialis.

236

Which of the following statements is true in relation to the axillary artery?

A. Has no branches in it's 3rd part

B. Arises from the vertebral artery

C. Is clasped in its 3rd part by the cords of the brachial plexus

D. Supplies the pectoral muscles via the superior thoracic artery

A. Has no branches in its 3rd part – Incorrect

Moore clearly states that the third part of the axillary artery (from the lateral border of pectoralis minor to the inferior border of teres major) gives off three branches: the subscapular artery (the largest), anterior circumflex humeral artery, and posterior circumflex humeral artery .

B. Arises from the vertebral artery – Incorrect

The axillary artery is simply the continuation of the subclavian artery once it crosses the lateral border of the first rib. It does not originate from the vertebral artery .

C. Is clasped in its 3rd part by the cords of the brachial plexus – Incorrect

The cords of the brachial plexus are named for their relationship around the second part of the axillary artery (posterior to pectoralis minor), not the third. By the time the artery reaches its third part, it has already passed distal to those cords .

D. Supplies the pectoral muscles via the superior thoracic artery – Correct

The superior thoracic artery is a small branch arising from the first part of the axillary artery, running anteromedially between pectoralis minor and major to supply the first and second intercostal spaces and the superior portion of serratus anterior—along with adjacent pectoral muscle fibers. Thus, it does contribute to pectoral muscle vascularization .

237

Which is true regarding subarachnoid cisterns?

A. Chiasmatic cistern is inferior and posterior to the optic chiasm

B. Ambient cistern is continous posteriorly with the quadrigeminal cistern

C. Ambient cistern contain parts of the great cerebral vein

D. Pontocerebellar cistern is the largest cistern

Here's the detailed and correctly formatted breakdown of the MCQ on subarachnoid cisterns:

 

Question:

Which is true regarding subarachnoid cisterns?

Option

Statement

Evaluation

A

Chiasmatic cistern is inferior and posterior to the optic chiasm

❌ Incorrect – The chiasmatic cistern is located superior and anterior to the optic chiasm, not inferior and posterior. It lies between the optic chiasm and the lamina terminalis.

B

Ambient cistern is continuous posteriorly with the quadrigeminal cistern

✅ Correct – This is true. The ambient cistern runs laterally around the midbrain and is continuous posteriorly with the quadrigeminal (superior cistern).

C

Ambient cistern contains parts of the great cerebral vein

❌ Incorrect – The great cerebral vein (of Galen) is located in the quadrigeminal cistern, not the ambient cistern. The ambient cistern contains structures such as the trochlear nerve (CN IV) and posterior cerebral artery.

D

Pontocerebellar cistern is the largest cistern

❌ Incorrect – The largest subarachnoid cistern is the cerebellomedullary cistern (cisterna magna), not the pontocerebellar cistern. The pontocerebellar (also called pontine cistern) is significant but not the largest.

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Ambient cistern is continuous posteriorly with the quadrigeminal cistern

🧠 Memory tip:

Think of the ambient cistern as the “wrap-around” cistern of the midbrain that connects anterior cisterns to the quadrigeminal cistern in back.

Let me know if you'd like a labeled diagram of the cisterns or a mnemonic to remember them!

238

Which of the following is the highest branch of the abdominal aorta?

A. Inferior phrenic artery

B. Right suprarenal artery

C. Left renal artery

D. Left gonadal artery

🧠 Mnemonic (for order of paired branches, superior to inferior):

"I Really Like Gonads"

  • I – Inferior phrenic
  • R – Renal
  • L – Lumbar
  • G – Gonadal

The inferior phrenic arteries are typically the first (highest) branches of the abdominal aorta, arising just below the aortic hiatus of the diaphragm, around the T12 level.

239

The posterior columns transmit which of the following structures?

A. Tendon stretch afferents

B. Pain afferents

C. Motor tracts

D. Temperature afferents

Here's the detailed breakdown of the MCQ on the posterior (dorsal) columns of the spinal cord:

 

Question:

The posterior columns transmit which of the following structures?

Option

Statement

Evaluation

A

Tendon stretch afferents

✅ Correct – The posterior columns (fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus) transmit large myelinated sensory fibers involved in proprioception, fine touch, vibration, and conscious tendon stretch sensation (i.e., muscle spindle and Golgi tendon organ inputs). These are carried to the brainstem, then to the medial lemniscus, and finally to the sensory cortex.

B

Pain afferents

❌ Incorrect – Pain fibers are transmitted via the spinothalamic tract (part of the anterolateral system), not the posterior columns.

C

Motor tracts

❌ Incorrect – Motor tracts such as the corticospinal tracts are descending, and located in the lateral and anterior funiculi, not in the posterior columns.

D

Temperature afferents

❌ Incorrect – Like pain, temperature sensation is carried via the spinothalamic tract, not the posterior columns.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Tendon stretch afferents

🧠 Quick Summary of Posterior Column Function (DCML Pathway):

  • Dorsal Column → Medial Lemniscus
  • Carries: Fine touch, vibration, conscious proprioception, tendon stretch

Let me know if you’d like a visual of spinal cord tracts or a comparison table of sensory pathways!

240

Regarding the circle of Willis which of the following statements is correct?

A. The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) is the largest branch of the internal carotid artery (ICA)

B. The posterior cerebral artery (PCA) is a branch of the internal carotid

C. The middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies the motor but not sensory cortex

D. The internal carotid artery (ICA) gives off the ophthalmic artery

The correct answer is: D. The internal carotid artery (ICA) gives off the ophthalmic artery

 

✅ Explanation of the Correct Answer:

  • The ophthalmic artery is the first major intracranial branch of the internal carotid artery (ICA).
  • It enters the orbit via the optic canal and supplies:
    • The eye
    • Orbital contents
    • Part of the forehead and scalp

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

  • A. The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) is the largest branch of the internal carotid artery (ICA)
    → Incorrect: The middle cerebral artery (MCA) is the largest branch of the ICA.
  • B. The posterior cerebral artery (PCA) is a branch of the internal carotid
    → Incorrect: The PCA arises from the basilar artery, part of the vertebrobasilar (posterior) circulation, not the ICA.
  • C. The middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies the motor but not sensory cortex
    → Incorrect: The MCA supplies both the motor and sensory cortices, especially the lateral aspects (e.g., face and upper limbs).

 

✅ Final Answer: D. The internal carotid artery (ICA) gives off the ophthalmic artery

241

Regarding the ulnar artery, which of the following is correct?

A. Has the common interosseus as its major branch

B. The ulnar nerve lies lateral to it

C. It disappears from the cubital fossa by passing above the fibrous arch of flexor digitorium superficialis

D. Forms the deep palmar arch

 

Thought for 9 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Correct

The common interosseous artery arises from the ulnar artery just distal to its origin in the cubital fossa. Moore notes that “The common interosseous artery, a short branch of the ulnar artery, arises in the distal part of the cubital fossa and divides almost immediately into anterior and posterior interosseous arteries” Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Incorrect

The ulnar nerve lies medial to the ulnar artery in the forearm. The artery “lies lateral to the ulnar nerve” as it passes into the hand (Guyon canal), not the other way around Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Incorrect

The ulnar artery descends into the forearm by passing deep to the tendinous arch of flexor digitorum superficialis, not above it. Moore describes that the artery “descends obliquely deep to the fibrous arch of the flexor digitorum superficialis to join the ulnar nerve” Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Incorrect

The ulnar artery contributes mainly to the superficial palmar arch in the hand. The deep palmar arch is formed primarily by the radial artery, with only a small deep palmar branch of the ulnar completing it on the medial side .

 

242

All the following muscles directly attach the pectoral girdle to the thoraxexcept?

A. Pectoralis minor

B. Pectoralis major

C. Subclavius

D. Rhomboids

Answer: B. Pectoralis major

Explanation:

  • Pectoralis minor (Option A) attaches the medial border and superior surface of the coracoid process of the scapula (part of the pectoral girdle) to the anterior surfaces of ribs 3–5. This directly connects scapula to the thoracic wall .
  • Pectoralis major (Option B), however, does not attach the pectoral girdle itself (scapula or clavicle) to the thorax. Instead, it originates from the clavicle, sternum, and costal cartilages but inserts on the lateral lip of the intertubercular sulcus of the humerus. Thus, it moves the humerus rather than anchoring the pectoral girdle to the thorax .
  • Subclavius (Option C) anchors and depresses the clavicle by arising from the junction of the first rib and its costal cartilage and inserting on the inferior surface of the clavicle. This directly ties the clavicle (part of the pectoral girdle) to the first rib (thoracic skeleton) .
  • Rhomboids (Option D) attach the medial border of the scapula to the spinous processes of T2–T5, thereby directly linking scapula to the thoracic vertebrae (part of the thoracic skeleton) .

Because pectoralis major inserts onto the humerus and does not attach the scapula/clavicle to the thorax, it is the exception.

243

What is the lymph drainage of the anus inferior to the pectineal line?

A. Deep inguinal lymph nodes

B. Superficial inguinal lymph nodes

C. Internal iliac lymph nodes

D. External iliac lymph nodes

Here's the detailed breakdown of this MCQ on lymphatic drainage of the anus:

 

Question:

What is the lymph drainage of the anus inferior to the pectineal (dentate) line?

Option

Evaluation

A. Deep inguinal lymph nodes

❌ Incorrect – These nodes drain deeper structures of the lower limb and some pelvic organs, but not the skin of the anal canal below the pectineal line.

B. Superficial inguinal lymph nodes

✅ Correct – The anal canal below the pectineal line (which is ectodermal in origin) drains to the superficial inguinal lymph nodes, along with perianal skin and lower anal canal.

C. Internal iliac lymph nodes

❌ Incorrect – These drain the anal canal above the pectineal line, which is endodermal in origin.

D. External iliac lymph nodes

❌ Incorrect – These primarily receive drainage from the superior bladder, cervix, and prostate, not the lower anal canal.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Superficial inguinal lymph nodes

🧠 Mnemonic for anal canal lymph drainage:

  • "Above the line, go deep inside" → Internal iliac nodes
  • "Below the line, stay outside" → Superficial inguinal nodes

Let me know if you'd like a full table of pelvic organ lymph drainage for rapid revision.

244

What is true of the biceps femoris muscle?

A. Distally the single tendon of biceps femoris muscle inserts into the upper end of the tibia

B. It is involved in flexion of the knee and hip joint

C. Receives dual supply from tibia (long head) and common fibular (short head) part of sciatic nerve.

D. Arterial supply is provided by the femoral artery

 

True?

Brief Explanation

A.

No

The common tendon of biceps femoris inserts on the head of the fibula, not the upper tibia.

B.

No

Biceps femoris flexes the knee and extends the hip (long head), but it does not flex the hip.

C.

Yes

The long head is innervated by the tibial division of the sciatic nerve, and the short head by the common fibular division.

D.

No

Its arterial supply comes from perforating branches of the profunda femoris, not the femoral artery directly.

Answer: C

245

Regarding the perforating veins of the lower limb, which is CORRECT?

A. They do not contain valves

B. They do not add to the musculovenous pump of the lower limb

C. They pierce the superficial and deep fascia of the lower limb

D. They ensure bloods flows from the superficial to the deep veins only

Here's the clear breakdown of this MCQ on perforating veins of the lower limb:

 

Question:

Regarding the perforating veins of the lower limb, which is CORRECT?

Option

Evaluation

A. They do not contain valves

❌ Incorrect – Perforating veins do contain valves, which are crucial to prevent backflow of blood from deep to superficial veins. Valve incompetence can lead to varicose veins.

B. They do not add to the musculovenous pump of the lower limb

❌ Incorrect – Perforating veins are an integral part of the musculovenous pump. Muscle contractions help push blood through perforators from superficial to deep veins and up toward the heart.

C. They pierce the superficial and deep fascia of the lower limb

✅ Correct – This is true. Perforating veins pierce the deep fascia (also known as crural fascia) to connect superficial veins (like the great saphenous) with deep veins (like the femoral or popliteal veins).

D. They ensure blood flows from the superficial to the deep veins only

❌ Incorrect – While valves in perforating veins normally direct blood flow from superficial to deep, in cases of valvular incompetence, reverse flow can occur. So they do not guarantee unidirectional flow.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. They pierce the superficial and deep fascia of the lower limb

🧠 Clinical Pearl:

Valve failure in perforating veins contributes to chronic venous insufficiency and varicose veins, especially when superficial venous pressure rises.

Let me know if you'd like a diagram of lower limb venous anatomy or a quick table of named perforators (e.g., Cockett, Boyd, Dodd).

246

Regarding cerebral veins which of the following statements iscorrect?

A. The veins lie subdurally

B. They do not follow the arterial pattern

C. The great cerebral vein drains into the cavernous sinus

D. They are thin walled and have valves

The correct answer is: B. They do not follow the arterial pattern

 

✅ Explanation of the Correct Answer:

  • Cerebral veins do not closely follow the pattern of cerebral arteries like in other parts of the body.
  • Instead, they have a more variable and independent course, and drain into the dural venous sinuses.

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

  • A. The veins lie subdurally
    → Incorrect: Cerebral veins lie in the subarachnoid space and cross the subdural space to drain into the dural venous sinuses. The bridging veins are particularly vulnerable here.
  • C. The great cerebral vein drains into the cavernous sinus
    → Incorrect: The great cerebral vein (of Galen) joins the inferior sagittal sinus to form the straight sinus, not the cavernous sinus.
  • D. They are thin-walled and have valves
    → Incorrect: Cerebral veins are thin-walled but lack valves, which is clinically important because infections from the face can retrogradely spread into the brain (e.g., via the cavernous sinus).

 

✅ Final Answer: B. They do not follow the arterial pattern

247

Regarding the lymphatic drainage of the upper limb, which of the following is correct?

A. Deep lymphatics travel follows the superficial veins

B. Superficial lymphatic drainage occurs form lymphatic plexuses in the skin of the fingers, palm and dorsum of the hand

C. Superficial lymphatics follows the arteries

D. Lymphatics of the hand drains into the central lymph nodes in the axilla

 

Thought for 4 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

Deep lymphatic vessels follow the deep veins, not the superficial veins. Superficial lymphatics follow the superficial veins, while the deep lymphatics course with the accompanying veins of the arteries (i.e., deep veins) Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Correct

Superficial lymphatic vessels arise from lymphatic plexuses in the skin of the fingers, palm, and dorsum of the hand, then ascend mostly with the superficial veins (cephalic and basilic) toward the cubital and axillary lymph nodes Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Incorrect

Superficial lymphatics do not follow the arteries; they follow the superficial veins. It is the deep lymphatics that accompany deep veins (which bear the same names as the major arteries) Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Incorrect

While superficial lymphatics from the hand eventually drain into axillary nodes, they first pass through cubital (and sometimes delto-pectoral) lymph nodes. They do not drain directly into the central axillary nodes without passing through these intermediary stations Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

248

Which of the knee bursae is the most likely to lead to a septic arthritis?

A. Anserine

B. Popliteus

C. Gastrocnemius

D. Suprapatellar

 

Thought for 9 seconds

 

Leads to Septic Arthritis?

Brief Explanation

A. Anserine bursa

No

The anserine bursa lies deep to the tendons of sartorius, gracilis, and semitendinosus, and does not communicate with the knee joint cavity, so infection here is unlikely to spread into the joint. Moore - Clinically Orie…

B. Popliteus bursa

No

Although the popliteus bursa opens into the synovial cavity of the knee, it is small and less commonly involved in septic bursitis leading to arthritis compared to the suprapatellar bursa. Moore - Clinically Orie…

C. Gastrocnemius bursa

No

The gastrocnemius bursa is an extension of the synovial cavity but is located deep to the medial head of gastrocnemius; infection here rarely precedes septic arthritis in clinical practice. Moore - Clinically Orie…

D. Suprapatellar bursa

Yes

The suprapatellar bursa communicates freely with the knee joint cavity. An infection in this bursa can readily spread into the joint, making it most likely to cause septic arthritis. Moore - Clinically Orie…

 

Answer: D Suprapatellar bursa

249

You are having difficulty obtaining venous accessing on a patient in a resuscitation situation and decide to perform a venous cutdown. The great saphenous vein is located relative to which structure in the lower limb?

A. Posterior to the medial malleolus

B. Anterior to the medial malleolus

C. Anterior to the lateral malleolus

D. Posterior to the lateral malleolus

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

The great saphenous vein does not pass posterior to the medial malleolus. That location corresponds to the small saphenous vein, which courses behind the lateral malleolus on the fibular side Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Correct

The great saphenous vein ascends anterior to the medial malleolus. This consistent landmark is used for a saphenous vein cutdown in emergency venous access Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Incorrect

The anterior aspect of the lateral malleolus is not traversed by the great saphenous vein. Veins on the lateral side include the small saphenous vein posteriorly and perforators, but not the great saphenous Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Incorrect

The great saphenous vein does not lie posterior to the lateral malleolus; that is the course of the small saphenous vein Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

250

With regard to cutaneous innervation of the lower limb, which of the following statements is correct?

A. The deep peroneal nerve supplies the 3rd digital cleft

B. The medial plantar nerve supplies a greater area than the lateral

C. The sural nerve supplies the medial malleolus

D. The superficial peroneal nerve supplies the 1st inter-digital cleft

 

Thought for 5 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

The deep fibular (peroneal) nerve supplies the skin of the first interdigital cleft (between toes 1 and 2), not the third interdigital cleft. It does not extend to the spaces between toes 3 and 4 Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Correct

The medial plantar nerve supplies a larger area of skin on the sole—namely the medial three and a half toes and adjacent sole—whereas the lateral plantar nerve supplies only the lateral one and a half digits. Thus, the medial plantar covers more cutaneous territory than the lateral Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Incorrect

The sural nerve supplies the lateral aspect of the foot and passes posterior to the lateral malleolus; it does not supply the medial malleolus. Innervation of the medial malleolus region is via the saphenous nerve Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Incorrect

The superficial fibular (peroneal) nerve supplies most of the dorsum of the foot and all toes except the web between the first and second toes—it specifically excludes that first interdigital cleft, which is supplied by the deep fibular nerve Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

251

Regarding the anatomy of the spleen, which isCORRECT?

A. The diaphragmatic surface of the spleen is concave to fit the convexity of the diaphragm.

B. The approximate size of the spleen is 12cm long and 7 cm wide

C. Lymph drainage of the spleen is via the pancreaticoduodenal nodes

D. The spleen is often palpable through the anterolateral abdominal wall

Here’s a detailed breakdown of the MCQ on spleen anatomy, focusing on identifying the correct statement:

 

Question:

Regarding the anatomy of the spleen, which is CORRECT?

Option

Statement

Evaluation

A

The diaphragmatic surface of the spleen is concave to fit the convexity of the diaphragm.

❌ Incorrect – The diaphragmatic surface of the spleen is convex, not concave, to fit snugly against the concave inferior surface of the diaphragm.

B

The approximate size of the spleen is 12 cm long and 7 cm wide

✅ Correct – This is the correct statement. A normal adult spleen is typically about 12 cm in length, 7 cm wide, and 3–4 cm thick. A common memory aid is “1 x 3 x 5 inches, weighs 7 oz, and lies between ribs 9–11”.

C

Lymph drainage of the spleen is via the pancreaticoduodenal nodes

❌ Incorrect – The spleen drains lymph primarily to the pancreaticosplenic lymph nodes, located along the splenic artery, and then to celiac nodes — not pancreaticoduodenal nodes (which drain parts of the pancreas and duodenum).

D

The spleen is often palpable through the anterolateral abdominal wall

❌ Incorrect – In a healthy individual, the spleen is not normally palpable because it lies under the rib cage in the left upper quadrant (LUQ). It becomes palpable only when enlarged (splenomegaly).

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. The approximate size of the spleen is 12 cm long and 7 cm wide

🧠 Memory Aid for Spleen:

“1 x 3 x 5 inches, 7 oz, ribs 9–11, T10 axis”

Let me know if you'd like a spleen surface anatomy diagram or a table of its anatomical relations!

252

In the lateral compartment of the leg, which of the following statements is correct?

A. The peroneus longus arises only from the fibula

B. The muscles are supplied by the deep peroneal nerve

C. The blood supply is the anterior tibial artery

D. The peroneal muscle tendons share the same tendon sheath as they pass the lateral malleolus

 

Thought for 10 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

While fibularis (peroneus) longus does originate from the head and superior two-thirds of the lateral surface of the fibula, it also gains attachments to adjacent intermuscular septa and deep fascia—not “only” from the fibular shaft itself .

B

Incorrect

The lateral compartment muscles (fibularis longus and brevis) are innervated by the superficial fibular (peroneal) nerve, not the deep fibular nerve Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Incorrect

There is no single named artery running through the lateral compartment; instead, it is supplied by perforating branches of the anterior tibial artery superiorly and the fibular artery inferiorly Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Correct

The tendons of fibularis longus and brevis share a common synovial sheath as they pass posterior and inferior to the lateral malleolus beneath the superior fibular retinaculum Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

253

What structure makes up the lateral border of the deep inguinal ring?

A. Lacunar ligament

B. Transversalis fascia

C. External oblique muscle

D. Inferior epigastric artery

 

Thought for 5 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

The lacunar ligament (of Gimbernat) forms the medial boundary of the subinguinal space, not the deep inguinal ring. It does not contribute to the margins of the ring itself Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Correct

The deep (internal) inguinal ring is an evagination of the transversalis fascia. Its “wall” is composed of that fascia, which therefore makes up the lateral border of the opening .

C

Incorrect

The external oblique aponeurosis contributes to the anterior wall of the inguinal canal and forms the superficial ring, but it does not form the border of the deep inguinal ring Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Incorrect

The inferior epigastric artery lies medial to the deep inguinal ring, marking its medial boundary; it is not on the lateral side of the ring Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

254

Which of the following statements concerning the femoral triangle is false?

A. Femoral vein receives the great saphenous and the deep femoral vein

B. Adductor longus is a medial boundary

C. The lateral border is the medial border of sartorius

D. It contains superficial inguinal lymph nodes and associated lymphatic vessels

 

Thought for 6 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

The femoral vein indeed receives both the great saphenous and the deep (profunda femoris) veins as its proximal tributaries within the femoral sheath Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Incorrect

The medial boundary of the femoral triangle is formed by the lateral border of the adductor longus muscle Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Incorrect

The lateral boundary of the triangle is the sartorius muscle; specifically, it is bounded by the medial border of sartorius Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Correct

The femoral triangle contains deep inguinal lymph nodes and their lymphatic vessels, not superficial inguinal nodes. Superficial inguinal nodes lie in the superficial fascia over the thigh, outside the femoral sheath Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

255

In relation to the brachial plexus, which statement iscorrect?

A. There are 7 divisions of the trunks

B. The nerve to subclavius is a branch form the trunks

C. The roots pass between the middle and posterior scalene muscles

D. The axillary nerve is derived from the lateral cord

 

Thought for 5 seconds

 

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation

A

Incorrect

Each of the three trunks of the brachial plexus divides into an anterior and a posterior division (total 6 divisions), not seven. “Each trunk of the brachial plexus divides into anterior and posterior divisions” Moore - Clinically Orie….

B

Correct

The nerve to subclavius (subclavian nerve) arises from the superior trunk of the brachial plexus, carrying fibers from C5 and C6. “Subclavian nerve … Superior trunk, receiving fibers from C5, C6 and often C4” Moore - Clinically Orie….

C

Incorrect

The roots of the brachial plexus pass between the anterior and middle scalene muscles, not between the middle and posterior scalene. “The roots of the plexus usually pass through the gap between the anterior and the middle scalene muscles” Moore - Clinically Orie….

D

Incorrect

The axillary nerve is a branch of the posterior cord, not the lateral cord. “FIGURE 6.46 D shows the axillary nerve arising from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus” Moore - Clinically Orie….

 

256

Which is true as regards the layers of the foot?

A. The third layer comprises the flexor digitorum brevis

B. The fourth layer contains the tendons of tibialis posterior and peroneus brevis

C. The 2nd layer comprises the long tendons and the lumbricals

D. The plantar aponeurosis can be regarded as the 5th layer

Certainly! Here's the correctly formatted table and explanation for the question on the layers of the sole of the foot:

 

Question:

Which is true as regards the layers of the foot?

Option

Statement

Evaluation

A

The third layer comprises the flexor digitorum brevis

❌ Incorrect – The flexor digitorum brevis is in the first (most superficial) layer of the sole, not the third.

B

The fourth layer contains the tendons of tibialis posterior and peroneus brevis

❌ Incorrect – The fourth layer contains the tendons of tibialis posterior and fibularis (peroneus) longus, not peroneus brevis. Peroneus brevis inserts on the 5th metatarsal and does not enter the sole.

C

The 2nd layer comprises the long tendons and the lumbricals

✅ Correct – This is true. The second layer of the sole includes:

 

  • Tendons of flexor digitorum longus (FDL) and flexor hallucis longus (FHL)
  • Lumbricals
  • Quadratus plantae |
    |     D | The plantar aponeurosis can be regarded as the 5th layer | ❌ Incorrect – The plantar aponeurosis is a thickened part of deep fascia overlying the first muscular layer. It is not considered a muscular layer, and there is no anatomical “5th layer” of the sole. |

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. The 2nd layer comprises the long tendons and the lumbricals

 

Let me know if you'd like a labeled cross-section diagram or a mnemonic to remember the foot muscle layers!

257

The mitral valve is located posterior to which costal cartilage?

A. 3rd costal cartilage

B. 2nd costal cartilage

C. 4th costal cartilage

D. 5th costal cartilage

Here's the accurate breakdown of the MCQ on mitral valve anatomical position:

 

Question:

The mitral valve is located posterior to which costal cartilage?

Option

Evaluation

A. 3rd costal cartilage

❌ Incorrect – This is the approximate location of the aortic valve, not the mitral valve.

B. 2nd costal cartilage

❌ Incorrect – This is too superior; it corresponds to the pulmonary valve area.

C. 4th costal cartilage

❌ Incorrect – This corresponds more to the tricuspid valve area.

D. 5th costal cartilage

✅ Correct – The mitral valve lies posterior to the left 4th–5th costal cartilages, with its surface projection near the left 5th costal cartilage, just medial to the midclavicular line. This is also the site for auscultation of the mitral valve (apex beat).

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. 5th costal cartilage

🩺 Clinical Tip:

Auscultation of the mitral valve is best performed at the apex of the heart, in the 5th intercostal space, midclavicular line — just below the 5th costal cartilage.

Let me know if you'd like a diagram of the cardiac valve surface landmarks or auscultation points!

258

Which of the following carries sensory supply of the epigastric region?

A. Sympathetic fibres travelling with greater splanchnic nerve

B. Visceral afferent fibres synapsing in the T7-8 sensory ganglia in spinal cord

C. Parasympathetic fibres synapsing in the celiac plexus

D. Sympathetic trunks

Here's the clear and detailed breakdown of the MCQ on sensory supply of the epigastric region:

 

Question:

Which of the following carries sensory supply of the epigastric region?

Option

Evaluation

A. Sympathetic fibres travelling with greater splanchnic nerve

❌ Incorrect – Sympathetic fibers in the greater splanchnic nerve are preganglionic motor (efferent) fibers, not sensory. While visceral afferents may travel along the same path, the sympathetic fibers themselves are not sensory.

B. Visceral afferent fibres synapsing in the T7–8 sensory ganglia in spinal cord

✅ Correct – This is true. The epigastric region (T7–T9 dermatome) receives visceral sensory input via afferent fibers that enter the spinal cord at T7–T8. These fibers have cell bodies in the dorsal root ganglia (sensory ganglia), and do not synapse until reaching the dorsal horn.

C. Parasympathetic fibres synapsing in the celiac plexus

❌ Incorrect – Parasympathetic fibers (mainly from the vagus nerve) pass through the celiac plexus, but they are motor to the viscera, not sensory. Also, parasympathetic fibers do not carry somatic sensation like pain from the epigastrium.

D. Sympathetic trunks

❌ Incorrect – The sympathetic trunks carry both sympathetic efferents and some afferents, but they are not the direct carriers of specific sensory supply to the epigastric region. The correct route is via splanchnic nerves → spinal nerve → dorsal root ganglia → spinal cord (T7–T8).

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Visceral afferent fibres synapsing in the T7–8 sensory ganglia in spinal cord

🧠 Clinical Insight:

Referred pain from foregut structures (e.g., stomach, pancreas) is often felt in the epigastrium, corresponding to T6–T9 dermatomes, due to visceral afferent fibers entering the spinal cord at those levels.

Let me know if you'd like a diagram showing visceral pain referral zones or the autonomic pathways!

259

Which of the following muscles causes dorsiflexion and inversion of the ankle and foot?

A. Tibialis posterior

B. Tibialis anterior

C. Extensor hallucis longus

D. Peroneus tertius

Here's the detailed breakdown of this MCQ on foot and ankle muscle actions:

 

Question:

Which of the following muscles causes dorsiflexion and inversion of the ankle and foot?

Option

Evaluation

A. Tibialis posterior

❌ Incorrect – Tibialis posterior causes inversion but not dorsiflexion. It is a plantarflexor, not a dorsiflexor.

B. Tibialis anterior

✅ Correct – Tibialis anterior is the primary muscle responsible for dorsiflexion of the ankle and inversion of the foot. It originates from the lateral tibia and inserts on the medial cuneiform and 1st metatarsal, pulling the foot up and inward.

C. Extensor hallucis longus

❌ Incorrect – This muscle contributes to dorsiflexion, but not inversion. Its main action is extension of the big toe.

D. Peroneus tertius

❌ Incorrect – Peroneus (fibularis) tertius assists in dorsiflexion but causes eversion, not inversion. It's functionally opposite to tibialis anterior.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Tibialis anterior

🦶 Memory tip:

“Tibialis anterior lifts and tilts inward” → Dorsiflexion + Inversion.

Let me know if you'd like a table comparing all leg compartment muscles and their actions!

260

A 65-year-old woman suffers a CVA and presents with right-sided hemiparesis. Where is the lesion?

A. MCA

B. ACA

C. Posterior communicating artery

D. Posterior cerebral artery

The correct answer is: A. Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)

 

✅ Explanation:

Right-sided hemiparesis indicates a lesion on the left side of the brain (due to the crossing of motor fibers in the medulla).

The Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) supplies the lateral surface of the cerebral hemisphere, including:

  • Primary motor cortex (especially for the face and upper limb)
  • Primary sensory cortex
  • Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas (in the dominant hemisphere)

A stroke in the left MCA is the most common cause of contralateral hemiparesis, especially affecting the face and arm more than the leg.

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

  • B. ACA (Anterior Cerebral Artery)
    → Supplies the medial parts of the frontal and parietal lobes → deficits would affect the contralateral leg more than the arm/face.
  • C. Posterior communicating artery
    → Not a major supplier of brain tissue itself. Aneurysms here may cause cranial nerve III palsy, but not hemiparesis.
  • D. PCA (Posterior Cerebral Artery)
    → Supplies the occipital lobe and inferior temporal lobe → strokes here cause visual deficits, not motor weakness.

 

✅ Final Answer: A. Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)

261

Which nerve root would be affected if there was numbness to the anterior lower leg and medial three toes?

A. L4

B. L3

C. L5

D. S1

The correct answer is: A. L4

 

✅ Explanation (based on Moore's Clinically Oriented Anatomy):

To localize nerve root lesions, we use dermatome maps:

 

Dermatomal Distribution Relevant to This Question:

  • L3 – anterior thigh
  • ✅ L4 – anterior lower leg, medial malleolus, and medial three toes
  • L5 – dorsum of the foot and great toe
  • S1 – lateral foot and heel, posterior leg

 

❓ What the question describes:

Numbness over the anterior lower leg and medial three toes

→ This matches the L4 dermatome

  • Sensory territory includes:
    • Anterior shin
    • Medial foot
    • First to third toes (medial side)

 

✅ Final Answer: A. L4

262

With regard to the sternoclavicular joint, which of the following statements is true?

A. Contains two fibrocartilaginous discs

B. Is supplied by nerve branches from C8 and T1

C. Is the fulcrum of movements of the sterno-clavicular joint

D. Is mostly stabilised by the sternoclavicular ligament

The correct answer is: C. Is the fulcrum of movements of the sternoclavicular joint

 

✅ Explanation (from Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy):

The sternoclavicular (SC) joint is a saddle-type synovial joint that connects the upper limb to the axial skeleton. Despite its small articular surfaces, it allows significant motion due to its structural support.

 

Evaluating Each Option:

 

A. "Contains two fibrocartilaginous discs" – ❌ Incorrect

  • The SC joint contains a single fibrocartilaginous articular disc, not two.
  • This intra-articular disc helps absorb shock and improves joint congruity.

 

B. "Is supplied by nerve branches from C8 and T1" – ❌ Incorrect

  • The sternoclavicular joint receives innervation from:
    • The medial supraclavicular nerve (from C3–C4)
    • The nerve to subclavius (from C5–C6)
  • Not from C8–T1, which are more associated with the lower brachial plexus.

 

C. "Is the fulcrum of movements of the sternoclavicular joint" – ✅ Correct

  • The sternoclavicular joint acts as the fulcrum for movements of the clavicle, especially in shoulder elevation, depression, protraction, and retraction.
  • It’s the pivot point that allows the scapula and clavicle to move together in upper limb motion.

 

D. "Is mostly stabilised by the sternoclavicular ligament" – ❌ Incorrect

  • While the sternoclavicular ligament does contribute to stability, the primary stabilizer is the costoclavicular ligament.
  • The costoclavicular ligament anchors the clavicle to the first rib and resists excessive elevation.

 

✅ Final Answer: C. Is the fulcrum of movements of the sternoclavicular joint

263

Regarding the internal jugular vein, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It runs deep to the two heads of sternocleidomastoid

B. It runs from the angle of the jaw to the proximal end of the clavicle

C. It lies medial to the carotid artery

D. It runs in close proximity to the thoracic duct

Let's evaluate each statement regarding the internal jugular vein (IJV):

  • A. It runs deep to the two heads of sternocleidomastoid
    This statement is CORRECT. The internal jugular vein descends through the neck, deep to the sternocleidomastoid muscle, lying initially between its sternal and clavicular heads, and then deep to the main belly of the muscle.
  • B. It runs from the angle of the jaw to the proximal end of the clavicle
    This statement is INCORRECT. The internal jugular vein begins in the jugular foramen at the base of the skull, which is roughly level with the mastoid process/earlobe, superior and slightly posterior to the angle of the jaw.1 It then descends to join the subclavian vein behind the medial end of the clavicle (not just the proximal end).
  • C. It lies medial to the carotid artery
    This statement is INCORRECT. The internal jugular vein lies lateral to the common carotid artery (and internal carotid artery superiorly) within the carotid sheath throughout most of its course in the neck.2
  • D. It runs in close proximity to the thoracic duct
    This statement is INCORRECT. The thoracic duct typically drains into the junction of the left internal jugular and left subclavian veins.3 While it terminates close to the left IJV, the IJV's general course is not described as running in close proximity to the thoracic duct along its length, which is a much smaller and more medially located structure ascending from the abdomen. The right lymphatic duct drains into the right IJV/subclavian junction.4

Therefore, the only correct statement is A.

The final answer is A​

 

 

264

Which cell is responsible for myelin formation in the CNS?

A. Schwann cells

B. Oligodendrocytes

C. Astrocytes

D. Dendrites

Here's the breakdown of the MCQ on myelin-forming cells in the central nervous system (CNS):

 

Question:

Which cell is responsible for myelin formation in the CNS?

Option

Evaluation

A. Schwann cells
