An 18-year-old male presents to the emergency department after being punched in the right eye. He complains of numbness to his right cheek. A branch of which nerve is likely damaged?

A. Maxillary

B. Mandibular

C. Facial

D. Vagus

The correct answer is: A. Maxillary

 

Explanation:

The maxillary nerve (V2) is the second division of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V). It is purely sensory and innervates:

  • Lower eyelid
  • Upper lip
  • Cheek
  • Side of the nose
  • Upper teeth and gums

 

Clinical Clue in the Question:

  • Trauma to the orbit (punched in the eye) raises concern for an orbital floor fracture, which can injure the infraorbital nerve, a branch of the maxillary nerve (V2).
  • This leads to numbness of the cheek, upper lip, and upper gum.

 

Why the other options are incorrect:

  • B. Mandibular (V3): Supplies lower jaw and lower teeth, and has motor function (e.g., mastication). Not related to cheek sensation.
  • C. Facial (VII): Mainly motor to muscles of facial expression. It also carries taste and parasympathetic fibers, but not cheek sensation.
  • D. Vagus (X): Autonomic nerve supplying thoracoabdominal viscera and some pharyngeal muscles. Not involved in facial sensory innervation.

 

✅ Final Answer: A. Maxillary

330

A middle-aged man presents to the emergency department with left-sided flank pain and is found to have a ureteric calculus. Nerve fibres carry afferent supply from the ureter to which vertebral level?

A. T10-T12

B. T8-T10

C. T11-L2

D. L2-L4

Here is the correct answer with expert explanation in table format:

 

🩺 Ureteric Pain – Afferent Nerve Supply and Spinal Levels

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. T10–T12

❌ Incorrect

These segments may receive referred pain from other abdominal organs (e.g. kidneys), but ureteric afferents reach lower spinal levels.

B. T8–T10

❌ Incorrect

This level is too high for the ureter. These segments are more related to the liver, gallbladder, and upper GI tract.

C. T11–L2

✅ Correct

Visceral afferent fibers from the ureter travel with sympathetic fibers to the spinal cord levels T11 to L2. This is the primary pain pathway for ureteric colic, which is typically referred to the flank, lower abdomen, groin, or scrotum/labia depending on stone location.

D. L2–L4

❌ Incorrect

This is too low; L2–L4 primarily innervate lower limb structures, not visceral afferents from the ureter.

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. T11–L2

Let me know if you’d like a pain referral map for ureteric stones based on stone location (upper, middle, lower ureter).

331

Which muscle causes flexion of the distal phalanges?

A. Flexor pollices longus

B. Palmaris longus

C. Flexor digitorum profundus

D. Flexor digitorum superficialis

Here is the correct answer with detailed explanation in table format:

 

✋ Finger Flexion – Distal Phalanges

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Flexor pollicis longus

❌ Incorrect

This muscle flexes the distal phalanx of the thumb, not the fingers.

B. Palmaris longus

❌ Incorrect

Palmaris longus is a weak wrist flexor and does not act on the fingers directly.

C. Flexor digitorum profundus (FDP)

✅ Correct

FDP is the only muscle that flexes the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints of the fingers (digits 2–5). It inserts into the distal phalanges.

D. Flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS)

❌ Incorrect

FDS flexes the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints of the fingers, inserting into the middle phalanges.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Flexor digitorum profundus

Let me know if you’d like a full hand muscle chart showing their actions, insertions, and innervations.

332

What is the main nerve of the lateral compartment of the leg?

A. Deep fibular nerve

B. Lateral fibular nerve

C. Superficial fibular nerve

D. Common fibular nerve

Here is the correct answer with detailed explanation in table format:

 

🦵 Nerve Supply of the Lateral Compartment of the Leg

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Deep fibular nerve

❌ Incorrect

The deep fibular (peroneal) nerve supplies the anterior compartment of the leg (e.g., tibialis anterior, EDL, EHL).

B. Lateral fibular nerve

❌ Incorrect

There is no such named nerve as the "lateral fibular nerve." This is an incorrect term.

C. Superficial fibular nerve

✅ Correct

The superficial fibular (peroneal) nerve is the main nerve of the lateral compartment, supplying:

– Fibularis longus

– Fibularis brevis

It also provides cutaneous sensation to most of the dorsum of the foot.

D. Common fibular nerve

❌ Incorrect

The common fibular nerve is a parent nerve that bifurcates into the superficial and deep fibular nerves near the fibular neck.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: C. Superficial fibular nerve

Let me know if you’d like a full compartmental innervation and action chart for the leg.

333

In relation to Hiltons law, which nerve does not supply the hip joint?

A. Nerve to quadratus femoris

B. Femoral

C. Inferior gluteal

D. Obturator

The correct answer is:

C. Inferior gluteal

 

✅ Explanation — Hilton’s Law:

“The nerve supplying a muscle that moves a joint also supplies the joint and the skin overlying the insertion of the muscle.”

Based on this principle, the hip joint receives innervation from nerves that supply muscles acting on it:

 

✅ Nerves that do supply the hip joint:

  • Femoral nerve — supplies anterior thigh muscles (e.g., iliopsoas) → involved in hip flexion
  • Obturator nerve — supplies medial thigh muscles (e.g., adductors) → involved in hip adduction
  • Nerve to quadratus femoris — supplies posterior hip muscles (quadratus femoris and inferior gemellus) → lateral rotators

 

❌ Nerve that does not supply the hip joint:

  • Inferior gluteal nerve — innervates gluteus maximus, which mainly acts on the hip extension, but this nerve does not send articular branches to the hip joint.

Instead, the superior gluteal nerve (which supplies gluteus medius and minimus) does send articular branches to the hip joint.

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., section on hip joint innervation and Hilton’s lawMoore - Clinically Orie….

334

Which of the following nerves is not a cutaneous branch of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve CNV supplying the face and scull

A. External nasal

B. Zygomaticotemporal

C. Lacrimal

D. Supratrochlear

The correct answer is: B. Zygomaticotemporal

 

Explanation:

The ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) is purely sensory and gives off several cutaneous branches to the forehead, scalp, upper eyelid, and nose. Its major cutaneous branches include:

 

✅ Cutaneous branches of the Ophthalmic (V1) division:

  1. Lacrimal nerve – to lateral upper eyelid and conjunctiva
  2. Supratrochlear nerve – to medial forehead and scalp
  3. Supraorbital nerve – to forehead and anterior scalp
  4. Infratrochlear nerve – to medial canthus and upper nose
  5. External nasal nerve – from the anterior ethmoidal branch of nasociliary, to dorsum and tip of the nose

 

❌ Zygomaticotemporal nerve is a branch of the zygomatic nerve, which comes from the maxillary division (V2) — not the ophthalmic division (V1).

  • It supplies the skin over the anterior temple.

 

✅ Final Answer: B. Zygomaticotemporal

335

Regarding the ocular muscles, which of the following statements is correct?

A. Superior rectus makes eye turn up and out

B. Abducens paralysis makes eye turn down and out

C. In trochlear paralysis, the eye cannot look upwards when turned out

D. Combined action of superior rectus and inferior oblique causes vertical upward movement

✅ Correct Answer: D. Combined action of superior rectus and inferior oblique causes vertical upward movement

 

🧠 Explanation of Each Option:

 

A. Superior rectus makes eye turn up and out

❌ Incorrect

  • Superior rectus elevates the eye but also causes adduction and intorsion, so it moves the eye up and in, not up and out.

 

B. Abducens paralysis makes eye turn down and out

❌ Incorrect

  • Abducens nerve (CN VI) innervates the lateral rectus muscle (abduction).
  • In its paralysis, the eye is pulled medially (unopposed medial rectus), not down and out.
  • "Down and out" is a sign of oculomotor (CN III) palsy, not abducens.

 

C. In trochlear paralysis, the eye cannot look upwards when turned out

❌ Incorrect

  • Trochlear nerve (CN IV) supplies superior oblique, which depresses the eye when it is adducted, not abducted.
  • So in trochlear palsy, the patient has trouble looking down when the eye is adducted (e.g., walking down stairs).

 

D. Combined action of superior rectus and inferior oblique causes vertical upward movement

✅ Correct

  • These two muscles counteract each other's secondary actions (adduction vs. abduction, intorsion vs. extorsion), resulting in pure elevation of the eye.
  • Hence, looking straight up involves the coordinated action of both muscles.

 

✅ Final Answer: D. Combined action of superior rectus and inferior oblique causes vertical upward movement

336

Which of the following bones is attached to both flexor and extensor retinaculum?

A. Hamate

B. Scaphoid

C. Pisiform

D. Triquetral

The correct answer is:

A. Hamate

 

✅ Explanation:

The flexor and extensor retinacula (bands of thick fascia) span across the wrist and attach to several carpal bones to form tunnels that guide tendons.

 

Flexor Retinaculum (Transverse Carpal Ligament):

  • Medial attachments: Pisiform and hook of hamate
  • Lateral attachments: Scaphoid and trapezium

Extensor Retinaculum:

  • Attaches to:
    • Lateral radius
    • Medial ulna, pisiform, and triquetral
    • Also blends with the fascia over the dorsal carpal bones, including the hamate

✔️ The hamate is involved in the attachment of both:

  • Flexor retinaculum (via its hook)
  • Extensor retinaculum (via blending fascia and its position in the carpal arch)

 

❌ Why Others Are Incorrect:

  • B. Scaphoid — Only attaches laterally to the flexor retinaculum, not the extensor.
  • C. Pisiform — Attaches medially to the flexor and extensor retinacula, but is a sesamoid bone in the FCU tendon, not directly involved in spanning both retinacula.
  • D. Triquetral — Involved in extensor retinaculum, not in flexor retinaculum.

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., section on carpal tunnel, retinacula, and attachments of wrist fasciaeMoore - Clinically Orie….

337

Which of the following structures is not involved in vocal cord movement?

A. Vocalis

B. Posterior cricoarytenoid

C. Thyroarytenoid

D. Aryepiglottics

The correct answer is:

D. Aryepiglottics — ✅ Not involved in vocal cord movement

 

✅ Explanation:

The movement of the vocal cords (true vocal folds) is controlled by intrinsic laryngeal muscles, which act on the arytenoid cartilages to adjust tension, position, and length of the cords for phonation and breathing.

 

Muscles involved in vocal cord movement:

  • A. Vocalis — ✅
    • Fine-tunes tension of the vocal cords (part of thyroarytenoid)
  • B. Posterior cricoarytenoid — ✅
    • The only muscle that abducts (opens) the vocal cords, allowing breathing
  • C. Thyroarytenoid — ✅
    • Relaxes the vocal cords; helps in lowering pitch

 

D. Aryepiglottic muscle — ❌

  • This muscle acts to constrict the laryngeal inlet during swallowing
  • It is not involved in moving the vocal cords themselves

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., section on laryngeal muscles and functions of the vocal cordsMoore - Clinically Orie….

338

What is meant by the term heterotopic bones?

A. Supernumerary bone formation when additional ossification centers appear

B. Cartilage that has undergone bony metaplasia

C. Bone that forms during fracture healing

D. Bone formation in tissues

The correct answer is: D. Bone formation in tissues

 

✅ Explanation:

Heterotopic bones refer to bone that forms in abnormal (non-skeletal) tissues, such as:

  • Skeletal muscle
  • Connective tissue
  • Around joints or in soft tissue after trauma

 

🔍 Key points about heterotopic ossification:

  • It is pathological (unlike normal bone formation).
  • Commonly occurs after:
    • Trauma
    • Burns
    • Spinal cord injury
    • Orthopedic surgery (e.g., hip replacement)

 

📌 Let's examine the other options:

  • A. Supernumerary bone formation when additional ossification centers appear
    → This refers to accessory bones, not heterotopic bones.
  • B. Cartilage that has undergone bony metaplasia
    → This could describe endochondral ossification or metaplasia, but it’s not the definition of heterotopic bone.
  • C. Bone that forms during fracture healing
    → This is normal bone repair, not heterotopic.

 

✅ Final Answer: D. Bone formation in tissues

339

The contents of the posterior triangle of the neck include which of the following?

A. Second part of the subclavian artery

B. Occipital lymph nodes

C. Superior belly of omohyoid muscle

D. Cervical plexus

Yes — here's the verified information from Moore's Clinically Oriented Anatomy (7th Ed.):

✅ Correct contents of the posterior triangle (lateral cervical region):

According to Moore, the posterior triangle is subdivided by the inferior belly of the omohyoid into:

  • Occipital triangle
  • Omoclavicular (subclavian) triangle

These contain:

  • Cervical plexus (cutaneous branches)
  • Spinal accessory nerve (CN XI)
  • External jugular vein
  • Third part of the subclavian artery
  • Occipital lymph nodes
  • Inferior belly of the omohyoid (not the superior belly)

→ Therefore, the correct answer to your original question is: D. Cervical plexus, which is a confirmed content of the posterior triangleMoore - Clinically Orie….

 

❌ Clarifications on other options:

  • A. Second part of subclavian artery – False: this part lies posterior to anterior scalene, not in the posterior triangleMoore - Clinically Orie….
  • B. Occipital lymph nodes – True: present in the occipital triangleMoore - Clinically Orie….
  • C. Superior belly of omohyoid – False: it's part of the anterior triangle, not the posterior triangleMoore - Clinically Orie….

Let me know if you'd like a labeled diagram of the triangle or further breakdown of its subdivisions.

340

Which is INCORRECT regarding the sciatic nerve?

A. The sciatic nerve runs inferolateraly under the gluteus maximus muscle

B. The sciatic nerve receives the sciatic artery, a branch of the superior gluteal artery

C. The sciatic nerve is the most lateral nerve entering the greater sciatic foramen

D. The sciatic nerve is the largest nerve in the body

The correct answer is:

B. The sciatic nerve receives the sciatic artery, a branch of the superior gluteal artery — ✅ INCORRECT

 

✅ Explanation of Each Option:

 

A. The sciatic nerve runs inferolaterally under the gluteus maximus muscle — ✅ Correct

  • After exiting the greater sciatic foramen (usually below piriformis), the sciatic nerve runs inferolaterally beneath the gluteus maximus toward the posterior thigh.

 

B. The sciatic nerve receives the sciatic artery, a branch of the superior gluteal artery — ❌ Incorrect

  • There is no "sciatic artery" branch from the superior gluteal artery supplying the sciatic nerve.
  • If present, the sciatic artery is an embryological remnant, rarely persisting into adulthood.
  • The sciatic nerve is primarily supplied by branches from the inferior gluteal artery, not the superior gluteal.

 

C. The sciatic nerve is the most lateral nerve entering the greater sciatic foramen — ✅ Correct

  • Among the structures passing through the greater sciatic foramen, the sciatic nerve is located most laterally.

 

D. The sciatic nerve is the largest nerve in the body — ✅ Correct

  • The sciatic nerve is indeed the largest and longest nerve in the human body, formed from L4–S3 nerve roots.

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., section on sciatic nerve anatomy, gluteal region, and neurovascular supply .

341

All the following areboundariesof the named triangles with the exception of?

A. Digastric and carotid triangles

B. Digastric and submental triangles

C. Muscular and digastric triangles

D. Muscular and carotid triangles

 

342

Features of the scalp include all EXCEPT?

A. The arteries and nerves run in the second layer of the scalp

B. There are no lymphnodes within the scalp

C. Arterial supply is by the internal and external carotids

D. The auriculotemporal and occipital nerves innervate the posterior part of the scalp

Here is the correct answer with detailed explanation in table format:

 

🧠 Scalp – Features Review

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. The arteries and nerves run in the second layer of the scalp

✅ True

The second layer of the scalp is the dense connective tissue layer, where nerves and blood vessels are located. It anchors them tightly, which is why scalp wounds bleed profusely.

B. There are no lymph nodes within the scalp

❌ False (Correct Answer)

This is incorrect. While there are no lymph nodes deep within the scalp proper, lymphatic drainage from the scalp is to pericranial lymph nodes such as the mastoid, occipital, and parotid nodes, which lie at the margins of the scalp. So lymphatic involvement exists.

C. Arterial supply is by the internal and external carotids

✅ True

The scalp is richly supplied by branches from both:

– Internal carotid: supratrochlear, supraorbital

– External carotid: superficial temporal, occipital, posterior auricular

D. The auriculotemporal and occipital nerves innervate the posterior part of the scalp

✅ True

The auriculotemporal nerve (branch of CN V3) supplies the temporal region, and greater and lesser occipital nerves supply the posterior scalp.

 

 

❌ Correct Answer: B. There are no lymph nodes within the scalp

Let me know if you'd like a summary table of scalp layers, blood supply, and innervation.

343

Which of the following statements is true in relation to the trachea?

A. Its lower end is behind the manubrium

B. Enters the thoracic inlet slightly to the left of midline

C. Is supplied by glossopharyngeal nerve

D. Drains into the axillary lymph nodes

The correct answer is:

A. Its lower end is behind the manubrium — ✅ True

 

✅ Explanation:

The trachea is a fibrocartilaginous tube extending from the larynx (C6) to its bifurcation at the carina (T4/T5 level).

 

Review of Each Option:

  • A. Its lower end is behind the manubrium — ✅ True
    • The tracheal bifurcation occurs posterior to the manubrium at the level of the sternal angle (T4–T5).
  • B. Enters the thoracic inlet slightly to the left of midline — ❌ False
    • The trachea enters the thorax slightly to the right of the midline, not left.
  • C. Is supplied by glossopharyngeal nerve — ❌ False
    • Sensory and autonomic innervation of the trachea comes from the vagus nerve (CN X) and recurrent laryngeal nerves, not the glossopharyngeal (CN IX).
  • D. Drains into the axillary lymph nodes — ❌ False
    • The trachea drains into paratracheal and deep cervical lymph nodes, not the axillary nodes (which are associated with the upper limb and breast).

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., section on trachea anatomy, lymphatic drainage, and innervationMoore - Clinically Orie….

344

Which of the following structures pass through the lesser sciatic foramen?

A. Superior gemelli

B. Piriformis muscle

C. Inferior gemelli

D. Obturator internus

Here is a comparison table listing the structures that pass through the Greater and Lesser Sciatic Foramina:

 

🔄 Structures Passing Through Sciatic Foramina

Structure

Greater Sciatic Foramen

Lesser Sciatic Foramen

Muscles

Piriformis (only muscle passing through)

Tendon of obturator internus

Nerves

- Sciatic nerve

- Superior gluteal nerve

- Inferior gluteal nerve

- Pudendal nerve

- Nerve to obturator internus

- Nerve to quadratus femoris

- Posterior femoral cutaneous nerve

- Pudendal nerve (re-enters perineum)

- Nerve to obturator internus (re-enters to supply muscle)

Vessels

- Superior gluteal artery and vein

- Inferior gluteal artery and vein

- Internal pudendal artery and vein

- Internal pudendal artery and vein (re-enter perineum)

Route Note

Structures exit pelvis, most pass below piriformis, except superior gluteal bundle (above it)

Structures enter the perineum after looping around ischial spine

 

 

🧠 Mnemonic Tip:

“PIN enters the perineum through the Lesser foramen”:

Pudendal nerve, Internal pudendal vessels, Nerve to obturator internus.

 

Let me know if you want this in a diagram or if you'd like a similar table for inguinal canal vs femoral canal contents.

345

The lumbar plexus, whichis INCORRECT?

A. Comprises of nerves from L1-L4

B. Formed medial to the lumbar transverse processes

C. Is formed within the proximal attachment of the psoas major

D. Ilioinguinal and iliohypogastric are branches of the lumbar plexus

The correct answer is:

B. Formed medial to the lumbar transverse processes — ✅ INCORRECT

 

✅ Explanation:

Let’s assess each statement based on accurate lumbar plexus anatomy:

 

A. Comprises of nerves from L1–L4 — ✅ Correct

  • The lumbar plexus is formed by the ventral rami of L1 to L4, often with a contribution from T12.
  • It supplies the lower abdominal wall, anterior and medial thigh.

 

B. Formed medial to the lumbar transverse processes — ❌ Incorrect ✅

  • The lumbar plexus is actually formed within the posterior part of the psoas major muscle, and it lies posterior (not medial) to the lumbar transverse processes.
  • So this statement is false, making it the correct choice for the "incorrect" option.

 

C. Is formed within the proximal attachment of the psoas major — ✅ Correct

  • Yes — the plexus is embedded within the posterior part of the psoas major muscle.

 

D. Ilioinguinal and iliohypogastric are branches of the lumbar plexus — ✅ Correct

  • Both are L1 branches of the lumbar plexus.

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., section on lumbar plexus formation and branchesMoore - Clinically Orie….

346

You are examining a patient with an injury/cut to the wrist. He is unable to abduct his thumb. Other deficits which may be present include the following EXCEPT?

A. Loss of fine control of 2-3 digits

B. Loss of thumb opposition

C. Loss of sensation over the thumb

D. Complete loss of thumb flexion

Here is the correct answer with detailed clinical reasoning in table format:

 

✋ Wrist Injury – Median Nerve Deficit Question Review

Injury at the wrist affecting thumb abduction most likely indicates median nerve damage, particularly affecting the thenar muscles.

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Loss of fine control of 2–3 digits

✅ Possible

The 1st and 2nd lumbricals (supplied by the median nerve) allow fine motor control (e.g., precision grip) of index and middle fingers. These are affected.

B. Loss of thumb opposition

✅ Possible

The opponens pollicis, supplied by the recurrent branch of the median nerve, is crucial for opposing the thumb. Damage here impairs this action.

C. Loss of sensation over the thumb

✅ Possible

The palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve provides sensation to the lateral palm, and digital branches cover the thumb, index, and middle fingers.

D. Complete loss of thumb flexion

❌ Not expected (Correct Answer)

Not all thumb flexion is lost. While the flexor pollicis longus is innervated by the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve, which may be spared in wrist-level injuries, and the flexor pollicis brevis has dual innervation (superficial head by median, deep head by ulnar nerve). Therefore, some thumb flexion is retained.

 

 

❌ Correct Answer: D. Complete loss of thumb flexion

Let me know if you’d like a summary of median nerve injury at different levels (wrist vs elbow) and their clinical signs.

347

Which bone in a child is the same size as adult at birth?

A. Ethmoid bone

B. Parietal bone

C. Squamous bone

D. Auditory ossicles

Here is the correct answer with explanation in table format:

 

🧠 Bones at Birth – Size Comparison Question Review

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Ethmoid bone

❌ Incorrect

The ethmoid bone continues to grow after birth, especially as the nasal cavity and sinuses develop.

B. Parietal bone

❌ Incorrect

The parietal bones are relatively large in infants but not fully developed; they participate in fontanelles and grow significantly postnatally.

C. Squamous bone

❌ Incorrect

The squamous part of the temporal bone is underdeveloped at birth and continues to ossify and grow.

D. Auditory ossicles

✅ Correct

The auditory ossicles (malleus, incus, stapes) are fully developed and adult-sized at birth. This ensures functional hearing very early in life.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Auditory ossicles

Let me know if you'd like a chart comparing the postnatal growth patterns of various skull bones.

348

According to Hilton's law, the hip joint is supplied by the following nervesEXCEPT

A. Femoral

B. Sciatic

C. Obturator

D. Gluteal

According to Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy (7th Ed.), the hip joint receives its nerve supply from several nerves, consistent with Hilton’s Law (nerves supplying the muscles acting on the joint also supply the joint).

 

✅ Nerves that supply the hip joint:

  1. Femoral nerve
    • Via branches to the iliopsoas muscle
    • Supplies the anterior aspect of the hip joint
  2. Obturator nerve
    • Through branches to adductor muscles
    • Supplies the inferomedial aspect of the joint
  3. Superior gluteal nerve
    • Supplies muscles like gluteus medius and minimus
    • Contributes to the superior/posterosuperior part of the joint
  4. Nerve to quadratus femoris
    • A branch of the sacral plexus
    • Innervates quadratus femoris and inferior gemellus
    • Supplies the posteroinferior aspect of the joint

 

❌ Nerves that do NOT supply the hip joint:

  • Sciatic nerve — despite being close to the joint, it does not give articular branches to the hip.

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., section on hip joint innervation and clinical anatomy of referred painMoore - Clinically Orie….

Let me know if you'd like a diagram of the articular branches or their dermatomal overlap.

349

Which isnot trueregarding the carpal tunnel?

A. The tendon of flexor pollices longus lies in its own synovial sheath as it passes through the fibro-osseous tunnel.

B. All eight tendons of the superficial and deep flexors share a common tendon sheath, which completely invests the tendon

C. The ulnar nerve lies on the front of the reticulum lateral to the pisiform bone

D. The median nerve and the flexor tendons of the fingers and thumb pass through this tunnel

Let's analyze each statement regarding the carpal tunnel to identify the one that is NOT true:

  • A. The tendon of flexor pollicis longus lies in its own synovial sheath as it passes through the fibro-osseous tunnel.1
    This statement is TRUE. The Flexor Pollicis Longus (FPL) tendon, which flexes the thumb's interphalangeal joint, has its own dedicated synovial sheath (the radial bursa) as it passes through the carpal tunnel.2
  • B. All eight tendons of the superficial and deep flexors share a common tendon sheath, which completely invests the tendon.3
    This statement is TRUE. The four tendons of Flexor Digitorum Superficialis (FDS) and the four tendons of Flexor Digitorum Profundus (FDP) collectively pass through the carpal tunnel within a single, common flexor sheath (the ulnar bursa), which completely invests these eight tendons.4
  • C. The ulnar nerve lies on the front of the reticulum lateral to the pisiform bone.
    This statement is FALSE. The ulnar nerve (and ulnar artery) pass superficial to the flexor retinaculum, within Guyon's canal.5 Guyon's canal is located on the ulnar side of the wrist.6 Specifically, the ulnar nerve passes between the pisiform bone (medially) and the hook of the hamate (laterally).7 Therefore, it lies medial to the hook of the hamate and lateral to the pisiform bone, but crucially, it's superficial (anterior) to the flexor retinaculum, not on the front of the reticulum lateral to the pisiform bone in a way that suggests it's within the main tunnel.8 The wording "lateral to the pisiform bone" is correct, but "on the front of the reticulum" implying its position relative to the retinaculum is important. The key point is that it is not within the carpal tunnel itself but superficial to the retinaculum.
  • D. The median nerve and the flexor tendons of the fingers and thumb pass through this tunnel.9
    This statement is TRUE. The carpal tunnel contents include the median nerve, the four tendons of Flexor Digitorum Superficialis, the four tendons of Flexor Digitorum Profundus, and the single tendon of Flexor Pollicis Longus.

Given the analysis, the most definitively INCORRECT statement is C, as the ulnar nerve passes superficial to the flexor retinaculum, not "on the front of the reticulum" in a way that implies it's within the main tunnel or that its specific position relative to the pisiform isn't accurately described in the broader context of its relationship to the retinaculum. It's the nerve that doesn't go through the carpal tunnel proper.

The final answer is C​

350

Which lymph nodes drain the lower (inferior) anal canal?

A. Superficial inguinal

B. External iliac

C. Deep inguinal

D. Para-aortic

Here is the correct answer with detailed explanation in table format:

 

🦠 Lymphatic Drainage of the Anal Canal – Question Review

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Superficial inguinal

✅ Correct

The inferior (below pectinate line) portion of the anal canal is drained by superficial inguinal lymph nodes, due to its somatic (skin-like) origin and venous drainage to the systemic system.

B. External iliac

❌ Incorrect

The external iliac nodes drain pelvic organs like the upper vagina and cervix, not the lower anal canal.

C. Deep inguinal

❌ Partially true, but not the primary route

These nodes may receive some secondary drainage, especially from superficial inguinal nodes, but they are not the primary drainage site for the lower anal canal.

D. Para-aortic

❌ Incorrect

These are retroperitoneal nodes that drain gonads, kidneys, adrenals, and upper lumbar structures, not the anal canal.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Superficial inguinal

 

📌 Key Clinical Point:

  • Above pectinate line: Drains to internal iliac nodes (visceral)
  • Below pectinate line: Drains to superfi

351

Which of the following lies outside the blood-brain barrier?

A. Cerebellar vermis

B. Thalamus

C. Posterior pituitary

D. Temporal lobe

The correct answer is:

C. Posterior pituitary

 

✅ Explanation:

The posterior pituitary (neurohypophysis) is one of the specialized structures known as a circumventricular organ, which:

  • Lack a typical blood-brain barrier (BBB)
  • Allow for direct exchange between the blood and brain tissue
  • Are involved in hormone release, homeostasis, and chemosensation

 

🧠 Structures outside the blood-brain barrier include:

  • Posterior pituitary ✅
  • Pineal gland
  • Median eminence of the hypothalamus
  • Area postrema (vomiting center)
  • Subfornical organ
  • Organum vasculosum of the lamina terminalis (OVLT)

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

  • A. Cerebellar vermis — ❌ Within the BBB
  • B. Thalamus — ❌ Deep brain structure, protected by the BBB
  • D. Temporal lobe — ❌ Contains cortex and hippocampus, well-protected by the BBB

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., and associated neuroanatomy content on circumventricular organs and the blood-brain barrierMoore - Clinically Orie….

352

Which muscle is responsible for flexion of the DIPJ of the 4th and 5th digits?

A. Dorsal interossei

B. Flexor digitorum profundus

C. Lumbricals

D. Flexor carpi ulnaris

✅ Correct Answer: B. Flexor digitorum profundus

 

🧠 Explanation:

The Distal Interphalangeal Joint (DIPJ) of the fingers is flexed only by one muscle:

Muscle

Action

Flexor digitorum profundus (FDP)

Flexes the DIP joints of digits 2–5
  • For the 4th and 5th digits, the medial part of FDP is supplied by the ulnar nerve.
  • The lateral part (digits 2 and 3) is supplied by the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve.

 

❌ Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:

Option

Reason

A. Dorsal interossei

Abduct the fingers at MCP joints; do not flex DIP joints

C. Lumbricals

Flex MCP and extend PIP/DIP joints; they do not flex DIP

D. Flexor carpi ulnaris

Flexes and adducts the wrist; no action at finger joints

 

✅ Final Answer: B. Flexor digitorum profundus

353

Regarding the medial side of the ankle, which of the following statements is correct?

A. The great saphenous vein runs posterior to the malleolus

B. The deltoid ligament is continuous with the spring ligament

C. The anterior talo-fibular ligament strengthens the joint

D. The posterior tibial artery runs anterior to the malleolus

Here is the correct answer with a detailed anatomical explanation:

 

🦶 Medial Ankle – Question Review

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. The great saphenous vein runs posterior to the malleolus

❌ Incorrect

The great saphenous vein runs anterior to the medial malleolus, not posterior.

B. The deltoid ligament is continuous with the spring ligament

✅ Correct

The deltoid ligament (medial collateral ligament) of the ankle is partially continuous with the spring ligament (plantar calcaneonavicular ligament), especially the tibionavicular component, which helps support the medial arch.

C. The anterior talo-fibular ligament strengthens the joint

❌ Incorrect (and misleading)**

This ligament is on the lateral side of the ankle and is commonly sprained in inversion injuries. It does not relate to the medial side.

D. The posterior tibial artery runs anterior to the malleolus

❌ Incorrect

The posterior tibial artery runs posterior to the medial malleolus, along with the tibial nerve and tendons of Tom, Dick, and Harry (Tibialis posterior, flexor Digitorum longus, flexor Hallucis longus).

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. The deltoid ligament is continuous with the spring ligament

Let me know if you’d like a diagram of the medial ankle structures or a mnemonic to remember them.

354

The deep peroneal nerve travels through the lower leg with which artery?

A. Common peroneal

B. Posterior tibial

C. Deep peroneal

D. Anterior tibial

Here is the correct answer with a detailed anatomical explanation:

 

🦵 Deep Peroneal (Fibular) Nerve – Accompanying Artery

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Common peroneal

❌ Incorrect

The common peroneal nerve gives rise to the deep and superficial peroneal nerves, but does not travel with the deep peroneal nerve through the leg.

B. Posterior tibial

❌ Incorrect

The posterior tibial artery runs in the posterior compartment of the leg with the tibial nerve, not the deep peroneal nerve.

C. Deep peroneal

❌ Invalid option

This is a nerve, not an artery, so it can't "travel with itself."

D. Anterior tibial

✅ Correct

The deep peroneal (fibular) nerve travels in the anterior compartment of the leg alongside the anterior tibial artery, supplying dorsiflexors of the foot and extensors of the toes.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. Anterior tibial

Let me know if you’d like a compartment-wise summary of the nerves and vessels of the leg.

355

Which of the following factors is themost importantin stabilizing the patella?

A. The lowest fibres of the vastus medialis

B. The forward prominence of the lateral femoral condyle

C. The ligamentous tension of the medial patella retinaculum

D. The pull of the of the quadriceps muscles

Here is the correct answer with detailed anatomical reasoning:

 

🦵 Stabilization of the Patella – Question Review

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. The lowest fibres of the vastus medialis

✅ Correct

The lowest fibers of the vastus medialis obliquus (VMO) insert into the medial border of the patella at an oblique angle, providing a medial stabilizing force that prevents lateral displacement of the patella — particularly during the last 20–30° of knee extension. This is considered the most important dynamic stabilizer of the patella.

B. The forward prominence of the lateral femoral condyle

❌ Incorrect

While the bony anatomy does help resist lateral dislocation, it is a static constraint and not as effective or critical as the VMO.

C. The ligamentous tension of the medial patella retinaculum

❌ Incorrect

The medial retinaculum does contribute to patellar stability, but it is not as important as the active muscular control from VMO.

D. The pull of the quadriceps muscles

❌ Incorrect

The quadriceps pull as a whole actually has a lateralizing force on the patella, especially the rectus femoris and vastus lateralis, which can predispose to lateral displacement unless balanced by the VMO.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. The lowest fibres of the vastus medialis

Let me know if you’d like a summary table of patellar stabilizers (static vs dynamic).

356

Regarding the medial longitudinal arch of the foot, which of the following isfalse?

A. The most important muscular supporting structure is the tendon of flexor hallucis longus

B. The most important ligament is the plantar aponeurosis

C. Bones contribute little to arch stability

D. The pillars of the arch are the tuberosity of the calcaneus posteriorly and the bodies of the three metatarsal bones anteriorly

Here are direct quotes from Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy (7th Ed.) supporting each statement about the medial longitudinal arch of the foot:

 

✅ A. The most important muscular supporting structure is the tendon of flexor hallucis longus

"Flexors hallucis and digitorum longus for the longitudinal arch... [are dynamic supports involved in maintaining the arches of the foot]"

"The flexor hallucis longus tendon... supports the medial longitudinal arch."

Moore - Clinically Orie…

 

✅ B. The most important ligament is the plantar aponeurosis

"Of these factors, the plantar ligaments and the plantar aponeurosis bear the greatest stress and are most important in maintaining the arches of the foot."

Moore - Clinically Orie…

 

❌ C. Bones contribute little to arch stability — This is false

"Passive factors involved in forming and maintaining the arches of the foot include: the shape of the united bones (both arches, but especially the transverse arch)."

"The integrity of the bony arches of the foot is maintained by both passive factors and dynamic supports."

Moore - Clinically Orie…

 

✅ D. The pillars of the arch are the tuberosity of the calcaneus posteriorly and the bodies of the three metatarsal bones anteriorly

"The medial longitudinal arch is composed of the calcaneus, talus, navicular, three cuneiforms, and three metatarsals. The talar head is the keystone."

"The calcaneus is common to both longitudinal arches."

Moore - Clinically Orie…

 

Let me know if you'd like a visual schematic or clinical cases related to arch collapse or flatfoot.

357

The internal thoracic artery is a branch of which of the following?

A. Subclavian artery

B. Axillary artery

C. Thyrocervical trunk

D. Vertebral artery

The correct answer is: A. Subclavian artery

 

Explanation:

The internal thoracic artery (also called the internal mammary artery) arises from the:

  • First part of the subclavian artery, just opposite the thyrocervical trunk.

Course:

  • It descends posterior to the clavicle and first costal cartilage, along the inner surface of the anterior thoracic wall, just lateral to the sternum.
  • It gives off anterior intercostal branches and perforating branches.
  • Terminates around the 6th intercostal space by dividing into:
    • Superior epigastric artery
    • Musculophrenic artery

 

Other options briefly:

  • B. Axillary artery: Continuation of subclavian beyond 1st rib – not the origin.
  • C. Thyrocervical trunk: Another branch of subclavian, gives off inferior thyroid, transverse cervical, and suprascapular arteries, not internal thoracic.
  • D. Vertebral artery: Also from subclavian, ascends to the brain via transverse foramina of cervical vertebrae.

 

So again, the internal thoracic artery arises from the subclavian artery – Answer A is correct.

358

With regard to the femoral nerve, which of the following statements is correct?

A. It enters the thigh by passing deep to the inguinal ligament lateral to the artery in the femoral sheath.

B. Deep and superficial branches of the nerve are separated by the lateral femoral circumflex artery

C. It runs in the adductor canal

D. The nerve originates from anterior divisions of the anterior rami of the lumbar nerves

The correct answer is:

B. Deep and superficial branches of the nerve are separated by the lateral femoral circumflex artery — ✅ Correct

 

✅ Explanation of Each Option:

 

A. It enters the thigh by passing deep to the inguinal ligament lateral to the artery in the femoral sheath — ❌ Incorrect

  • The femoral nerve does pass deep to the inguinal ligament, but it is not within the femoral sheath.
  • It lies lateral to the femoral artery, outside the sheath.

 

B. Deep and superficial branches of the nerve are separated by the lateral femoral circumflex artery — ✅ Correct

  • As the femoral nerve divides in the femoral triangle into anterior (superficial) and posterior (deep) divisions, the lateral femoral circumflex artery courses between them.
  • This is a classic anatomical landmark.

 

C. It runs in the adductor canal — ❌ Incorrect

  • The femoral nerve itself does not enter the adductor canal.
  • Only the saphenous nerve (a branch of the femoral nerve) continues into the canal.

 

D. The nerve originates from anterior divisions of the anterior rami of the lumbar nerves — ❌ Incorrect

  • The femoral nerve arises from the posterior divisions of the anterior rami of L2–L4.
  • (A common point of confusion!)

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., section on femoral nerve anatomy, course, and branches in the thighMoore - Clinically Orie….

359

Following a fracture of a bone in the lower limb, you notice a patient has a high stepping gait. A fracture of which structure would most likely be responsible for this?

A. Proximal fibula

B. Femur

C. Mid-shaft fibula

D. Proximal tibia

A high stepping gait, also known as a steppage gait or neuropathic gait, is characterized by the patient excessively lifting their leg (flexing at the hip and knee) to clear the foot off the ground. This is done to compensate for foot drop, which is the inability to dorsiflex (lift the front part of) the foot at the ankle.

Foot drop is primarily caused by weakness or paralysis of the muscles in the anterior compartment of the leg, which are responsible for dorsiflexion. These muscles are innervated by the deep peroneal nerve (deep fibular nerve), which is a branch of the common peroneal nerve.

The common peroneal nerve (a branch of the sciatic nerve) is highly vulnerable to injury as it courses superficially around the neck of the fibula.

Let's look at the fracture options:

  • A. Proximal fibula: A fracture of the proximal fibula, particularly the fibular neck, is the most common bony injury associated with damage to the common peroneal nerve. As the nerve wraps around this area, it can be stretched, compressed, or even severed, leading to foot drop and a high stepping gait.
  • B. Femur: A fracture of the femur (thigh bone) is less likely to directly cause a common peroneal nerve injury leading to foot drop. While a high-energy femur fracture could theoretically cause a more proximal sciatic nerve injury (which would affect the common peroneal nerve), the direct and most common association with foot drop is a fibular neck injury. Femur fractures are more likely to cause femoral nerve damage (affecting quadriceps and sensation on anterior thigh/medial leg) or general vascular injury.
  • C. Mid-shaft fibula: A mid-shaft fibula fracture is generally less likely to injure the common peroneal nerve compared to a fracture at the neck, as the nerve has already divided and is less exposed to direct trauma at this level.
  • D. Proximal tibia: A proximal tibia fracture (e.g., tibial plateau fracture) can certainly involve nerves, particularly if there's significant soft tissue swelling or compartment syndrome. However, direct common peroneal nerve injury is more classically associated with the fibular neck due to the nerve's anatomical course. Tibial fractures might affect the tibial nerve more, which would lead to problems with plantarflexion and sensation on the sole of the foot, not typically foot drop and a high stepping gait.

Therefore, a fracture of the proximal fibula is the most likely cause of a high stepping gait due to common peroneal nerve damage.

The final answer is A​

360

Regarding myotomes, which of the following statements is correct?

A. Shoulder adduction is C5

B. Foot inversion is L4, L5

C. Knee is flexion is L3,4

D. myotome is a muscle supplied by single peripheral nerve

Here is the correct answer with detailed neuroanatomical explanation:

 

🧠 Myotomes – Question Review

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Shoulder adduction is C5

❌ Incorrect

Shoulder adduction is primarily C6–C8, involving muscles like pectoralis major and latissimus dorsi. C5 is more associated with abduction (deltoid, supraspinatus).

B. Foot inversion is L4, L5

✅ Correct

Foot inversion is mediated by the tibialis anterior (L4) and tibialis posterior (L5), making L4–L5 the correct myotomal level for this movement.

C. Knee flexion is L3,4

❌ Incorrect

Knee flexion is mediated by the hamstrings, which are supplied by L5–S2. L3–L4 are responsible for knee extension (quadriceps).

D. Myotome is a muscle supplied by single peripheral nerve

❌ Incorrect

A myotome is a group of muscles innervated by fibers from a single spinal nerve root, not a single peripheral nerve. A peripheral nerve often contains fibers from multiple roots.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Foot inversion is L4, L5

Let me know if you'd like a full chart of key myotomes and their associated movements for clinical testing.

361

Which of the following is the most anterior structure in the thoracic inlet?

A. Subclavian vein

B. Vagus nerve

C. Right subclavian artery

D. Thoracic duct

Here is the correct answer with detailed anatomical reasoning:

 

🫁 Thoracic Inlet (Superior Thoracic Aperture) – Anterior Structure Review

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Subclavian vein

✅ Correct

The subclavian vein is the most anterior major structure in the thoracic inlet. It runs anterior to the anterior scalene muscle and lies just posterior to the clavicle, making it easily accessible for central venous access.

B. Vagus nerve

❌ Incorrect

The vagus nerve runs posterior to the subclavian vein and crosses anterior to the subclavian artery, but is not the most anterior structure.

C. Right subclavian artery

❌ Incorrect

The subclavian artery lies posterior to the subclavian vein and passes between the anterior and middle scalene muscles.

D. Thoracic duct

❌ Incorrect

The thoracic duct is a deep, posterior structure that ascends on the left side, typically posterior to the esophagus, and empties into the junction of the left subclavian and internal jugular veins.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Subclavian vein

Let me know if you’d like a cross-sectional diagram of the thoracic inlet and its key structures!

362

Which is not a common branch of the basilar artery?

A. Pontine branches

B. Anterior inferior cerebellar artery

C. Labyrinthine artery

D. Superior cerebellar

Here is the correct answer with detailed anatomical explanation:

 

🧠 Branches of the Basilar Artery – Question Review

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Pontine branches

✅ True (Common branch)

These are numerous small branches arising directly from the basilar artery to supply the pons.

B. Anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA)

✅ True (Common branch)

The AICA is a typical branch of the basilar artery and supplies the anterior inferior cerebellum and parts of the brainstem.

C. Labyrinthine artery

❌ Correct Answer (Not a common branch)

The labyrinthine artery usually arises from the AICA, but it can sometimes come directly from the basilar artery. Because of this variable origin, it is not considered a consistent/common branch of the basilar artery.

D. Superior cerebellar artery

✅ True (Common branch)

This artery arises just before the bifurcation of the basilar artery into posterior cerebral arteries, and it supplies the superior cerebellum and midbrain.

 

 

❌ Correct Answer: C. Labyrinthine artery

 

🧠 Bonus:

The basilar artery commonly gives off:

  • Pontine branches
  • AICA
  • Superior cerebellar artery
  • Ends as posterior cerebral arteries

Let me know if you'd like a labeled diagram of the vertebrobasilar circulation!

363

Regarding the deep fascia, which of the following is incorrect?

A. It is anchored firmly to the periostium

B. It is insensate

C. It forms the retinaculae

D. It is not present in the face

The correct answer is:

B. It is insensate — ✅ Incorrect (i.e., false statement)

 

✅ Explanation:

Let’s examine each option based on Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy (7th Ed.):

 

A. It is anchored firmly to the periosteum — ✅ True

  • Deep fascia is firmly attached to bone via the periosteum, especially at bony prominences and along fascial septa.

 

B. It is insensate — ❌ False ✅

  • This is the incorrect statement.
  • Deep fascia is richly innervated, particularly with pain-sensitive nerve endings.
  • This is clinically relevant, as fasciitis and compartment syndrome cause significant pain due to pressure within deep fascial compartments.

 

C. It forms the retinaculae — ✅ True

  • Thickened areas of deep fascia at joints form retinacula (e.g., flexor and extensor retinacula at the wrist and ankle) to hold tendons in place.

 

D. It is not present in the face — ✅ True

  • The face lacks deep fascia; it has superficial fascia that contains muscles of facial expression, allowing for mobility.

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., section on fascia and clinical relevance of deep fascia in limb compartmentsMoore - Clinically Orie….

364

Regrading the anterior spinal artery, which is CORRECT?

A. The artery supplies the anterior grey and white columns of both sides

B. It is a branch of the vertebral or posterior inferior cerebral artery

C. It is uniform in size throughout the length of the spinal cord

D. There are two anterior spinal arteries and one posterior spinal artery that supply the spinal cord

Answer: A. The artery supplies the anterior grey and white columns of both sides

 

Explanation

  • The anterior spinal artery is formed by the joining of small branches from each vertebral artery high in the neck.
  • It runs in the anterior median fissure, supplying roughly the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord on both sides, including:
    • Anterior (ventral) grey horns (motor cell bodies)
    • Anterior and lateral white matter columns (e.g., corticospinal tracts)

 

Why the other options are incorrect

  • B. It arises directly from the vertebral arteries, not from the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA).
  • C. Its caliber varies along the cord and is bolstered by segmental (radicular) feeders (e.g., the artery of Adamkiewicz).
  • D. Anatomical arrangement is one anterior spinal artery and two posterior spinal arteries.

 

Thus, only option A accurately describes the distribution of the anterior spinal artery.

365

Which of the following statements is true of colon?

A. The only part suspended on mesentry is the transverse colon

B. The ascending is longer than the descending colon

C. The marginal artery is weakest at the hepatic flexure

D. The lymphatic drainage is via superior and inferior mesenteric lymph nodes

The correct answer is:

D. The lymphatic drainage is via superior and inferior mesenteric lymph nodes — ✅ True

 

✅ Explanation:

The colon is supplied by and drains lymph through the superior and inferior mesenteric lymph nodes, matching the distribution of its arterial supply:

  • Superior mesenteric lymph nodes:
    • Drain the cecum, ascending colon, and proximal 2/3 of the transverse colon
  • Inferior mesenteric lymph nodes:
    • Drain the distal 1/3 of the transverse colon, descending colon, and sigmoid colon

 

❌ Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:

A. The only part suspended on mesentery is the transverse colon — ❌ False

  • The sigmoid colon is also suspended by a mesentery (sigmoid mesocolon).
  • Therefore, both the transverse and sigmoid colon are intraperitoneal and suspended by mesenteries.

 

B. The ascending is longer than the descending colon — ❌ False

  • The descending colon is usually slightly longer than the ascending colon.
  • Length can vary, but Moore typically describes ascending colon as ~15 cm and descending colon ~25 cm.

 

C. The marginal artery is weakest at the hepatic flexure — ❌ Partially true but oversimplified

  • The marginal artery of Drummond forms a continuous anastomosis along the colon.
  • It may be less robust at the splenic flexure (not hepatic flexure), known as the "watershed area" (Griffith's point) — making this statement incorrect.

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., sections on colon anatomy, lymphatic drainage, and arterial supplyMoore - Clinically Orie….

366

Which of the following structuresdo NOTpass through the transpyloric plane?

A. Tips of the 9th costal cartilages

B. Splenic vein

C. Spleen

D. Superior mesenteric artery

The correct answer is:

C. Spleen — ✅ Does NOT pass through the transpyloric plane

 

✅ Explanation:

The transpyloric plane is an important anatomical landmark located:

  • At the level of L1 vertebra
  • Approximately midway between the suprasternal notch and the pubic symphysis
  • Usually lies at the tip of the 9th costal cartilage

 

✅ Structures that DO lie on or pass through the transpyloric plane:

  • A. Tips of the 9th costal cartilages — ✅ True
    • These define the horizontal level of the transpyloric plane.
  • B. Splenic vein — ✅ True
    • The splenic vein runs posterior to the body of the pancreas, near L1, at the transpyloric level.
  • D. Superior mesenteric artery (SMA) — ✅ True
    • The SMA arises from the aorta at the L1 level, directly on the transpyloric plane.

 

❌ C. Spleen — ❌ False statement (Correct answer)

  • The spleen lies in the left upper quadrant, typically from the 9th to 11th ribs, posterior to the mid-axillary line.
  • It does not lie at the L1 level or on the transpyloric plane — it is higher and more lateral/posterior.

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., section on transpyloric plane and related abdominal structuresMoore - Clinically Orie….

367

Flexor Digitorum Superficialis (FDS), which is CORRECT

A. The Tendons pass beneath the flexor retinaculum, the middle and ring finger tendons lie deep to those to the index and little finger

B. The muscle arises from the medial ligament of the elbow joint and the tubercle on the medial border of the coronoid process of the ulna

C. The FDS flexes the distal phalanges of the medial four fingers

D. It is considered the largest muscle of the deep layer of the forearm

The correct answer is:

B. The muscle arises from the medial ligament of the elbow joint and the tubercle on the medial border of the coronoid process of the ulna — ✅ Correct

 

✅ Explanation:

The Flexor Digitorum Superficialis (FDS) is a muscle of the intermediate layer of the anterior forearm (not deep), and it has three heads of origin:

  1. Humeroulnar head:
    • From the medial epicondyle of the humerus
    • Medial (ulnar) collateral ligament of the elbow
    • Medial border of the coronoid process of the ulna ✅ ← This is what makes option B correct
  2. Radial head:
    • From the oblique line of the anterior surface of the radius

 

❌ Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:

  • A. The tendons pass beneath the flexor retinaculum... — ❌
    • While true that the tendons pass through the carpal tunnel, the arrangement is:
      • Superficial: tendons to the middle and ring fingers
      • Deep: tendons to the index and little fingers
        🔁 This is opposite of what the option states.
  • C. The FDS flexes the distal phalanges of the medial four fingers — ❌
    • FDS flexes the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints, not the distal.
    • FDP (Flexor Digitorum Profundus) flexes the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints.
  • D. It is considered the largest muscle of the deep layer of the forearm — ❌
    • FDS is part of the intermediate layer, not the deep layer.

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., section on anterior forearm muscles and FDS origin/insertion/functionMoore - Clinically Orie….

368

Where is the best place to palpate the radial artery at the wrist?

A. Between the flexor carpis radialis and adductor pollicis longus tendons

B. Anatomical snuffbox

C. Lateral to the abductor pollicis longus tendon

D. Medial to the flexor carpis radialis tendon

✅ Correct Answer: D. Medial to the flexor carpi radialis tendon

 

🧠 Explanation: Where to Palpate the Radial Artery at the Wrist

At the wrist, the radial artery is most easily palpated:

  • Just lateral to the flexor carpi ulnaris (which is not relevant here)
  • But more specifically:
    👉 Medial to the tendon of flexor carpi radialis (FCR)
    👉 Lateral to the tendon of brachioradialis
    👉 In the distal forearm, just proximal to the wrist crease, over the radius (where the artery lies superficial)

 

🔍 Option Breakdown:

Option

Verdict

Reason

A. Between flexor carpi radialis and adductor pollicis longus

❌ Incorrect

The adductor pollicis longus is in the hand, not near the wrist artery pulse

B. Anatomical snuffbox

❌ Incorrect (but close)

Radial artery does pass through here, but it's not ideal for pulse palpation due to depth

C. Lateral to abductor pollicis longus tendon

❌ Incorrect

That’s more proximal, and the artery lies deep here — not best for palpation

D. Medial to the flexor carpi radialis tendon

✅ Correct

This is the standard location for radial pulse palpation at the wrist

 

✅ Final Answer: D. Medial to the flexor carpi radialis tendon

369

A patient presents with a sensory disturbance to the dorsal aspect of their first inter-digital space of the hand has a lesion of which nerve?

A. Medial cutaneous nerve

B. Median nerve

C. Radial nerve

D. Ulnar nerve

 

370

Which bones form the borders of the anterior fontanelle in an infant?

A. 1 frontal, 2 parietals and the squamous bones

B. 2 frontals, 2 parietal bones

C. 2 frontal, 2 temporal and the occipital bones

D. 1 frontal, 1 parietal and 2 frontal bones

✅ Correct Answer: B. 2 frontals, 2 parietal bones

 

🧠 Explanation: Anterior Fontanelle in Infants

  • The anterior fontanelle is the largest and most clinically important fontanelle in a newborn.
  • It is located at the junction of the coronal and sagittal sutures.
  • It is diamond-shaped and typically closes by 18–24 months of age.

 

🔹 Bones forming the borders of the anterior fontanelle:

Bone

Number

Frontal bones

2 (before fusion at the metopic suture)

Parietal bones

2

So the total bones = 4 bones: 2 frontal + 2 parietal

 

❌ Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:

Option

Reason

A. 1 frontal, 2 parietals and the squamous bones

❌ Only 1 frontal is incorrect — in infants, the frontal bone is in 2 parts

C. 2 frontal, 2 temporal and the occipital bones

❌ These form the posterolateral (mastoid) and posterior fontanelles, not anterior

D. 1 frontal, 1 parietal and 2 frontal bones

❌ Repeats and miscounts bones — not anatomically correct

 

✅ Final Answer: B. 2 frontals, 2 parietal bones

371

The abdominal-pelvic lymphnode drainage. Which is INCORRECT?

A. The lymphatic drainage of the testis follows the testicular artery and vein to the right and left lumbar and preaortic lymph nodes.

B. The Inferior half of the rectum drains directly to sacral lymph nodes

C. The sigmoid colon drains to the inferior mesenteric lymphnodes

D. Ovaries, uterine tubes and most of the uterine fundus follow the ovarian veins as they ascend to the external iliac lymph nodes

Here is the correct answer with detailed anatomical explanation:

 

🧬 Lymphatic Drainage of Abdomen and Pelvis – Question Review

Option

Correctness

Explanation

A. The lymphatic drainage of the testis follows the testicular artery and vein to the right and left lumbar and preaortic lymph nodes

✅ Correct

The testes develop in the posterior abdominal wall, so their lymphatics drain to the lumbar (para-aortic) and preaortic nodes, not inguinal nodes.

B. The inferior half of the rectum drains directly to sacral lymph nodes

✅ Correct

The lower rectum drains to sacral and internal iliac nodes. The upper rectum drains to inferior mesenteric nodes.

C. The sigmoid colon drains to the inferior mesenteric lymph nodes

✅ Correct

The sigmoid colon is supplied by sigmoid arteries (from IMA), and lymph drains to inferior mesenteric nodes.

D. Ovaries, uterine tubes and most of the uterine fundus follow the ovarian veins as they ascend to the external iliac lymph nodes

❌ Incorrect (Correct Answer)

The ovaries, uterine tubes, and fundus of the uterus drain to the lumbar (para-aortic) nodes, not external iliac nodes. This follows the path of the ovarian vessels, which ascend to the aorta.

 

 

❌ Correct Answer: D. Ovaries, uterine tubes and most of the uterine fundus follow the ovarian veins as they ascend to the external iliac lymph nodes

 

Let me know if you’d like a full lymphatic drainage chart of pelvic organs or a labeled diagram!

372

Which of the following is correct in relation to the radial nerve?

A. Gives off the posterior interosseus in the spiral groove

B. Runs with the profunda brachii in the radial groove

C. Contains only fibers of C 5,6,7

D. Occupies the entire length of the radial groove

Here is the correct answer with detailed anatomical explanation:

 

💪 Radial Nerve – Question Review

Option

Correctness

Explanation

A. Gives off the posterior interosseous in the spiral groove

❌ Incorrect

The posterior interosseous nerve is a branch of the deep radial nerve, which is given off in the forearm, after the radial nerve passes the lateral epicondyle, not in the spiral groove.

B. Runs with the profunda brachii in the radial groove

✅ Correct

The radial nerve travels in the radial (spiral) groove of the humerus alongside the profunda brachii artery. This is a key neurovascular relationship in the posterior arm.

C. Contains only fibers of C5, C6, C7

❌ Incorrect

The radial nerve contains fibers from C5 to T1 (C5, C6, C7, C8, T1), as it arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus.

D. Occupies the entire length of the radial groove

❌ Incorrect

The radial nerve does not run the full length of the groove. It enters the radial groove mid-shaft and exits laterally near the lateral intermuscular septum, so it only occupies a portion of the groove.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Runs with the profunda brachii in the radial groove

 

Let me know if you'd like a diagram showing the course and branches of the radial nerve.

373

Regarding the right coronary artery which of the following statements is correct?

A. Supplies 60% of atrio-ventricular (AV) nodes

B. Its course is through the left auricle and infundibulum

C. Supplies 30% of sino-atrial (SA) nodes

D. The RCA arises form the right aortic sinus

The correct answer is:

D. The RCA arises from the right aortic sinus — ✅ Correct

 

✅ Explanation:

The right coronary artery (RCA) is one of the two main arteries arising from the ascending aorta, and it has specific anatomical origins and branches.

 

🔍 Option Breakdown:

 

A. Supplies 60% of atrioventricular (AV) nodes — ❌ Incorrect

  • The RCA supplies the AV node in ~80% of individuals, not 60%.

 

B. Its course is through the left auricle and infundibulum — ❌ Incorrect

  • The RCA passes between the right auricle and pulmonary trunk, not the left auricle or infundibulum.

 

C. Supplies 30% of sinoatrial (SA) nodes — ❌ Incorrect

  • In ~60% of people, the SA nodal branch arises from the RCA (not 30%).

 

D. The RCA arises from the right aortic sinus — ✅ Correct

  • The right coronary artery originates from the right aortic (anterior) sinus of the ascending aorta, just above the right cusp of the aortic valve.

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., section on coronary circulation and anatomy of the right coronary arteryMoore - Clinically Orie….

374

The infra-orbital nerve innervates all of the following parts of the faceEXCEPT?

A. Dorsum and apex of the nose

B. Mucosa of incisor maxillary teeth

C. Skin of the oral mucosa of superior lip

D. Conjunctiva of the inferior eye lid.

The correct answer is:

A. Dorsum and apex of the nose — ✅ EXCEPT

 

✅ Explanation:

The infra-orbital nerve is a terminal branch of the maxillary division (V2) of the trigeminal nerve. After emerging from the infraorbital foramen, it gives off several sensory branches.

 

Structures Supplied by the Infra-orbital Nerve:

  1. B. Mucosa of the incisor maxillary teeth — ✅ Supplied
    • Via its anterior superior alveolar branches.
  2. C. Skin of the oral mucosa of superior lip — ✅ Supplied
    • Via the superior labial branches.
  3. D. Conjunctiva of the inferior eyelid — ✅ Supplied
    • Via palpebral branches.

 

A. Dorsum and apex of the nose — ❌ Not supplied by infra-orbital nerve

  • These are supplied by:
    • External nasal branch of the anterior ethmoidal nerve, which is a branch of the nasociliary nerve (from ophthalmic division V1).
  • Thus, this region is innervated by V1, not V2 (infra-orbital nerve).

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., section on cutaneous innervation of the face and branches of the trigeminal nerveMoore - Clinically Orie….

375

An elderly lady suffers a subcapital neck of femur fracture. She is at risk of avascular necrosis of the femoral head. Injury to which artery is responsible for this disease?

A. Artery to head of femur

B. Medial circumflex artery

C. Descending branch of superior gluteal artery

D. Descending branch of inferior gluteal artery

The correct answer is:

B. Medial circumflex artery — ✅ Responsible for avascular necrosis in femoral neck fractures

 

✅ Explanation:

In elderly individuals, especially those with subcapital neck of femur fractures (just below the head of the femur), the blood supply to the femoral head can be compromised, leading to avascular necrosis (AVN).

 

🩸 Primary blood supply to the femoral head:

  • The main source in adults is the retinacular arteries, which are branches of the medial femoral circumflex artery.
  • These vessels travel along the neck of the femur within the capsule, and are highly susceptible to injury in intracapsular fractures.

 

❌ Why Other Options Are Incorrect:

  • A. Artery to head of femur — ❌
    • A small branch from the obturator artery via the ligamentum teres — minor contribution in adults; mainly important in children.
  • C. Descending branch of superior gluteal artery — ❌
    • Supplies gluteal muscles, not the femoral head.
  • D. Descending branch of inferior gluteal artery — ❌
    • Also supplies posterior thigh, not significant for the femoral head.

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., section on hip joint blood supply and avascular necrosis risk in femoral neck fracturesMoore - Clinically Orie….

376

Which of the following muscles of the lower leg can initiate dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot?

A. Tibialis anterior

B. Tibialis posterior

C. Peroneus tertius

D. Peroneus longus

The muscle of the lower leg that can initiate both dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot is the A. Tibialis anterior.

Here's a breakdown of the actions of each muscle:

  • A. Tibialis anterior: This is the primary dorsiflexor of the foot (lifting the foot upwards towards the shin) and also a strong inverter of the foot (turning the sole of the foot inwards).
  • B. Tibialis posterior: This muscle is primarily a plantarflexor (pointing the foot downwards) and a strong inverter of the foot. It does not perform dorsiflexion.
  • C. Peroneus tertius (Fibularis tertius): This muscle is a weak dorsiflexor and an everter of the foot (turning the sole of the foot outwards). It does not perform inversion.
  • D. Peroneus longus (Fibularis longus): This muscle is a strong plantarflexor and everter of the foot. It does not perform dorsiflexion or inversion.

377

Which of the following muscles isnot suppliedby the posterior interosseus nerve?

A. Brachioradialis

B. Supinator

C. Abductor pollicis longus

D. Extensor carpi ulnaris

Here is the correct answer with detailed anatomical explanation:

 

💪 Posterior Interosseous Nerve – Muscle Supply Review

Option

Correctness

Explanation

A. Brachioradialis

❌ Correct Answer

The brachioradialis is supplied by the radial nerve before it branches into the superficial and deep branches (i.e. before giving rise to the posterior interosseous nerve). It is not supplied by the posterior interosseous nerve.

B. Supinator

✅ Correct

The supinator is supplied by the posterior interosseous nerve, which actually pierces the supinator to enter the posterior forearm compartment.

C. Abductor pollicis longus

✅ Correct

This muscle is a deep extensor and is supplied by the posterior interosseous nerve.

D. Extensor carpi ulnaris

✅ Correct

Another posterior compartment muscle, innervated by the posterior interosseous nerve.

 

 

❌ Correct Answer: A. Brachioradialis

 

🧠 Key Point:

  • The posterior interosseous nerve (a continuation of the deep branch of the radial nerve) supplies most of the extensor muscles in the posterior forearm — except for a few muscles like brachioradialis, extensor carpi radialis longus, and part of ECR brevis, which are innervated by the radial nerve proper before it splits.

Let me know if you’d like a nerve supply chart of forearm muscles!

378

All of the following make up the lateral longitudinal arch except?

A. Talus

B. Calcaneus

C. lateral two metatarsals

D. Cuboid

The lateral longitudinal arch of the foot is primarily formed by the following bones:

  • Calcaneus (heel bone)
  • Cuboid
  • Fourth and fifth metatarsals

Looking at the options:

  • A. Talus: The talus is a key component of the medial longitudinal arch, not the lateral.
  • B. Calcaneus: This is a major bone of the posterior pillar of the lateral longitudinal arch.
  • C. Lateral two metatarsals (4th and 5th): These form the anterior pillar of the lateral longitudinal arch.
  • D. Cuboid: The cuboid is the "keystone" of the lateral longitudinal arch.

Therefore, the bone that does not make up the lateral longitudinal arch is the A. Talus.

379

Which of the following eye muscles depresses, adducts and laterally rotates the eyeball?

A. Superior rectus

B. Inferior rectus

C. Inferior oblique

D. Superior oblique

 

🧠 Explanation:

Let’s break down the actions of the superior oblique muscle:

  • Primary action: Intorsion (medial rotation)
  • Secondary actions:
    • Depression (when the eye is adducted)
    • Abduction (moves eye outward)

 

❗ But the key here is to focus on the combined actions of:

  • Depression
  • Adduction
  • Lateral rotation (extorsion or intorsion?)

And here's where the confusion often comes in:

Muscle

Depression

Adduction

Rotation

Superior oblique

✅ Yes (in adduction)

✅ Yes

✅ Intorsion (medial rotation)

Inferior rectus

✅ Yes

✅ Yes

❌ Extorsion (lateral rotation)

 

🚨 So, since the question asks:

"Which muscle depresses, adducts, and laterally rotates the eyeball?"

  • That actually fits Inferior rectus, not superior oblique.

❗ Final correction:

  • D. Superior oblique = depresses, adducts, medially rotates (intorsion) — ❌
  • B. Inferior rectus = depresses, adducts, laterally rotates (extorsion) — ✅

 

✅ Corrected Final Answer: B. Inferior rectus

380

Which ligament of the knee forms part of the capsule?

A. Anterior cruciate

B. Medial collateral

C. Posterior cruciate

D. Popliteus tendon

Here is the correct answer with anatomical explanation:

 

🦵 Knee Joint – Capsular Ligament Review

Option

Answer

Explanation

A. Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL)

❌ Incorrect

The ACL is intracapsular but extrasynovial and does not form part of the fibrous capsule of the knee.

B. Medial collateral ligament (MCL)

✅ Correct

The MCL (also called tibial collateral ligament) is broad and flat, and its deep fibers are fused with the joint capsule and medial meniscus, making it a true capsular ligament.

C. Posterior cruciate ligament (PCL)

❌ Incorrect

Like the ACL, the PCL is intracapsular but extrasynovial and does not contribute to the capsule.

D. Popliteus tendon

❌ Incorrect

The popliteus tendon pierces the capsule to reach the lateral femoral condyle but is not part of the capsule itself.

 

 

✅ Correct Answer: B. Medial collateral ligament

 

🧠 Clinical Tip:

  • Injury to the MCL can also affect the medial meniscus due to their shared capsule connection.

Let me know if you'd like a labeled diagram of the knee ligaments or capsule.

381

An 80-year-old lady with atrial fibrillation presents with acute abdominal pain. Which part of the vasculature of the bowel is most likely to be compromised?

A. Transverse colon

B. Duodenum

C. Jejunum

D. Sigmoid colon

The correct answer is:

C. Jejunum

 

✅ Explanation:

In a patient with atrial fibrillation who develops acute abdominal pain, the most likely underlying cause is an embolic event leading to acute mesenteric ischemia.

 

🔍 Why the jejunum is most vulnerable:

  • Atrial fibrillation predisposes to embolism.
  • Emboli from the heart typically lodge in the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) because:
    • It arises at a sharper angle from the aorta
    • It has a relatively large diameter
  • The SMA supplies the jejunum, ileum, cecum, ascending colon, and proximal 2/3 of the transverse colon.
  • The jejunum and ileum are particularly vulnerable due to their long vasa recta and high metabolic demand.

 

❌ Why the other options are less likely:

  • A. Transverse colon — partially supplied by SMA and IMA, but less vulnerable than the jejunum
  • B. Duodenum — supplied by celiac trunk and SMA, and has rich collateral circulation
  • D. Sigmoid colon — supplied by inferior mesenteric artery, which is less commonly involved in embolic events

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., section on mesenteric circulation and bowel ischemia risk zonesMoore - Clinically Orie….

382

Regarding the blood supply of the cerebral cortex, which of the following statements is true?

A. The territory of the middle cerebral artery (MCA) controls the ipsilateral arm, face and vision

B. The territory of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA) controls the contralateral leg, micturition and defacation

C. The territory of the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) controls ipsilateral vision

D. The territory of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA) controls the contralateral leg, auditory and speech

The correct answer is: B. The territory of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA) controls the contralateral leg, micturition and defecation

 

✅ Explanation of the Correct Answer:

  • The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) supplies the medial surface of the frontal and parietal lobes, including:
    • Leg area of the primary motor and sensory cortex → controls contralateral leg movement and sensation
    • Medial frontal lobe, which is involved in micturition and defecation control via the medial frontal micturition center

 

❌ Why the other options are incorrect:

  • A. "The territory of the middle cerebral artery (MCA) controls the ipsilateral arm, face and vision"
    → Incorrect:
    • The MCA supplies the contralateral face and arm areas of the cortex.
    • Vision is primarily supplied by the posterior cerebral artery (PCA).
  • C. "The territory of the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) controls ipsilateral vision"
    → Incorrect:
    • The PCA supplies the occipital lobe, which processes contralateral visual fields (e.g., left PCA lesion → right visual field defect).
  • D. "The territory of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA) controls the contralateral leg, auditory and speech"
    → Incorrect:
    • ACA controls leg, but auditory and speech areas (like Broca's and Wernicke’s) are in the MCA territory.

 

✅ Final Answer: B. The territory of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA) controls the contralateral leg, micturition and defecation

383

What is the function(s) of the lumbricals of the foot?

A. Flexion of the lateral four toes

B. Adduction of the lateral four toes

C. Adduct digits and flex metatarsophalangeal joints

D. Extension of middle and distal phalanges of the lateral four digits

The correct answer is:

D. Extension of middle and distal phalanges of the lateral four digits — ✅ Correct

 

✅ Explanation:

The lumbricals of the foot function similarly to those in the hand. They act on the lateral four digits (toes 2–5) and have a dual action:

  1. Flex the metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joints
  2. Extend the proximal and distal interphalangeal (PIP and DIP) joints

This is achieved because the lumbricals insert into the extensor expansions (dorsal digital expansions) on the dorsum of the toes.

 

🔍 Breakdown of Each Option:

  • A. Flexion of the lateral four toes — ❌ Partially true
    • Only refers to MTP flexion, missing the crucial extension of IP joints
  • B. Adduction of the lateral four toes — ❌
    • Not a function of lumbricals; adduction is performed by plantar interossei
  • C. Adduct digits and flex MTP joints — ❌
    • Again, lumbricals do not adduct; that’s the role of interossei
  • D. Extension of middle and distal phalanges of the lateral four digits — ✅
    • This describes the interphalangeal joint extension, which is one of the primary actions

✅ Best answer, even if it doesn’t mention MTP flexion explicitly.

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., section on muscles of the sole of the foot – lumbricals and their actionsMoore - Clinically Orie….

384

A 24-year-old man has been punched to the upper lip and requires repair of a lip laceration in the emergency department. Blockade of which nerve will provide appropriate sensory anaesthesia?

A. Intra-trochlear

B. Infra-orbital

C. Buccal

D. Mandibular

The correct answer is:

B. Infra-orbital — ✅ Provides sensory anaesthesia to the upper lip

 

✅ Explanation:

The infra-orbital nerve is a branch of the maxillary nerve (CN V2), which exits the skull via the infraorbital foramen and supplies:

  • Skin of the lower eyelid
  • Lateral nose
  • Upper lip ✅
  • Cheek and part of the maxillary teeth and gingiva

Thus, a nerve block at the infraorbital foramen will effectively anaesthetize the upper lip, making it ideal for repairing a laceration in that area.

 

❌ Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:

  • A. Infratrochlear nerve — ❌
    • Branch of nasociliary nerve (V1)
    • Supplies medial upper eyelid and side of the nose, not the lip
  • C. Buccal nerve — ❌
    • Branch of mandibular nerve (V3)
    • Supplies cheek mucosa and skin, not the upper lip
  • D. Mandibular nerve — ❌
    • Supplies lower lip, chin, and mandibular teeth, not the upper lip

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., section on cutaneous innervation of the face and sensory branches of the trigeminal nerveMoore - Clinically Orie….

385

Which of the following is not a branch of the axillary artery?
