A. Thoracoacromial

B. Medial thoracic

C. Subscapular

D. Superior thoracic

The correct answer is:

B. Medial thoracic — ✅ Not a branch of the axillary artery

 

✅ Explanation:

The axillary artery is divided into three parts by the pectoralis minor muscle, and it gives off six named branches:

 

📌 Branches of the Axillary Artery:

1st Part (proximal to pectoralis minor):

  • Superior thoracic artery

2nd Part (posterior to pectoralis minor):

  • Thoracoacromial artery
  • Lateral thoracic artery

3rd Part (distal to pectoralis minor):

  • Subscapular artery
  • Anterior circumflex humeral artery
  • Posterior circumflex humeral artery

 

❌ B. Medial thoracic — is not a recognized branch

  • This is not an anatomical artery; the likely intended name is lateral thoracic artery, which is a branch.
  • Thus, “medial thoracic” is not a true branch of the axillary artery.

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., section on axillary artery and its branchesMoore - Clinically Orie….

386

Following an urgent saphenous vein cut down, a patient complains of numbness to the medial border of the foot. Which of the following nerves has been compromised?

A. Saphenous nerve

B. Medial plantar nerve

C. Sural nerve

D. Tibial nerve

A saphenous vein cutdown is often performed in the ankle region, specifically anterior to the medial malleolus. The saphenous nerve runs in close proximity to the great saphenous vein in this area.

Let's examine the sensory distribution of the nerves listed:

  • A. Saphenous nerve: This nerve is a purely sensory branch of the femoral nerve. It provides sensation to the medial side of the leg and ankle, extending down to the medial border of the foot and even the great toe. Injury to this nerve is a known complication of saphenous vein procedures in this region.
  • B. Medial plantar nerve: This nerve is a terminal branch of the tibial nerve. It primarily supplies sensation to the medial two-thirds of the sole of the foot and the medial three and a half toes (including the big toe). While it supplies the foot, its distribution doesn't directly cover the medial border of the foot in the ankle region where a cutdown would typically affect it.
  • C. Sural nerve: This nerve is purely sensory and supplies the posterolateral aspect of the distal leg, the lateral ankle, and the lateral side of the foot to the fifth toe. This is on the opposite side of the foot from the saphenous vein cutdown.
  • D. Tibial nerve: The tibial nerve itself is a large nerve that supplies motor innervation to the posterior leg muscles and sensory innervation to the entire sole of the foot via its terminal branches (medial and lateral plantar nerves, and medial calcaneal branches). Direct injury to the main tibial nerve in an ankle cutdown is less likely to specifically cause numbness to only the medial border of the foot; it would likely result in more widespread sensory and potentially motor deficits.

Given the anatomical proximity of the saphenous nerve to the great saphenous vein in the ankle region, and its sensory distribution covering the medial border of the foot, injury to the saphenous nerve is the most likely cause of the patient's complaint.

The final answer is A​

387

After a tonsillectomy, a patient complains of loss of taste from the posterior tongue. Which nerve has been damaged?

A. Glossopharangeal

B. Hypoglossal

C. Lingual

D. Vagus

The correct answer is A. Glossopharyngeal nerve (Cranial Nerve IX).

Here's why:

  • Glossopharyngeal Nerve (CN IX): This nerve is responsible for both general sensation and taste sensation from the posterior one-third of the tongue. It also innervates the palatine tonsils, oropharynx, and stylopharyngeus muscle. Due to its close proximity to the tonsillar bed, it is susceptible to damage during a tonsillectomy.

Let's look at why the other options are incorrect:

  • B. Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII): This nerve is primarily a motor nerve to almost all intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue, controlling tongue movement. It is not involved in taste sensation.
  • C. Lingual nerve: This nerve (a branch of the trigeminal nerve, CN V3) provides general sensation (touch, pain, temperature) to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Taste to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is carried by the chorda tympani, a branch of the facial nerve (CN VII), which travels with the lingual nerve.
  • D. Vagus nerve (CN X): While the vagus nerve does carry some taste sensation from the epiglottis and most posterior parts of the tongue/pharynx, its primary role in taste is minimal compared to the glossopharyngeal nerve for the posterior tongue. Its main functions are related to the pharynx, larynx, and thoracic/abdominal viscera.

Therefore, loss of taste from the posterior tongue specifically points to damage of the glossopharyngeal nerve.

388

Which of the following definitions is incorrect?

A. Facet: rough flat area usually covered with cartilage

B. Condyle: rounded, knuckle-like articular head

C. Trochlea: spool like articular process

D. Capitulum: small, round articular head

Let's analyze each definition:

  • A. Facet: rough flat area usually covered with cartilage
    • A facet is indeed a flat or nearly flat articular surface. While typically covered with articular cartilage in living individuals, the definition states "rough flat area," which is not entirely accurate. Facets are generally smooth (when covered with cartilage) for articulation. If it's a "rough" area, it might be for muscle attachment (like a tuberosity or tubercle) rather than articulation.
  • B. Condyle: rounded, knuckle-like articular head
    • This is a good definition. A condyle is a rounded articular projection, often found at the ends of bones forming joints (e.g., femoral condyles, occipital condyles).
  • C. Trochlea: spool-like articular process
    • This is an excellent definition. A trochlea is a pulley-shaped articular surface, allowing for hinge-like movement (e.g., the trochlea of the humerus, which articulates with the ulna).
  • D. Capitulum: small, round articular head
    • This is also a good definition. A capitulum is a small, rounded articular prominence (e.g., the capitulum of the humerus, which articulates with the radius).

Based on the analysis, the definition of a facet is the most inaccurate because it describes it as "rough." Articular facets are designed to be smooth for movement.

The final answer is A​

389

Which muscle attaches to both the tibia and fibula?

A. Extensor digitorum longus

B. Tibialis anterior

C. Flexor digitorum longus

D. Peroneus

The correct answer is:

A. Extensor digitorum longus — ✅ Attaches to both the tibia and fibula

 

✅ Explanation:

The extensor digitorum longus (EDL) originates from:

  • The lateral condyle of the tibia
  • The anterior surface of the fibula
  • The interosseous membrane

➡️ Thus, it is the only option listed that clearly attaches to both the tibia and fibula.

 

❌ Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:

  • B. Tibialis anterior — ❌
    • Originates from the lateral surface of the tibia and interosseous membrane,
    • Does not attach to the fibula
  • C. Flexor digitorum longus — ❌
    • Arises from the posterior surface of the tibia
    • Does not attach to the fibula
  • D. Peroneus (fibularis) — ❌
    • Peroneus longus and brevis originate from the fibula only,
    • Do not attach to the tibia

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., section on muscles of the anterior and posterior compartments of the legMoore - Clinically Orie….

390

Between which muscles does the musculocutaneous nerve run after piercing the coracobrachialias?

A. Biceps and brachioradialis

B. Biceps and brachialis

C. Brachioradialis and supinator

D. Biceps and Flexor Digitorum Profundus

The correct answer is:

B. Biceps and brachialis — ✅ Correct

 

✅ Explanation:

After the musculocutaneous nerve pierces the coracobrachialis muscle, it continues its course:

  • Between the biceps brachii (superficially) and
  • Brachialis (deep)

It then continues distally and emerges lateral to the biceps tendon as the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm, providing sensory innervation to the lateral forearm.

 

❌ Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:

  • A. Biceps and brachioradialis — ❌
    • Brachioradialis is in the forearm, not the arm, and is innervated by the radial nerve.
  • C. Brachioradialis and supinator — ❌
    • Both are in the posterior forearm; not related to musculocutaneous nerve path.
  • D. Biceps and Flexor Digitorum Profundus — ❌
    • FDP is a deep forearm flexor; not involved in the arm-level course of the musculocutaneous nerve.

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., section on musculocutaneous nerve and anterior compartment of the armMoore - Clinically Orie….

391

Which of the following cranial nerves are not mixed nerves(both sensory and motor)

A. CN VI

B. CN IX

C. CN X

D. CN VII

To remember if they are Sensory (S), Motor (M), or Both (B) in order:

Once you have the order mnemonic down, use this one:

  • Some Say Marry Money, But My Brother Says Big Brains Matter More.
    • CN I: Sensory
    • CN II: Sensory
    • CN III: Motor
    • CN IV: Motor
    • CN V: Both
    • CN VI: Motor
    • CN VII: Both
    • CN VIII: Sensory
    • CN IX: Both
    • CN X: Both
    • CN XI: Motor
    • CN XII: Motor

392

Regarding the Brachial plexus, which of the following statements is incorrect?

A. Cords embrace the 2nd part of the axillary artery

B. Divisions form behind the clavicle and enter the anterior triangle

C. Branches of the cords surround the third part of axillary artery

D. Cords enter the axilla above the first part of the axillary artery

The correct answer is:

D. Cords enter the axilla above the first part of the axillary artery — ✅ Incorrect

 

✅ Explanation:

Let’s examine each statement with reference to the brachial plexus anatomy and its relationship to the axillary artery.

 

A. Cords embrace the 2nd part of the axillary artery — ✅ Correct

  • The cords of the brachial plexus (lateral, posterior, and medial) are named according to their position relative to the second part of the axillary artery, which lies posterior to the pectoralis minor muscle.

 

B. Divisions form behind the clavicle and enter the anterior triangle — ✅ Correct

  • The anterior and posterior divisions form behind the clavicle and pass into the axilla, deep to the clavipectoral fascia, not strictly into the anterior triangle of the neck, but this statement reflects common anatomical phrasing.

 

C. Branches of the cords surround the third part of the axillary artery — ✅ Correct

  • Terminal branches like the musculocutaneous, median, ulnar, and others arise around the third part of the axillary artery, distal to pectoralis minor.

 

D. Cords enter the axilla above the first part of the axillary artery — ❌ Incorrect ✅

  • The cords do not enter above the first part of the artery.
  • They are formed distal to the clavicle from the divisions and arranged around the second part of the axillary artery.
  • The roots and trunks lie in the neck, superior to the first rib, but the cords are formed and lie within the axilla, not above the axillary artery.

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., section on brachial plexus formation, parts, and relation to the axillary arteryMoore - Clinically Orie….

393

Myotome C6 performs all upper limb movements EXCEPT?

A. Wrist extension

B. Medial rotation of upper limb

C. Pronation of forearm

D. Elbow extension

✅ Correct Answer: D. Elbow extension

 

🧠 Explanation: Myotome C6

The C6 spinal nerve root contributes to multiple upper limb movements, but not all. Here's what it does and doesn't do:

 

🔹 Movements involving C6 myotome:

Movement

Involvement of C6

Wrist extension

✅ Yes (C6–C7; mainly C6 via extensor carpi radialis)

Medial rotation of shoulder

✅ Yes (C5–C6; subscapularis, pectoralis major)

Pronation of forearm

✅ Yes (C6–C7; pronator teres, pronator quadratus)

 

❌ Movement NOT performed by C6:

Movement

Myotome

Elbow extension

❌ C7 (via triceps brachii) — not C6

 

✅ Final Answer: D. Elbow extension

394

In relation to the brachial artery, which of the following statements is correct?

A. The largest branch of the brachial artery is the radial artery

B. It passes anterior to the medial supra-epicondylar ridge at the elbow joint

C. Is a continuation of the subclavian artery

D. It crosses over the median nerve during its course through the arm

The correct answer is:

B. It passes anterior to the medial supra-epicondylar ridge at the elbow joint — ✅ Correct

 

✅ Explanation:

The brachial artery is the continuation of the axillary artery and runs down the anterior compartment of the arm, supplying the muscles and contributing to the arterial anastomoses around the elbow.

 

🔍 Evaluation of Each Option:

 

A. The largest branch of the brachial artery is the radial artery — ❌ Incorrect

  • The radial artery is a terminal branch, but not the largest.
  • The largest branch of the brachial artery is the profunda brachii artery, which travels with the radial nerve in the radial groove.

 

B. It passes anterior to the medial supra-epicondylar ridge at the elbow joint — ✅ Correct

  • Near the elbow, the brachial artery runs anterior to the medial supracondylar ridge, close to the biceps tendon, and can be palpated just medial to it in the cubital fossa.

 

C. It is a continuation of the subclavian artery — ❌ Incorrect

  • The brachial artery is a continuation of the axillary artery, not the subclavian.
  • The subclavian becomes the axillary artery at the lateral border of the first rib, and the axillary becomes the brachial at the inferior border of teres major.

 

D. It crosses over the median nerve during its course through the arm — ❌ Incorrect

  • The median nerve actually crosses over the brachial artery, not the other way around.
  • In the mid-arm, the median nerve lies lateral to the artery, then crosses anteriorly to become medial.

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., section on brachial artery course, branches, and relationshipsMoore - Clinically Orie….

395

Which of the following regarding the anatomical sunffbox is correct?

A. Has extensor pollicis longus on its ulnar side and the abductor pollicis longus (APL) and extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) on the radial side

B. Has trapezoid palpable in the floor of the snuff box

C. Contains the posterior interosseus artery

D. Is most obvious with the thumb abducted and extended

The correct answer is:

A. Has extensor pollicis longus on its ulnar side and the abductor pollicis longus (APL) and extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) on the radial side — ✅ Correct

 

✅ Explanation:

The anatomical snuffbox is a triangular depression on the lateral (radial) aspect of the wrist, most prominent when the thumb is fully extended.

 

🧭 Boundaries of the anatomical snuffbox:

  • Radial (lateral) side:
    • Abductor pollicis longus (APL)
    • Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)
  • Ulnar (medial) side:
    • Extensor pollicis longus (EPL) — its tendon crosses obliquely over the others

So Option A is anatomically accurate ✅

 

❌ Evaluation of Incorrect Options:

  • B. Has trapezoid palpable in the floor of the snuffbox — ❌
    • The floor is formed by the scaphoid and trapezium bones, but scaphoid is the most palpable.
    • Trapezoid is deeper and not easily palpable.
  • C. Contains the posterior interosseous artery — ❌
    • The radial artery passes through the floor of the snuffbox, not the posterior interosseous artery.
  • D. Is most obvious with the thumb abducted and extended — ❌
    • The snuffbox is most prominent when the thumb is extended, not abducted.
    • Extension tightens the tendons that define the borders.

 

📚 Reference:

Moore’s Clinically Oriented Anatomy, 7th Ed., section on anatomical snuffbox boundaries and contentsMoore - Clinically Orie….
